If also H is anchored in a finite set, then the latter expression equals [ι(H),ι(H′)] with [·,·] the standard commutator on A. Derivations The action of an interaction H on Aal by [H, ·] is an (unbounded) derivation. It is the derivation, rather then the interaction itself, that determines the almost local evolution αH. One should notice that distinct H ≠ H′ can give rise to the same derivation, which complicates some of our calculations. Therefore, we introduce the relation ≡ to indicate equality of derivations; H ≡ H′ iff. [H, A] = [H′, A] ∀A ∈ Aal Weak sums Given a family of interactions H(n) indexed by n ∈ Z, we define the weak sum ∑n H(n) by (∑ H(n))S = ∑ HS(n), n n provided the right-hand side is absolutely norm-convergent for every S. 4.5.3 Automorphisms Since we consider spin chain algebras A where for every finite S, AS is finite- dimensional, there is a well-defined tracial state τ on A. For a region X, we write τXc : A → A for the corresponding conditional expectation 1AX ⊗ τXc. This linear map is contracting: ||τXc[A]|| ≤ ||A||. We define a canonical decomposition of observables A ∈ A into finitely suppported terms centered at a given site j ∈ Z, A = ∑k∈N Aj,k, defined by Aj,k = {τBkc(j)[A] − τBkc−1 (j)[A] k > 0 τB0c(j)[A] k = 0 , (4.5.2) where we used the balls Bk(j) = {dist(·,j) ≤ k}. Given an interaction F that is X-anchored and a ∗-automorphism β, we define β[F] by (β[F ])Bk(j) = ∑ 1 (β [FS ])j,k (4.5.3) |X ∩ S| S:S∩X≠∅ for any k ∈ and j ∈ X. For S that are not of the form Bk(j) with j ∈ X, we set (β[F])S = 0. This definition satisfies the following constraint on the N associated derivations. [β[F ], ·] = β ◦ [F, ·] ◦ β−1 (4.5.4) and the integrated version for a TDI H follows from the definition (4.2.1) αβ[H] = β ◦ αH ◦ β−1 (4.5.5) where β[H](s) = β[H(s)]. However, the above definition of β[F] is of course not the unique definition satisfying these properties. For example, if F is X-anchored, then it is also X′-anchored, whenever X ⊂ X′. The transformed interaction resulting from the definition (4.5.3) does in general change upon replacing X by X′, whereas the associated derivations are equal. Let us illustrate a particular and relevant consequence of this. Let αH be an almost local evolution and F an interaction, so that the family αH(s)[F] is defined by (4.5.3) for every s ∈ [0, 1]. Then in general the Heisenberg-like evolution equation αH (s)[F ] − F = i ∫0s du αH (u){[H (u), F ]} is not correct as an equation between interactions, but the equality does hold on the level of derivations, i.e. we do have ∫ s αH (s)[F ] − F ≡ i du αH (u){[H (u), F ]} 0 with ≡ introduced in Section 4.5.2. 4.5.4 Bounds on transformed interactions To state bounds on transformed interactions, we will need to adjust the functions f ∈ F as we go along. It would be too cumbersome to define each time explicity the adjusted function, and therefore we introduce the following generic notion: Definition 4.5.1. We say that fˆ is affiliated to f (and depends on some parameter C) if i. Both f, fˆ are elements of F and fˆ depends only on f (and on the the parameter C). ii. If f(r) ≤ Cβe−cβrβ for some β < 1 and cβ,Cβ > 0, then fˆ(r) ≤ Cβ′e−c′βrβ for some Cβ′,c′β > 0. We will also use repeatedly that max(f1, f2) ∈ F if f1, f2 ∈ F. Lemma 4.5.2. Let F, Fn, n ∈ Z be interactions and H a TDI. Let X, Xn be regions (possibly infinite) and let f, f1, f2 be elements of F. i. If X1 ∩ X2 = ∅, then ||[F1, F2]|| ≤ fˆ(dist(X1, X2)||F1||X1,f1||F2||X2,f2, for fˆ affiliated to f = max(f1, f2). ii. If X = X1 ∩ X2 is not empty, then ||[F1, F2]||X,fˆ ≤ ||F1||X1,f1||F2||X2,f2, for fˆ affiliated to f = max(f1, f2). iii. If all Xn are mutually disjoint, then || ∑ Fn||X,fˆ ≤ sup ||F (n)||Xn,f , X = ∪nXn n n for fˆaffiliated to f. iv. Assume that |||H|||f1 ≤ CH for some CH < ∞. Then ||αH(s)[F]||X,fˆ≤ ||F||X,f2, s ∈ [0,1] for fˆaffiliated to f = max(f1,f2) and depending on CH. Note that the upper bounds are trivial if the interactions are not anchored in the respective sets, see (4.5.1). Since the proofs rely on standard techniques, we refer to the similar statements in [44, 7] and their proofs, see also the proof of Lemma 4.5.5. Item iv is a consequence of the Lieb-Robinson bound. One of the main difference with the cited references is the use of slightly different norms, but they can be shown to be equivalent, see the appendix of [6]. 4.5.5 Inversion, time-reversal, and composition of almost local evolutions We will often need to invert, time-reverse, and compose almost local evolutions. For TDIs H, H1, H2, we set (α−H1)(s) = (αH(s))−1, (4.5.6) (αθH)(s) = α−H1(1) ◦ αH(1 − s), (4.5.7) (αH2 ◦ αH1 )(s) = αH2 (s) ◦ αH1 (s). (4.5.8) Lemma 4.5.3. The families of automorphisms defined in (4.5.7),(4.5.6) and (4.5.8), parametrized by s ∈ [0, 1] are almost local evolutions. More precisely: i. The TDI −αH(s)[H(s)] generates the inverse α−H1. ii. The TDI −H(1 − s) generates αθH, the time-reversal of αH. iii. The TDI H1(s) + α−H11(s)[H2(s)] generates the composition αH2 ◦ αH1 Proof. The proposed families of interactions have a finite ||| · |||f-norm for some f ∈ F by Lemma 4.5.2. They are strongly measurable: If H(s) is strongly measurable, it is the pointwise limit of a piecewise constant interaction; The definition (4.2.1) and the bounds of Lemma 4.5.2 further imply that αH(s) can be approximated by a piecewise constant automorphism. The fact that they generate the given families of automorphisms follows from a direct computation. If ψ(·) is a loop generated by a TDI H, then the time-reversal αHθ generates the time-reversed loop ψθ(·) that was defined in Section 4.3.2. Indeed, using that ψ and ψθ have the same basepoint ψ(0), we verify ψ(0)◦αθH(s) = ψ(0)◦α−H1(1)◦αH(1−s) = ψ(0)◦αH(1−s) = ψ(1−s) = ψθ(s). We now introduce the notion of a cocyle, associated to an almost local evolution. The cocycle αH (s, u), with u ≤ s, is defined as αH (s, u) = α−H1(u) ◦ αH (s) (4.5.9) so that in particular αH (s) = αH (s, 0). It corresponds to the evolution from time u to time s. The cocyle satisfies the cocyle equation αH(s, u) = αH(s′, u) ◦ αH(s, s′). (4.5.10) and the evolution equation αH(s,u)[A]=A+i ds′αH(s′,u){[H(s′),A]}. ∫ s u In particular, αH (s, u) satisfies the same bound as αH (s) in Lemma 4.5.2(iv). Now we can then state the Duhamel principle: αH2(s)−αH1(s)=i αH2(u){[H2(u)−H1(u),αH1(s,u){·}]}du (4.5.11) ∫ s 0 which is established in the usual way from the Heisenberg equation (4.2.1). Lemma 4.5.4. If H1, H2 are TDIs, then i. The TDI αH1(s)[H2(s) − H1(s)] generates the almost local evolution αH2 ◦ α−H11. ii. The TDI H2(s) − H1(s) + iα−H12(s)[∫ s αH2(u){[H2(u) − H1(u), αH1(s, u){H1(s)}]}du ] 0 (4.5.12) generates the almost local evolution α−H11 ◦ αH2 . Proof. Both claims follow by applying Lemma 4.5.3. For the second claim, one uses the Duhamel principle applied to interactions, more concretely, αH2 (s)[H (s)] − αH (s)[H (s)] ≡ i ∫s 0 αH2 (u){[H2 (u) − H (u), αH (s, u){H (s)}]}du. (4.5.13) 4.5.6 Applications of the Duhamel principle We establish a few consequences of the bounds in the previous sections. Even though they are straightforward, they will be used so often that it is worthwile to highlight them. First of all, we introduce the L1 norm on TDIs, given by |||H |||(X1,)f ∫1 := ds||H (s)||X,f 0 Of, course, we always have |||H|||(X1,)f ≤ |||H|||X,f , but some bounds are stated more naturally in terms of the L1-norm. Lemma 4.5.5. Let X, Y be intervals or complements thereof and let A ∈ AY . i. If F is an interaction anchored in X , then ||[F, A]|| ≤ ||A||||F ||X,f fˆ(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X ∩ Y |) (4.5.14) with fˆ affiliated to f . ii. Let H1, H2 be TDIs satisfying |||H1|||f ≤ CH, |||H2|||f ≤ CH for some constant CH. If H1 − H2 is anchored in X, then ||αH1 (s)[A] − αH2 (s)[A]|| ≤ ||A|||||H1 − H2|||(X1,)f fˆ(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X ∩ Y |) (4.5.15) with fˆ affiliated to f and depending on CH . Note that the intervals are possibly infinite. Also, the right hand side of (4.5.14) is allowed to be infinite, but if it is finite then [F, A] is a well-defined element of A. Proof. We write [F, A] = ∑ [FS , A]. S∩Y ≠∅,S∩X≠∅ Hence, ||[F, A]|| ≤ ∑ ∑ 2||FS||||A|| ≤ 2||A|| ∑ f(1 + dist(y, X))||F||X,f y∈Y S∋y,S∩X≠∅ y∈Y where we used the definition of the f -norm and the fact that f is non-increasing. The bound ∑ f (1 + dist(y, X)) ≤ fˆ(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X ∩ Y |) now holds in the particulya∈rYcase of intervals. For ii) we use Duhamel’s formula (4.5.11) to get αH1 (s)[A] − αH2 (s)[A] = i ∫ s du αH1 (u) ◦ αH2 (s, u){[αH−12(s, u){H1(s) − H2(s)}, A]} 0 (4.5.16) bounded by an expression depending on CH. Therefore, we invoke Lemma 4.5.2 By the results above, α−H12(s,u) is generated by a TDI whose norm is upper item iv) to get ||α−H12(s, u){H1(s) − H2(s)}||X,fˆ ≤ ||H1(s) − H2(s)||X,f uniformly in u, s ≤ 1. Using now item i) above, he argument of {·} in (4.5.16) is in norm bounded by ||H1(s) − H2(s)||X,f ||A||fˆ(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X ∩ Y |), which proves the claim since αH1 (u) and αH2 (s, u) preserve the norm. The next lemma elaborates on the situation when a TDI K is anchored in a set X. If X is finite, then αK(s) is an inner automorphism, i.e. we retrieve the formulas familiar from finite quantum systems: αK (s)[A] = Ad(V (s))[A] (4.5.17) with V (s) ∈ A a unitary family that solves V(s)=1+i duV(u)ι(K(u)). ∫ s 0 Lemma 4.5.6. Let H be a TDI and B a TDI anchored in X, i. There are TDIs K, K′ anchored in X such that αH+B = αH ◦ αK = αK′ ◦ αH. If H, B are G-invariant, then so are K, K′. ii. Let ψ be a pure state andlet X be finite. Then the states ψ ◦ αH+B and ψ ◦ αH are mutually normal. If ψ and H, B are G-invariant, then the relative charge of ψ ◦ αH+B and ψ ◦ αH is zero. Proof. Item i). We use Lemma 4.5.3 and Lemma 4.5.4 to derive expressions for K, K′. Then we use Lemma 4.5.2 to pass the property of being anchored in X from B to K, K′. Item ii). By i) and the fact that K is anchored on a finite set, the remark preceding the lemma ensures that there is a unitary V ∈ A such that ψ′ = ψ ◦ Ad(V ). In particular they are normal with respect to each other. If V is G-invariant, then they have zero relative charge. 4.5.7 Concatenation of almost local evolutions First, we remark that one can often construct almost local evolutions by time- rescaling. This is used so often that we put it in a lemma. Lemma 4.5.7. Let H be a TDI and let j : [0,1] → [0,1] be a piecewise smooth function, with |djd(ss)| ≤ Cj, except for a finite set of times s. Then α−H1(j(0))◦αH(j(·)) is an almost local evolution. Proof. We set K = djd(ss) H (s), except for the finite set of times where the bound |djd(ss)| ≤ Cj does not hold, where we set K(s) = 0. We see that |||K|||f ≤ Cj|||H|||f for any f ∈ F so that the TDI satisfies the necessary bound. The fact that it generates the family α−H1(j(0)) ◦ αH(j(·)) follows from direct computation. For almost local evolutions α, α′, we define the concatenated evolution α □ α′ by (α □ α′)(s) = {αα((21s))◦ α′(2s − 1) 0 ≤ s <1/21/2 ≤ s < 1 (4.5.18) The family of automorphisms (α □ α′)(s) is again an almost local evolution by Lemma 4.5.3. We also note the relation to the concatenation of loops defined in (4.3.3): If ψ, ψ′ are loops with common basepoint and generated by α, α′, then ψ′ ψ is a loop with the same basepoint and generated by α α′. We will now state that composition of almost local evolutions is, in a certain sense, □ □ homotopic, to concatenation of almost local evolutions. Definition 4.5.8. A family (s, λ)↦ → α(λ)(s) is a G-homotopy of almost local evolutions if σ(0)(λ) ◦ α(λ)(s) = α(0)(s) ◦ σ(s)(λ), for any s, λ ∈ [0, 1] with α(λ), σ(s), for each λ, s, generated by G-invariant TDIs Hλ, Fs satisfying the uniform boundedness property (4.3.2) and such that σ(0)(λ) = σ(1)(λ) = Id (4.5.19) Before, the homotopy was defined as a property of a function (s, λ)↦ → ψλ(s) of states. The connection with the above definition is the following: If (s, λ)↦ → α(λ)(s) is a homotopy of almost local evolutions, then (s, λ)↦ → ν ◦ α(λ)(s) is a homotopy, for any choice of state ν. Note that this is a homotopy with fixed basespoint in the sense that the basepoint of the interpolating loops ν ◦ α(λ)(·) is ν for all λ ∈ [0, 1]. To complete the vocabulary, two almost local evolutions α(0), α(1) are called G-homotopic if there exists a G-homotopy α(λ) reducing to α(0) for λ = 0 and to α(1) for λ = 1. Finally, note that the condition (4.5.19) is the analogue of the restriction to loops in Section 4.3.2. If we omit this condition, any local evolution would be homotopic to identity. The main reason to consider homotopy of almost local evolutions, is given by the following lemma. Lemma 4.5.9. i. Let H be a G-invariant TDI and let j : [0, 1] → [0, 1] be a piecewise smooth function, whose derivative is bounded (except for a finite set), and such that j(0) = 0 and j(1) = 1. Then αH(·) and αH(j(·)) are G-homotopic. ii. Let H1, H2 be two G-invariant TDIs. Then αH2 ◦ αH1 is G-homotopic to αH2□αH1. Proof. Item i) We consider the family αλ(s) = α(k(s, λ)), k(s, λ) = (1 − λ)s + λj(s) For any s, the function k(s,·) satisfies the conditions of Lemma 4.5.7 and hence it yields the required almost local evolution σ(s)(·) = α−1(s)α(k(s,·)). The condition (4.5.19) follows from the fact that j(0) = 0 and j(1) = 1. Item ii) For simplicity, let us denote α(s) = αH1(s) and β(s) = αH2(s). We will construct a family αλ(s) interpolating between β ◦ α and β α as λ ranges between 0 and 1. Let □ d(λ) = 12 (1 + λ, 1 − λ) ∈ [0, 1]2, λ ∈ [0, 1]. Let j(λ) : [0, 1]↦ → [0, 1]2 : s↦ → j(λ)(s) = (j1λ(s), j2(λ)(s)) be the continuous and piecewise smooth map defined by j(λ)(s) = {2ds(λd)(λ+) 2(s − 12 )((1, 1) − d(λ)) s ≤ 1/2 s > 1/2 . We note that j(0)(s) = (s, s), j(1)(s) = {(2s, 0) s ≤ 1/2 (1, 2s − 1) s > 1/2 (4.5.20) Then we define the family of automorphisms α(λ)(s) = β(j1(λ)(s)) ◦ α(j2(λ)(s)), λ ∈ [0, 1]. We verify i. α(λ)(0) = Id and α(λ)(1) = β(1) ◦ α(1) because j(λ)(0) = (0, 0), j(λ)(1) = (1, 1). ii. α(0)(s) = (β ◦ α)(s). iii. α(1)(s) = (β α)(s). □ iv. For each λ, α(λ) is an almost local evolution. v. α(λ)(s) = α(0)(s) ◦ σ(s)(λ), with σ(s)(λ) = α(s)−1 ◦ β(s)−1 ◦ β(j1(λ)(s)) ◦ α(j2(λ)(s)) vi. For each s, σ(s) is an almost local evolution. vii. σ(0)(λ) = σ(1)(λ) = Id, so item (v) means that (s, λ)↦ → α(λ)(s) is a homotopy. Item (i–iii) and (vii) are immediate consequences of the definition, using (4.5.20). To check (iv), we use Lemma 4.5.7 to conclude that both β(j1(λ)(·)) and α(j2(λ)(·)) are almost local evolutions and so is their composition by Lemma 4.5.3. Item (v) follows from the definition of α(λ)(s) and (ii). Item (vi) follows from Lemma 4.5.7 upon noting that λ↦ → j(λ)(s) has uniformly bounded derivatives and j(0)(s) = (s, s). 4.6 Hilbert space theory for states equivalent to a product state Although most of our reasoning stays on the level of the spin chain algebra A, some steps are easier taken within the GNS representation. In this section, we establish the tools that we will need from Hilbert space theory. 4.6.1 GNS construction We will make use of the GNS representation of state ψ on A, see [12]. As before, we denote the GNS triple associated to ψ by (H, Ω, π) (Hilbert space H, vector Ω ∈ H, ∗-representation π : A → B(H)), such that ψ(A) = ⟨Ω, π[A]Ω⟩, for any A ∈ A. From the purity of ψ, it follows that π(A)′ = C1 and hence the von Neumann algebra π(A)′′ equals the full algebra B(H). The following lemma, already used in Section 4.3.1, verifies that we are in the setting outlined in Section 4.3.1. HILBERT SPACE THEORY FOR STATES EQUIVALENT TO A PRODUCT STATE Lemma 4.6.1. If ψ is G-invariant, then there is a unique strongly continuous unitary representation G → U(H) : g↦ → U(g), such that U(g)Ω = Ω and π ◦ γ(g) = Ad(U(g)) ◦ π (4.6.1) Proof. By the uniqueness of the GNS representation, up to unitary equivalence, it follows that for each g ∈ G there is a unique unitary U(g) such that U(g)Ω = Ω and such that (4.6.1) holds. From π(A)′ = C1, it also follows that U(g′)U(g)U−1(g′g) is a multiple of identity and by the invariance of Ω, it follows that this multiple of identity is identity. This yields that g↦ → U(g) is a genuine representation. To get the strong continuity of g↦ → U(g), it suffices to get continuity of g↦ → U(g)Ψ for Ψ ∈ D with D ⊂ H dense. We choose D = {π(A)Ω,A ∈ A} and we note that g↦ → U(g)π(A)Ω = U(g)π(A)U∗(g)Ω = π(γ(g)[A])Ω is continuous by the strong continuity of g↦ → γ(g) and the continuity of π. Two pure states ψ,ψ′ are said to be mutually normal5 iff. ψ′ is represented as a pure density matrix ρψ′ in the GNS representation of ψ: ψ′(A) = TrH(ρψ′π(A)). It then follows that the same holds with the roles of ψ, ψ′ reversed. 4.6.2 GNS representation of a product ϕ We construct the GNS representation of a pure, G-invariant product state ϕ in a pedagogical way to render the objects that follow more tangible. (To avoid any possible confusion, we are going to construct a representation that is unitarily algebra of ni × ni complex matrices, that we write as Ai = B(Cni ) For every i, equivalent to the canonical GNS representation.) Recall that Ai is a matrix we choose an orthonormal basis of ni labelled by σ = 0, . . . , ni − 1 such that C ϕ(A) = ⟨0|A|0⟩, A ∈ Ai. The state ϕ corresponds hence intuitively to the -a priori ill-defined- vector . . . ⊗ |0⟩i−1 ⊗ |0⟩i ⊗ |0⟩i+1 ⊗ . . . (4.6.2) The representation Hilbert space H is chosen as H := l2(MZ) 5The term ‘equivalent’ is used more often in the literature, but we avoid this term since it has already another natural meaning within this paper. However, in the zero-dimensional case, the two notions actually coincide. where MX , for X ⊂ Z, is the space of sequences m : X → {0, 1, 2 . . .} such that m(j) < nj and the set {j : m(j) ≠ 0} is finite. We write henceforth HX = ℓ2(MX) and we note the tensor product structure H = HX ⊗ HXc. We now define an isometry KS : ⊗j∈SCnj → HS for finite S, by { KS(⊗j∈S|mj⟩)(m′) = 1 0 m′ = m m′ ≠ m , m, m′ ∈ MS and we lift it to an isomorphism of C∗-algebras by setting πS : AS → B(HS) : A↦ → KSAKS−1. Then the representation π : A → B(H) is fixed by the requirement that its restrictions πAS : AS ⊗ 1Sc → B(HS)) ⊗ 1HSc coincide with πS, for finite S. We note that for finite S, πS = π|AS : π(AS) → B(HS) is an isomorphism, whereas for infinite X, π(AX) is a strict subset of B(HX). In case X is afinite set S, we have equality π(AS) = B(HS) and π restricts to an isomorphism of C∗-algebras between AS and B(HS). In that case, the dual space of functionals on AS is isomorphic to the trace-class operators on HS, equipped with the trace norm || · ||1. The state ϕ is now represented by the vector Ω = δm0,· ∈ H with m0(j) = 0 for all j; ϕ(A) = ⟨Ω, π[A]Ω⟩ and we see that Ω indeed corresponds to the heuristic (4.6.2), and it factors as Ω = ΩX ⊗ ΩXc. We denote by ΠX (and again Π = Π ) the orthogonal projection on the range of ΩX and we abuse notation by also writing ΠX to Z denote ΠX ⊗ 1Xc. We now state a relevant condition for a pure state ψ to be normal with respect to the product state ϕ. We fix intervals in centered on the sites {0, 1}; Z I1 = ∅, Ir = [2 − r, r − 1], r > 1. (4.6.3) Then Lemma 4.6.2. Let ϕ, ψ be a pure states on A and let ϕ be a product. If ||(ψ − ϕ)Irc || → 0 as r → ∞, then ψ is normal w.r.t. ϕ. Proof. Let ρIr be the density matrix on the finite-dimensional Hilbert space HIr representing the state ψIr . We consider the sequence (indexed by r) ρIr ⊗ ΠIrc (4.6.4) and we prove now that this sequence is a Cauchy sequence in trace-norm || · ||1. Let us denote δ(r) = ||(ψ − ϕ)Irc|| and abbreviate ρr = ρIr, Πr,r′ = ΠIr′\Ir for r < r′ and let Trr be the trace on HIr. Then ||ρr′ ⊗ ΠIrc′ − ρr ⊗ ΠIrc||1 = ||ρr′ − ρr ⊗ Πr,r′||1 (4.6.5) ≤ ||ρr′ − Πr,r′ρr′Πr,r′||1 + ||Πr,r′ρr′Πr,r′ − ρr ⊗ Πr,r′||1. (4.6.6) To bound the first term in (4.6.6), we compute, for A ∈ B(Hr′), ||ρr′ − Πr,r′ ρr′ Πr,r′ ||1 = sup | Trr′ [(Πr,r′ ρr′ Πr,r′ − ρr′ )A]| (4.6.7) A∈B(Hr′ ),||A||≤1 √ ≤ 3 Trr′ [ρr′ (1 − Πr,r′ )] sup √Trr′ [ρr′ AA∗] A∈B(Hr′ ),||A||≤1 (4.6.8) ≤ 3 Trr′[ρr′(1 − Πr,r′)] ≤ 3 δ(r) √ √ (4.6.9) where we used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the fact that Trr′ [ρr′ (1 − Πr,r′ )] = ψ(1 − Πr,r′ ) = (ψ − ϕ)(1 − Πr,r′ ). To bound the second term in (4.6.6), we observe that Πr,r′ acts as a rank-1 projector on HIr′ \Ir , hence Πr,r′ ρr′ Πr,r′ is equal to cρr ⊗ Πr,r′ with c ≥ 0. Since c = Trr′ [Πr,r′ ρr′ Πr,r′ ] ≥ 1 − δ(r), the second term in (4.6.6) is bounded by δ(r). It follows that (4.6.4) is indeed a Cauchy sequence and it converges hence to a density matrix ρ. Therefore, the normal states on A, induced by the density matrices (4.6.4) form a Cauchy sequence as well and they have a limit. The limit is necessarily equal to ψ since ψ is obviously a limit point (hence the unique limit point) in the weak∗-topology. We therefore conclude that ψ is represented by ρ. As remarked in Section 4.4.1, this lemma also follows from Corollary 2.6.11 in [12]. Unlike there, the proof given here yields quantitative bounds, whichThen, taking r′ → ∞ in the proof of Lemma 4.6.2, we havewe collect now. We use the notations above, in particular δ(r) = ||(ψ − ϕ)Irc||. ||ρ − ρIr ⊗ ΠIrc||1 ≤ 4√δ(r), (4.6.10) ||ρ − ΠIrcρΠIrc||1 ≤ 3√δ(r). (4.6.11) From (4.6.11), we also deduce ||ρ − TrΠ[ΠIrcIρrcΠρΠIrcIrc ] ||1 ≤ 4√δ(r), (4.6.12) provided that Tr[ΠIrc ρΠIrc ] ≠ 0. 4.6.3 The pumped state and its index In this section we analyze the pumped state that was introduced in Section 4.4.1 for the special case in which the basepoint of the loop is a pure G-invariant product ϕ, as in the previous subsections. We fix this state ϕ in what follows, and we consider a G-invariant TDI H that generates a loop ϕ◦αH(·), satisfying |||H|||f ≤ CH for some f ∈ F and some constant CH. As in Section 4.4.1, we cut the TDI by defining H′ to contain only the terms HS supported on the left, S ≤ 0, obtaining the pumped state ψ = ϕ ◦ αH′(1). (4.6.13) We first establish that ψ is normal w.r.t ϕ. Lemma 4.6.3. There is fˆ affiliated to f and depending on CH such that ||(ψ − ϕ)Irc || ≤ fˆ(r) (4.6.14) Therefore, as a consequence of Lemma 4.6.2, ψ is normal w.r.t. ϕProof. Clearly, ψ is a product ψ = ψ≤0 ⊗ ψ≥1, and ψ≥1 = ϕ≥1. It follows that ||(ψ − ϕ)Irc|| = ||(ψ − ϕ)<2−r|| = sup |ψ(A) − ϕ(A)| A∈A<2−r,||A||≤1 and we now estimate the last quantity: |ψ(A) − ϕ(A)| = |ϕ(αH′(A) − αH(A))| ≤ fˆ(r)||A|| (4.6.15) where the equality follows because ϕ ◦ αH (·) is a loop, and the inequality follows from Lemma 4.5.5 item ii), with the input that H − H ′ is anchored in {≥ 1} and that all constants that appear can be bounded by functions of CH . Since ψ is normal w.r.t. ϕ, and the G-action is implemented by a unitary representation, see Lemma 4.6.1, we can indeed define the index I(ϕ, H) introduced in Section 4.4.1. We will now derive some topological properties of the map H↦ → I(ϕ, H). Properties of the index map I(ϕ, ·) We fix again the product state ϕ and its GNS triple. We also fix f ∈ F and a constant CH. We let S = S(CH, f, ϕ) be the set of G-invariant TDIs such that i. |||H|||f ≤ CH ii. ϕ ◦ αH(·) is a loop To any H ∈ S, we associate the pumped state ψ = ϕ ◦ αH′(1) Let T1,∗(H) the set of pure G-invariant density matrices on H. In particular, ρψ, the density matrix representing the state ψ on H, is in T1,∗(H). We then define the function ρˆ : S → T1,∗(H) : H↦ → ρψ Next, let g↦ → U(g) be the unique unitary representation on H given in Lemma 4.6.1. We set ĥ : T1,∗(H) → H1(G) : ρ↦ → ĥ(ρ) where ĥ(ρ) is the homomorphism G↦ → S1 defined by eiĥ(ρ)(g) = Tr(ρU (g)) ∈ U (1) (4.6.16) Because of the specific choice of U(·), we find that ĥ(ρψ) = hψ/ϕ. We consider S, T1,∗(H), H1(G) with topologies induced by, respectively, the norm ||| · |||(f1), the trace norm || · ||1, and the metric d∞(h, h′) = supg∈G |h(g) − h′(g)|S1. With these choices, the map ĥ is Lipschitz. Indeed, for any ρ(1), ρ(2) ∈ T1,∗(H), d∞(ĥ(ρ(1), ρ(2) )) ≤ CS1 sup | Tr[ρ(1)U (g)] − Tr[ρ(2)U (g)]| ≤ ||ρ(1) − ρ(2)||1. g∈G with CS1 = supθ∈(0,2π] |ei|θθ−|1| < ∞. We now show Lemma 4.6.4. The maps ρˆ : S → T1(H) and I(ϕ, ·) = ĥ ◦ ρˆ : S → H1(G) are uniformly continuous. Proof. We have already remarked that ĥ is Lipschitz, so both claims will be proven once we show that ρˆ is uniformly continuous, which we do now. Consider H(1), H(2) ∈ S and let ρ(j) = ρˆ(H(j)). We have ||ρ(1) − ρ(2)||1 ≤ ||ρ(I1r) ⊗ ΠIrc − ρ(I2r) ⊗ ΠIrc||1 + ||ρ(I1r) ⊗ ΠIrc − ρ(1)||1 + ||ρ(I2r) ⊗ ΠIrc − ρ(2)||1 ≤ ||ρ(I1r) − ρ(I2r)||1 + 8√fˆ(r) where we used the bound (4.6.10) with δ(r) = fˆ(r), by Lemma 4.6.3. To bound the difference ||ρ(I1r) − ρ(I2r)||1, we rewrite it as sup |ϕ ◦ α(H(1))′(1)[A] − ϕ ◦ α(H(2))′(1)[A]| (4.6.17) A∈AIr,||A||≤1 which is bounded by fˆ(1)|Ir||||H(1) − H(2)|||(f1) by Lemma 4.5.5. We hence get ||ρ(1) − ρ(2)||1 ≤ fˆ(1)|Ir| |||H(1) − H(2)|||(f1) + 8√fˆ(r) It it important to note that, since f is fixed, fˆ can be fixed as well. Since fˆ(r) → 0 as r → 0, we can now find a modulus of continuity for the function ρˆ. Finally, we formulate a proposition that will be used crucially in the proof of homotopy invariance of the index map I(ϕ, ·). Proposition 4.6.1. There is an ϵ > 0, such that, if |||H(1) − H(2)|||(f1) ≤ ϵ for H(1), H(2) ∈ S, then I(ϕ, H(1)) = I(ϕ, H(2)). Proof. For a given h ∈ H1, the discreteness of H1 implies that there is an ϵ(h) > 0 such that d∞(h, h′) ≤ ϵ(h) implies h = h′. However, since the metricand one can choose ϵ uniformly on H1. The claim of the proposition follows on H1 is homogenous, namely d∞(h, h′) = d∞(h − h′, 0), we find ϵ(h) = ϵ(0) then from the uniform continuity of the index map I (ϕ, ·) on S , i.e. from Lemma 4.6.4. 4.6.4 Connecting states by adiabatic flow States that are mutually normal, can be connected via an almost local evolution whose generating TDI is anchored in a finite set. In other words, the almost local evolution consists of inner automorphisms. In this section, we establish this statement in a quantitative way, but restricted to the specific setting in which we will need it. The crucial Lemma 4.6.6 below is taken from [33]. Parallel transport for 0-dimensional systems We first exhibit how to connect states on 0-dimensional systems, i.e. states on B(H), with H a Hilbert space. We say that a bounded, measurable function [0, 1] ∋ s↦ → E(s) with E(s) = E∗(s) ∈ B(H) is a zero-dimensional TDI and we set |||E||| = sups∈[0,1] ||E(s)||. The evolution s↦ → αE(s) is then defined as the family of automorphisms that is the unique solution to the equation αE(s)=1+i duαE(s){[E(u),·]}. ∫ s 0 Lemma 4.6.5. Let ν, ω be pure normal states on B(H). Then there exist zero-dimensional TDI E, such that i. |||E||| < 8||ν − ω|| ii. ν = ω ◦ αE(1) iii. If both ν, ω are invariant under a G-action by automorphisms γ(s), and hν/ω = 0, then E can be chosen G-invariant as well. The proof of this lemma uses only basic linear algebra and we postpone it to Appendix A.1. Parallel transport for states normal to ϕ Let ψ be a pure state normal w.r.t. the pure product state ϕ. Recall the definition of the intervals Ir in (4.6.3). Lemma 4.6.6. Let ψ be a pure state and ϕ a pure product state, such that ||(ψ − ϕ)Irc || ≤ f (r), f ∈ F (4.6.18) Then there exist a TDI K such that i. |||K |||{0,1},fˆ < 1 for fˆ affiliated to f . ii. ψ = ϕ ◦ αK (1) iii. If both ϕ, ψ are G-invariant, with zero relative charge hψ/ϕ = 0, then K can be chosen G-invariant. Proof. By Lemma 4.6.2, ψ is normal w.r.t. ϕ. Let ρ be the density matrix on H representing ψ. We set ρr = TrΠ[ΠIrcIρrcΠρΠIrcIrc ] , provided Tr[ΠIrc ρΠIrc ] ≠ 0 (4.6.19) By the bounds (4.6.11) and (4.6.12) with δ(r) = f(r) and the fact that f is non-increasing, there is a finite r0 > 0 such that for r ≥ r0, the denominator (4.6.19) is not zero. For 1 ≤ r ≤ r0, we set simply ρr = Π (which coincides with the definition (4.6.19) for r = 1). In any case, the densities ρr are of the form µr ⊗ ΠIcr with µr pure. We have ||µr+1 − µr ⊗ ΠIr+1\Ir||1 = ||ρr+1 − ρr||1 ≤ ||ρr − ρ||1 + ||ρr+1 − ρ||1 ≤ 4√f(r) + 4√f(r + 1) ≤ 8√f(r) by (4.6.12) with δ(r) = f(r). We now apply Lemma 4.6.5 to obtain a zero-dimensional TDI Er(·) of operators on HIr+1 transporting µr ⊗ ΠIr+1 into µr+1, satisfying the bound sup||Er(s)|| ≤ 8√f(r) (4.6.20) s and we identify Er(·) with Er(·) ⊗ 1Irc+1 so that Er(·) are viewed as operators on H transporting ρr into ρr+1. Since the restricted GNS representation π|AX : AX → B(HX) is bijective for X finite, we can define Kr(s) = π−1(Er(s)) ∈ AIr+1 It remains to assemble this family of time-dependent operators into a single TDI. Let Tr ⊂ [0, 1] be half-open intervals [t, t′) of length (π2/6)−1 × 1/r2 such that min T1 = 0 and sup Tr = min Tr+1. Note that ∪rTr = [0, 1). Then, for s ∈ [0, 1], {|T1r|Kr(|Tr| S = Ir+1,s ∈ Tr for some r ∈ s KS (s) = ) N + 0 otherwise. By construction, ϕ ◦ αK (sup Tr ) is the state corresponding to the density matrix ρr+1 and so ϕ ◦ αK (sup Tr ) → ψ as r → ∞. The bound |||K |||{0,1},fˆ < 1 now follows from the bounds (4.6.20). The other claims simply carry over from Lemma 4.6.5. A LOOP WITH TRIVIAL INDEX AND PRODUCT BASEPOINT IS HOMOTOPIC TO A SHORT LOOP 87 4.7 A loop with trivial index and product basepoint is homotopic to a short loop In this section, we fix again a specific setup. We fix a G-invariant pure product state ϕ on a spin chain algebra, and a G-invariant TDI H such that ϕ ◦ αH (·) is a loop whose index is trivial; I (ϕ, H ) = 0. We also fix an f ∈ F and a constant CH such that |||H|||f ≤ CH. The only aim of this is section is to prove that this loop is G-homotopic to an arbitrarily short loop, in the sense that the norm of the generator is arbitrarily small: Proposition 4.7.1. There exists G-invariant TDIs H˜(R), with R ∈ 2N such that ϕ ◦ α (·) is a loop that is G-homotopic to ϕ ◦ αH (·), and such that H˜(R) Rl→im∞ |||H˜ (R)|||fˆ = 0. for fˆ affiliated to f and depending on CH . The homotopy can be chosen to have fixed basepoint ϕ. Throughout the section, we keep the loop and its generating TDI H fixed, together with f ∈ F and CH . All constants C that appear can depend on CH and f . In particular, we write fˆ for functions affiliated6 to f and depending on CH. Just like for constants C, we will use fˆas a generic notation, and its precise value can hence change from line to line. 4.7.1 Splitting of the loop at a single edge We say that a TDI F is split at an edge (j, j + 1) iff. min S ≤ j < max S ⇒ ∀s : FS (s) = 0. In such a case, we can write F = F≤j + F>j where, obviously, F≤j , F>j consist of terms FS with max S ≤ j and min S > j, respectively. The aim of this section is to modify the TDI H locally, H → H + E(j), such that it is split at (j, j + 1) while still generating a loop with basepoint ϕ, see also Figure 4.4. We write H = H≤j + H>j + Bj, where (Bj)S = χ(min S ≤ j < max S)HS 6As defined in Section 4.5.2 such that H − Bj is split at (j, j + 1). Note that for j = 0, we previously used the notation H′ for H≤0. We recall that the pumped state ϕ ◦ αH≤0(1) is assumed to have zero charge with respect to ϕ. The following lemma uses and strenghtens this statement. Lemma 4.7.1. Let ψ− = ϕ ◦ αH≤j(1), ψ+ = ϕ ◦ αH>j(1) Then the states ψ−|≤j, ψ+|>j have zero relative charge with respect to (in particular: are normal with respect to) ϕ|≤j, ϕ|>j, respectively. Proof. Since ψ− = ψ−|≤j ⊗ ϕ|>j and ψ+ = ϕ|≤j ⊗ ψ+|>j, we have h(ψ−|≤j/ϕ|≤j) = h(ψ−/ϕ), h(ψ+|>j/ϕ|>j) = h(ψ+/ϕ) (4.7.1) fromitemiii)ofProposition4.3.1. Therefore,inwhatfollows,weabusenotation and we write ψ−,ψ+ also for ψ−|≤j,ψ+|>j, as the potential for confusion is small. Then ψ− ⊗ ψ+ = ϕ ◦ αH−Bj(1) = ϕ ◦ αH(1) ◦ αL(1) = ϕ ◦ αL(1) where, by Lemma 4.5.6, L is a G-invariant TDI anchored in {j, j + 1}. The last equality follows because H generates a loop. By invoking the last item of Lemma 4.5.6, we conclude that ψ− ⊗ ψ+ has zero charge wrt. ϕ. Therefore, chosen as j = 0, then the state ϕ− is precisely the pumped state ψ′ defined in using (4.7.1) and Proposition 4.3.1, we have hψ−/ϕ + hψ+/ϕ = 0. If the site j is Section (4.4.1). However, the TDIs H′ = H≤0 and H≤j differ by an interaction anchored in a finite set, therefore the resulting states have equal charge, invoking again Lemma 4.5.6. Since we assumed that the loop generated by H has index zero, the claims follow. φ ◦ αH (s): s=1 s = 3/4 s = 1/2 •••••••••••••• s = 1/4 j j +1 s = 0 H (s): •••••••••••••• φ ◦ αH+E(j)(s): j j +1 H(s) + E(j)(s): Figure 4.4: The TDI H is modified locally around edge (j, j + 1) so that it is split at this edge. This means that H(s) is split for all s ∈ [0, 1]. Lemma 4.7.2. For any site j ∈ Z, there is a G-invariant TDI E(j) with |||E(j)|||{j,j+1},fˆ ≤ C, such that H + E(j) is split at the edge (j, j + 1) and it generates a loop with basepoint ϕ. In particular the affiliated function fˆ can be chosen independently of j. Proof. We fix j and we use again the notation ψ−, ψ+ as above. By the same analysis as the one in the proof of Lemma 4.6.3, we get that ||(ϕ − ψ−)|≤j−r−2|| ≤ fˆ(r), ||(ϕ − ψ+)|≤j+r|| ≤ fˆ(r). We will use Lemma 4.6.6 to connect these states. Even though Lemma 4.6.6 is formulated for states on a spin chain algebra, i.e. referring to the graph A = AZ, with X = {≤ j} and once with X = {> j}, to obtain TDIs K−, K+, supportedit of course holds just as well for states on AX with X ⊂ Z. We apply it onceon {≤ j} and {> j}, and such that ψ− ⊗ ψ+ = ϕ ◦ αK(1), K = K− + K+, |||K±|||{j,j+1},fˆ ≤ 1, with fˆ chosen independently of j. Hence we have now obtained that the path of states ϕ ◦ αH−Bj ◦ α−K1(·) is aloop with basepoint ϕ and it is factorized between {≤ j} and {> j}. The TDI generating this loop is, by Lemma 4.5.4, H + E(j), E(j)(s) = αK(s)[−K(s) − Bj(s)] + (αK(s)[H(s)] − H(s)). To get the desired bounds on the TDI E(j), we use Lemma 4.5.2 and Duhamel’sSince H − Bj and K are split at (j, j + 1), we deduce that E(j) is split as well. formula. 4.7.2 Approximate splitting into factors In the previous subsection, we constructed anchored interactions E(j) that each split the loop at the edge (j, j + 1). Now we will try to split a loop at all edges (Rn, Rn + 1) at once, with n ∈ and R a large even integer. We will however only succeed to do this approximatively, and we will obtain the representation Z αH = αF ◦ αW ◦ αZ where F, W, Z are G-invariant TDIs depending on the parameter R such that i. W is small in the sense that |||W |||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R). ii. F is factorized over the intervals In and Z is factorized over the intervals Jn (both In, Jn have length R and they are defined below). iii. F, Z are close to generating loops: for each n, ||(ϕ − ϕ ◦ αF (1))In|| ≤ fˆ(R), and analogously for Z. The first item is proven as a consequence of Lemma 4.7.4. The second item will be manifest by construction, and the third item is shown in Lemma’s 4.7.5 and 4.7.6. We sketch the rough idea of the proof in Figure 4.5. H •••••••••••••• • ••••••••••••••• F ≈ H + m E(Rm) ∑ In−1 In In+1 H −F ≈ Z ••••••••••••••• Jn Jn+1 Figure 4.5: We represent TDIs by a spatial function, so that edges at which the TDI is split correspond to zeros of this function. By implementing the loop-splitting procedure of Section 4.7.1 at multiple edges, we obtain the TDI F that is split over intervals In and that generates an (approximate) loop. The difference H − F is then split over the intervals Jn. Since H and F generate (approximate) loops with basepoint ϕ, the almost local evolution α−F1 ◦ αH also generates an (approximate) loop with basepoint ϕ. The TDI Z that generates the latter approximate loop would naturally be equal to H − F in the limit of small H and F . In general, Z is not approximately equal to H − F , but it does inherit a crucial property of H − F , namely being (nearly) split over the intervals Jn. In the present and next sections, 4.7.2 and 4.7.3 all TDIs and all states will be G-invariant, and we will not repeat this. Indeed, the triviality of the index of our original loop was used heavily in Section 4.7.1 to argue that the pumped state can be connected to the basepoint, but in the remainder of the proof it plays no role. Splitting the loop into factorized quasiloops Let us introduce the intervals In = [Rn + 1, R(n + 1)], Jn = [R(n − 12 ) − 1, R(n + 12 )] (n ∈ Z). R(n − 2) R(n − 1) Rn R(n + 1) R(n + 2) Jn−1 Jn Jn+1 Jn+2 In−2 In−1 I− I+ In+1 I1+2 Figure 4.6: The various intervals used in the splitting procedure We consider the TDI F˜ = H + ∑ E(Rn) (4.7.2) n∈Z where the infinite sum is understood in a weak sense, as in Section 4.5.2. By Lemma 4.5.2, we have |||F˜|||fˆ ≤ C. Because of the tails of the anchored interactions E(Rn), F˜ is not exactly split overthe intervals In. Therefore, we explicitly define the split interaction F by FS = F˜S Soth⊂erIwnisefor some { n 0 Lbuett Zu˜nbliektehFe ,TtDhIe stuecrhmtshaarteαnZ˜ow= sαu−Fp1p◦orαtHed. oWnetshimeiilnatrelryvdalesfiJnne:its split version, ZS = Z˜S Soth⊂erJwnisefor some { n 0 We will now express that the differences F − F˜, Z − Z˜ are small. We note first that all four of these interactions depend on the parameter R and this is the parameter that controls the smallness, namely Lemma 4.7.3. |||F − F˜|||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R) To avoid confusion, we remind that the two functions called fˆ in the above expression need not be equal, as explained at the beginning of Section 4.7. Proof. Since H + E(Rn) is split at site Rn, the only interaction terms in F˜ = H + ∑n′ E(Rn′) that contain Rn arise from E(Rn′) with n′ ≠ n and hence they correspond to a set S with diam(S) ≥ R. More generally, every term in F − F˜ is of the form FS with diam(S) ≥ R. Therefore |||F − F˜|||√fˆ √fˆ(R)|||F˜|||fˆ. ≤ As we already remarked that |||F˜|||fˆ ≤ C, the lemma is proven. Lemma 4.7.4. |||Z − Z˜|||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R). 4P.r5o.o4f. We recall that Z˜ is defined by αZ˜ = α−F1 ◦ αH and therefore, by Lemma Z˜(s) = H (s) − F (s) − iαH−1(s)[∫ s αH (u){[H (u) − F (u), αF (s, u){F (s)}]}du ] 0 (4.7.3) We write H − F = D1 + D2, D2 = ∑ E(Rn), D1 = F˜ − F, n and we note the following properties |||D1|||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R), |||D2|||RZ,fˆ ≤ C The bound on D1 follows from Lemma 4.7.3. The bound on D2 is by Lemma 4.5.2 item iii) and Lemma 4.7.2. Inspecting (4.7.3) and using again Lemma 4.5.2 items ii,iii), we conclude that the above representation of H − F carries over to Z˜, i.e. Z˜ = D1′ + D2′, |||D1′|||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R), |||D2′|||RZ,fˆ ≤ C By definition, if S intersects more than a single interval Jn and (D2)S ≠ 0, then diam(S) ≥ R/2. Since Z is derived from Z˜ by omitting such terms, we have |||Z − Z˜|||√fˆ ≤ |||D1′|||√fˆ √fˆ(R)|||D2′|||√fˆ ≤ 2√fˆ(R) + which ends the proof. F and Z generate quasiloops We have established that F and Z are manifestly split; F is decoupled over intervals In and Z is decoupled over intervals Jn. So in particular we have that both ϕ ◦ αF and ϕ ◦ αZ are factorized over intervals of length R. Next, in Lemma’s 4.7.5 and 4.7.6, we investigate how close those states are to ϕ, namely how close F, Z are to generating genuine loops. Lemma 4.7.5. Let ψ = ϕ ◦ αF (1). Then ||(ψ − ϕ)|In|| ≤ fˆ(R) Proof. We partition, see Figure 4.6, In = I− ∪ I+, I− = In ∩ Jn, I+ = In ∩ Jn+1. Let us first estimate ||(ψ − ϕ)|I+ ||. Let Fn = H + E(Rn). Then Fn generates a loop with basepoint ϕ by Lemma 4.7.2 and we have, for A ∈ AI+ , ϕ(A) − ψ(A) = ϕ(αFn (1)[A] − αF (1)[A]) (4.7.4) We note now that the TDI F − Fn = ∑n′≠n E(Rn′) is anchored at distance at least R/2 from I−, see Figure 4.6 and Lemma 4.5.2. Therefore, by Lemma 4.5.5, the integrand is bounded by fˆ(R)||A||. We next estimate ||(ψ − ϕ)|I−|| by the same argument but this time using Fn+1 = H + E(R(n+1)), so that, again F − Fn+1 is anchored at distance R/2 from the relevant region I−. We have thus obtained ||(ψ − ϕ)I± || ≤ fˆ(R) By a simple Lemma A.1.1 in Appendix A.1, these two bounds together imply that ||(ψ − ϕ)In|| ≤ 12√fˆ(R) which ends the proof. Lemma 4.7.6. Let ψ = ϕ ◦ α−Z1(1). Then ||(ψ − ϕ)|Jn|| ≤ fˆ(R). Proof. Recalling that αZ˜ = α−F1 ◦ αH, we have ψ = ϕ ◦ α−H1(1) ◦ αF (1) ◦ αZ˜(1) ◦ α−Z1(1) = ϕ ◦ αF (1) ◦ αZ˜(1) ◦ α−Z1(1), where the last equality follows because H generates a loop with basepoint ϕ. Now we estimate |ψ(A) − ϕ(A)| ≤ |ϕ ◦ αF (1)[A] − ϕ[A]| + ||A − αZ˜(1) ◦ α−Z1(1)[A]|| (4.7.5) for A ∈ AJn , and we deal with both terms separately. For the first term, we use that Jn is contained in the union In ∪ In+1. Employing Lemma 4.7.5 for the intervals In, In+1 and Lemma A.1.1, we can bound this term by ||A||fˆ(R). For the second term in (4.7.5), we note that αZ˜◦α−Z1 is generated by W = αZ[Z˜−Z], 4.5.2 to ||W||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R) and hence to the estimate see Lemma 4.5.3. The smallness of Z˜ − Z, see Lemma 4.7.4 leads via Lemma ||A − αW (1)[A]|| ≤ ∫ 1 ds||[W (s), A]|| ≤ fˆ(R)|Jn|||A|| 0 Since |Jn| grows linearly in R, it can be absorbed in fˆ(R). Therefore, (4.7.5) is bounded by fˆ(R)||A||, as required. Let us check that we achieved the result described at the beginning of Section 4.7.2. We write αH = αF ◦ α−F1 ◦ αH = αF ◦ αZ˜ ◦ α−Z1 ( ) ◦ αZ = αF ◦ αW ◦ αZ and the desired properties of F, Z, W are manifest from the results above. 4.7.3 Final stage of the proof of Proposition 4.7.1 Closing the product quasi-loops Up to now, we have defined the TDIs F, Z that are split on intervals of length R. They do not generate loops, but they fail to do so by an error which decays fast in R. We now show that, by modifying F, Z by a small term that is split as well, the quasi-loops are made into genuine loops. Lemma 4.7.7. There are TDIs E = E(R), L = L(R) such that i. |||E|||fˆ → 0 and |||L|||fˆ → 0, as R → ∞. ii. E is split over the intervals In and L is split over the intervals Jn. iii. ϕ ◦ αF ◦ αE and ϕ ◦ αL ◦ αZ are loops with basepoint ϕ. Proof. Both ϕ◦αF (1) and ϕ are factorized exactly over intervals In. We consider each interval separately and we note that we are exactly in the framework of Lemma 4.6.5. For each n, we obtain a time-dependent observable En(·) in AInthat generates parallel transport from (ϕ◦αF(1))In to ϕIn, with norm bounded by ||(ϕ ◦ αF (1) − ϕ)In || ≤ fˆ(R). We then assemble the different En(·) into a TDI: ES (s) = En(s) for S = In for some n and ES (s) = 0 otherwise. This TDI E satisfies ϕ ◦ αF (1) ◦ αE (1) = ϕ. To get a bound on E, note that for any h ∈ F , |||E|||h ≤ sup supsh||(ERn)(s)||. (4.7.6) n We choose h = √fˆ, and so we obtain |||E|||√fˆ √fˆ(R). This proves all ≤ claims concerning E. We now do the same for Z−1, but replacing now In by Jn and calling the resulting (split and small) interaction L−1. This achieves that ϕ = ϕ ◦ αZ−1(1) ◦ αL−1(1) and hence also ϕ = ϕ ◦ αL(1) ◦ αZ(1). Contracting product loops In the above sections, we have produced G-loops factorized over a collection of sets Yn. In our case Yn = In or Yn = Jn. We will now show that such a loop is contractible, i.e. homotopic to a constant loop. Lemma 4.7.8. Consider a G-loop ψ that is factorized over intervals Yn, with Yn forming a partition of Z. If diam(Yn) is bounded uniformly in n, then ψ is homotopic to a constant loop with the same basepoint. It is intuitively clear that this lemma relies on the fact that zero-dimensional systems don’t allow for nontrivial loops because B(H) is simply connected. However, our notion of loops and their homotopy for states on spin chain algebras, does not simply reduce, in the case the chain is finite, to the standard notion of continuous loops and homotopy on topological spaces. The reason is that we require the loops to be generated by a TDI, which, even for loops on B(H), is a stronger notion than continuity. Actually, the requirement of being generated by a zero-dimensional TDI E(·), as defined before Lemma 4.6.6, is in that case equivalent to absolute continuity of the loop. For this reason, we actually need an additional lemma on zero-dimensional loops. Lemma 4.7.9. Let s↦ → ν(s) be a loop of pure normal states on B(H), with H a finite-dimensional Hilbert space, and E(·) a zero-dimensional TDI with |||E||| = sups ||E(s)|| < ∞ such that ν(s) = ν(0) ◦ αE(s). Then, there is a two-dimensional family of pure normal states νλ(s) with λ, s ∈ [0, 1], and zero-dimensional TDIs Eλ(·), Fs(·) such that i. supλ |||Eλ||| ≤ 80|||E||| and sups |||Fs||| ≤ 208 ii. ν1(s) = νλ(0) = νλ(1) = ν(0) = ν(1) for all s, λ. iii. νλ(s) = ν(0) ◦ αEλ(s) iv. νλ(s) = ν(s) ◦ αFs(λ) v. If the loop ν(·) is G-invariant, then the family νλ(s) and the families Eλ(s), Fs(λ) can also be chosen G-invariant. As the proof of this lemma uses only standard expressions on parallel transport on Hilbert spaces, we postpone it to the appendix. Proof of Lemma 4.7.8. Let E be the TDI generating the factorized loop ψ, with basepoint ϕ. Then (ψ(s))Yn is a loop of pure, G-invariant states on AYn. Since AYn is isomorphic to B(HYn) through the map π−1, we can apply Lemma 4.7.9 for every n separately. We first obtain then the time-dependent operators Eλ,n(·) and Fs,n(·) in B(HYn ). We then assemble these time-dependent operators in two TDIs by setting Eλ,S = {π−1(En,λ) 0 Fs,S = {π−1(Fn,λ) 0 so that we get, for any h ∈ F , S = Yn otherwise S = Yn otherwise |||Eλ|||h ≤ sup n |h|E(|Yn,nλ||)|, |||Fs|||h ≤ sup h||(F|Yn,ns||)| n By the bounds of Lemma 4.7.9, and the assumption supn |Yn| < ∞, we get that these norms are finite. It is straightforward to check that ϕ ◦ Eλ(·) is a homotopy of loops connecting the original loop ϕ(·) to the constant loop with basepoint ϕ. CONTRACTIBILITY OF SHORT LOOPS WITH PRODUCT BASEPOINT 97 Proof of Proposition 4.7.1 We start from the identity αH = αF ◦ (αZ˜ ◦ α−Z1) ◦ αZ We now use Lemma 4.7.7 by bringing in the almost local evolutions E,L defined therein and bracketing terms judiciously: αH = (αF ◦ αE ) ◦ α−E1 ◦ αZ˜ ◦ α−Z1 ◦ α−L1 ( ) ◦ (αL ◦ αZ ). At this point, we see that the first and third bracketed evolutions generate loops with basepoint ϕ. Since αH also generates a loop with basepoint ϕ, we conclude that also the second bracketed term generates a loop with basepoint ϕ. By Lemma 4.5.9, the above almost local evolution is homotopic to the concatenation of 3 loops7. (αF ◦ αE ) □ α−E1 ◦ αZ˜ ◦ α−Z1 ◦ α−L1 ( ( ) ) □ (αL ◦ αZ ) The first and third loop are product loops, hence contractible by Lemma 4.7.8. It follows that the loop ϕ ◦ αH is homotopic to the loop ϕ ◦ α , where H˜ α H˜ = α−E1 ◦ αZ˜ ◦ α−Z1) ◦ α−L1. ( Just as all of E, Z˜, Z, L constructed above, the TDI H˜ depends on the parameter R and we write H˜(R). Since Z − Z˜ is small (Lemma 4.7.4) and E, L are small in the same sense, we get from Lemma 4.5.4 and Lemma 4.5.2, that also H˜ is small in this sense, e.g. ||H˜||fˆ ≤ fˆ(R). □ 4.8 Contractibility of short loopswith product basepoint In this section, we prove that short loops, i.e. where the TDI has small norm, with product basepoint, are G-homotopic to a constant loop. The more precise statement is below in Proposition 4.8.1. As before, we fix ϕ to be a G-state that is a product. 7Concatenation of loops is not an associative operation. However, Lemma 4.5.9 shows that (αH1 □αH2)□αH3 is homotopic to αH1 □(αH2 □αH3), since the composition ◦ is associative. Therefore we allow ourselves here to write simply . . . . . . . . .. □ □ Proposition 4.8.1. For any f ∈ F, there is an ϵ1(f), such that, if |||H|||f ≤ ϵ1(f) for a G-invariant TDI H that generates a loop ϕ ◦ αH, then this loop is G-homotopic to the trivial loop with basepoint ϕ, and the homotopy can be chosen to have constant basepoint. 4.8.1 Construction of a loop of ground states First we rescale the given G-loop ϕ ◦ αH to ψ(s) = {ϕ ◦ αH(2s) ϕ s ≤ 1/2, s > 1/2, (4.8.1) so that now ψ(1/2) = ϕ. The resulting loop ψ is G-homotopic to the original one by Lemma 4.5.9 item i). Next, we construct a specific G-invariant interaction F , tailored to the product state ϕ: F has only on-site terms Fi = 1 − Pi with Pi the orthognonal projection on the range of the state ϕ|i. It follows that for any finite S, ∑i∈S Fi has a simple eigenvalue 0, corresponding to the state ϕ|S, and it has no other spectrum below 1. We now define the G-invariant interaction ⎧ ⎨F i ∫02s du αH(2s){[H(u), F]} s ≤ 1/2, + Z(s) = ⎩(2s − 1)F + (2 − 2s)Z(1/2) s > 1/2. Note that we have obtained a loop of interactions, since Z(1) = Z(0) = F. We will contract this loop of interactions to a point (namely F) by setting Zλ(s) = Z(0) + (1 − λ)(Z(s) − Z(0)), λ ∈ [0, 1]. This two-parameter family of interactions has the property that it remains close to F , as we remark now. Lemma 4.8.1. If |||H |||f ≤ ϵ ≤ 1, then, for fˆ affiliated to f , i. ||Zλ(s) − F ||fˆ ≤ ϵ ii. There are G-invariant TDIs Xλ(·), Xs′(·) such that ∫ s ∫ λ Zλ(s) − Zλ(0) = duXλ(u), Zλ(s) − Z0(s) = dλ′Xs′(λ′) 0 0 iii. The TDIs from item ii) are uniformly bounded sup(|||Xλ|||fˆ + |||Xs′|||fˆ) ≤ ϵ s,λ CONTRACTIBILITY OF SHORT LOOPS WITH PRODUCT BASEPOINT Proof. Item i) follows directly from the definition of Z, using Lemma 4.5.2, and ||F||f = f(1). To satisfy items ii) and iii), we identify, ⎧ Xλ(s)= ⎨αH(2s)[H(2s),F] s≤1/2 s>1/2 , ⎩2F −2Z(1/2) Xs′(λ) = −(Z(s) − Z(0)) and we obtain the bounds similarly to item i). To continue, we recall the notion of a ground state in the infinite-volume setting of quantum lattice systems. Definition 4.8.2. A state ψ on a spin chain algebra A is a ground state associated to an interaction K iff. ψ(A∗[K, A]) ≥ 0, ∀A ∈ Aal We will need two particular properties of a ground state. The first one is its invariance under the dynamics generated by the constant TDI K(s) = K: ψ = ψ ◦ αK(s), s ∈ [0, 1] (4.8.2) It follows by using that [K, ·] is a derivation. Indeed, [K, A∗A] = A∗[K, A] − (A∗[K, A])∗ and hence ψ([K, A∗A]) = 0 for a ground state ψ, which implies (4.8.2). The other property is the following variational statement, see Theorem 6.5.52 in [13]. Lemma 4.8.3. Let X be a finite subset of Z and let K be an interaction. Consider the functional eX,K : P(A) → (recall that P(A) is the set of states) given by C eX,K(ψ′) = ∑ ψ′(KS) S:S∩X≠∅ Then, any ground state ψ satisfies eX,K (ψ) = min ψ′:ψ′|Xc =ψ|Xc eX,K (ψ′) This property makes explicit the fact that ground states minimize the energy locally. The relevant to our problem is that we have a loop of ground states of explicitly given interactions, namely Lemma 4.8.4. For all s ∈ [0,1], ψ(s) is a ground state of the interaction Z(s). Proof. Definition 4.8.2 makes it explicit that the property of being a ground state depends only on the derivation association to the interaction Z(s). For s ∈ [0,1/2], we have Z(s) ≡ αH(2s)[F] and therefore the fact that ψ(s)) is a ground state of Z(s) follows directly from ϕ being a ground state of F. For s > 1/2, we have Z(s) ≡ (2s − 1)F + (2 − 2s)αH(12)[F] and we use that ϕ ◦ αH(12) = ϕ. Therefore ϕ is a ground state of both F and αH(12)[F] and hence also of their convex combinations. 4.8.2 Construction of the homotopy via spectral flow Our main idea to prove Proposition 4.8.1 is to consider the 2-parameter family of states given by groundstates of the two-parameter family Zλ(s). To make such considerations less subtle, we first remark, in Proposition 4.8.2, that these groundstates are unique in the perturbative regime (small perturbations of product states). Results of that kind have been established in great generality in [66, 14, 39, 45]. However, the specific claim that we need does not seem to appear in the literature, mainly because we consider the infinite-volume setup. Therefore we provide a proof in Appendix A.3. Proposition 4.8.2. For any h ∈ F, there is a ϵ2(h) > 0 such that, if ||W||h ≤ ϵ2(h), then the interaction F + W has a unique ground state. If we choose ϵ1(f ) in Proposition 4.8.1 small enough, then, by Lemma 4.8.1, all of the interactions Zλ(s) satisfy the condition of the above proposition and hence they have a unique ground state, that we call ψλ(s). This two-dimensional family (s, λ)↦ → ψλ(s) is the homotopy that will realise Proposition 4.8.1. Indeed, for any λ, we have Zλ(0) = Zλ(1) = F , which has ϕ as the unique ground state, and hence ψλ(0) = ψλ(1) = ϕ. For λ = 0, the family ψλ(s) reduces to the loop ψ(·), as we had already remarked that this was a loop of ground states of Z(·). For λ = 1, we have that Z1(s) = F , and hence ψ1(·) = Idϕ. It remains to show that the family (s, λ)↦ → ψλ(s) is generated by a TDI in λ and s directions. Such TDI will be obtained from the so-called spectral flow [28, 8, 40]. Proposition 4.8.3 below is the precise result on spectral flow that we will use. Such results appear in the literature for a much wider class of interactions instead of only F , see e.g. [14, 39, 45]. Even though none of these references covers explicitly the case we need, no extra idea is needed for the proof of Proposition 4.8.3, and we comment on it in Appendix A.3. To avoid a clash of notation, we use z ∈ [0, 1] (instead of s, λ) as time-parameter in a TDI. CLASSIFICATION OF LOOPS WITH PRODUCT BASEPOINT Proposition 4.8.3. For any h ∈ F, there is 0< ϵ3(h) < 1 such that, for any pair of TDIs W and Y satisfying ∫ z |||W|||h ≤ ϵ3(h), |||Y |||h < ∞, W(z) − W(0) = dz′Y (z′), (4.8.3) 0 the following holds: There exists a TDI Ŷ satisfying |||Ŷ |||h′ ≤ |||Y |||h for h′ ∈ F depending only on h, such that, if the pure state ν is a ground state of F + W(0), then ν(z) = ν(0) ◦ αŶ (z), z ∈ [0, 1] (4.8.4) is a ground state of the interaction F + W (z). If Y is G-invariant, then also Ŷ can be chosen G-invariant. Based on this result we can finish in a straighforward way the Proof of Proposition 4.8.1. By choosing ϵ in Lemma 4.8.1 small enough, we can apply the spectral flow technique, i.e. Proposition 4.8.3, to get generating TDIs for the paths s↦ → ψλ(s), and λ↦ → ψλ(s). They are uniformly bounded in ||| · |||h′ by Proposition 4.8.3 and hence they provide the desired homotopy. By combining Proposition 4.8.1 with Proposition 4.7.1 we conclude Theorem 4.8.5. Let ϕ be a product G-state and let ψ(·) = ϕ ◦ αH(·) be a G-loop such that I(ϕ, H) = 0, i.e. its index is zero, then the loop is homotopic to the constant loop Idϕ, via a homotopy with constant basepoint. This theorem will be the main tool in the next Section 4.9. 4.9 Classification of loops with product basepoint We are now ready to state a full result for the case of loops with a fixed product basepoint. Throughout this section, we again let ϕ be a pure, G-invariant product state and we consider it fixed. 4.9.1 Well-definedness of the index Up to now, the index I(ϕ, H) was defined as a function of the TDI H and the basepoint ϕ. We prove now that for product basepoint, it actually depends only on the loop itself and not on the choice of TDI that generates it. Lemma 4.9.1. Let H1,H2 be G-invariant TDIs that generate loops with basepointϕ. If ϕ◦αH1(s)=ϕ◦αH2(s), s∈[0,1], i.e. if the loops are equal, then the relative charge of the pumped states ϕ◦αH1′(s), ϕ ◦ αH2′(s) is zero and hence I(ϕ, H1) = I(ϕ, H2). Proof. By the same estimate as in Lemma 4.6.3 combined with Lemma 4.6.2, we deduce that ϕ ◦ αH1′ (s) and ϕ ◦ αH2′ (s) are mutually normal for all s ∈ [0, 1]. Therefore, the states ξ(s) = ϕ ◦ αH1′(s) ◦ α−H12′(s) are normal to ϕ and the path s↦ → ξ(s) can be represented as a path of G-invariant, pure, normal states on B(H), with H the GNS Hilbert space associated to ϕ. Moreover, since s↦ → αH(s)[A] is continuous for any A ∈ A and TDI H, we get that s↦ → ξ(s) is continuous in weak ∗-topology. Hence, item ii) of Proposition 4.3.1 implies that the states ξ(s) have zero relative charge with respect to ϕ, and it follows then that also the mutually normal states ϕ◦αH1′(s) and ϕ◦αH2′(s) have zero relative charge. The claim of the lemma then follows by item i) of Proposition 4.3.1. In particular, this result means that we can now consistenly use the notation h(ψ) for a loop ψ, instead of the more tedious object I(ϕ, H). 4.9.2 Additivity of the index Lemma 4.9.2. Let the TDIs H1 and H2 generate G-loops ψ1, ψ2 with common product basepoint ϕ. Then h(ψ2 ψ1) = h(ψ2) + h(ψ1) □ Proof. The pumped state of the loop ψ2□ψ1 is ϕ◦αH1′(1)◦αH2′(1) (4.9.1) where, as before, Hj′ are the truncated TDI. We let H2′(r) denoted the TDI truncated between sites −r and −r + 1 instead of the sites 0 and 1. By Lemma 4.5.6, we can replace H2′ by H2′(r) , such that the resulting pumped state ψ′(r) = ϕ ◦ αH1′(1) ◦ αH2′(r)(1) has the same charge as the state (4.9.1), for any r. Let CH be a constant such that |||H1|||f, |||H2|||f ≤ CH for some f ∈ F. Let now K1, K2(r) by the parallel transport TDIs constructed in Lemma 4.6.6 satisfying ϕ ◦ αH1′ (1) = ϕ ◦ αK1 (1), ϕ ◦ αH2′ (1) = ϕ ◦ αK2 (1) (4.9.2) and the bounds ||K1||{0,1},fˆ ≤ 1, sup ||K2||{−r,−r+1},fˆ ≤ 1 r for fˆ affiliated to f and depending on CH. Then we calculate ψ′(r) = ϕ ◦ αK1(1) ◦ αH2′(r)(1) = ϕ ◦ αH2′(r)(1) ◦ αK1+E(r)(1) = ϕ ◦ αK2(r)(1) ◦ αK1+E(r)(1) (4.9.3) The first and third equality follow from (4.9.2), and the second equality follows by the commutation formula (4.5.4) with E(r) = α−H12′(r)(K1) − K1. Locality estimates based on the fact that H2′(r) is anchored in a region at distance r from the origin, yield ||E(r)||{0,1},fˆ → 0 as r → ∞ and therefore also ||ψ′(r) − ϕ ◦ αK2(r)(1) ◦ αK1(1)|| → 0 (4.9.4) As K1, K2(r) are anchored in a finite set, we have K1 = Ad(V1), K2(r) = Ad(V2(r)) and by the locality properties we deduce that ||[V1, γ(g)[V2(r)]|| → 0. We let the pure density matrix ρ(r) represent the (pure) pumped state ψ′(r) and we write. Then (4.9.4) reads in the GNS representation ||ρ(r) − Ad(W1∗W2∗(r))Π||1 → 0, W1 = π(V1∗), W2(r) = π(V2∗(r)) (4.9.5) with Π, as before, the pure density matrix corresponding to the state ϕ, and ||[W1,U(g)W2(r)U∗(g)|| → 0 (4.9.6) by the corresponding property for V1, V2(r) above. We now bound d(h(ψ2 □ ψ1), h(ψ2) + h(ψ1)) ≤ CS1 sg∈uGp∣∣Tr[ρ(r)U(g)] − ei(h1(g)+h2(g))∣∣∣, hj = h(ψj) (4.9.7) for any r ∈ N+, with CS1 = supθ∈S1 |ei|θθ−|1| . We use (4.9.5), (4.9.6) and the definitions of the separate charges U(g)Ad(W1∗)Π = eih1(g)Ad(W1∗)Π, U(g)Ad(W2∗(r))Π = eih1(g)Ad(W2∗(r))Π to argue that the right hand side of (4.9.7) vanishes as r → ∞, which concludes the proof. 4.9.3 Homotopy invariance Proposition 4.9.1. Let ψ0 and ψ1 be G-invariant loops with common basepoint ϕ. If ψ0 and ψ1 are G-homotopic, then h(ψ1) = h(ψ0). Proof. We consider a homotopy ψλ(s) relating ψ0 and ψ1, as defined in Section 4.3.2, with the families of TDIs Hλ and Fs, and we set C0 = sup(|||Hλ|||f + |||Fλ|||f ), s,λ with C0 finite by the condition (4.3.2). Moreover, for every λ, the TDI Hλ generates a loop. For later reference, let us also define the loop λ↦ → ν(λ) = ψλ(0) = ψλ(1). (4.9.8) where the last equality follows from the fact that ψλ(·) is a loop for every λ. Moreover, ν is a loop with basepoint ϕ because the loops ψ0 and ψ1 both have basepoint ϕ. We now take the set S = S(f, ϕ, C0) as defined in Section 4.6.3 and we take ϵ as furnished by Proposition 4.6.1. Note that ϵ depends on S. We set N = 1/(C0ϵ) and TN = {0, 1/N, . . . , 1}. For any t ∈ T2N \ {1}, we denote by tˆ its successor, i.e. ˆt = t + 21N . We consider functions x : T2N → TN2 that satisfy i. x(0) = (0, 0) ii. x(1) = (1, 1) iii. x(ˆt) − x(t) equals either (1/N, 0) or (0, 1/N ). and we call such functions admissible walks, By drawing a straight line between x(t) and x(tˆ), we obtain a piecewise linear path in the unit square, starting at the bottom-left corner (0, 0) and ending in the top-right corner (1, 1), and always moving either upwards or to the right, see Figure 4.7 and 4.9 for examples. To every admissible walk x, we associate a TDI Dx(·) as follows: for s ∈ (t, ˆt], we set Dx(s) = {2Hx1(t)((x2(t) + 2(s − t)) if x(tˆ) − x(t) = (0, 1 N ) 2Fx2(t)((x1(t) + 2(s − t)) if x(ˆt) − x(t) = ( N1 , 0) (4.9.9) This construction is illustrated in Figure 4.7. Every one of such TDIs Dx generates a loop with basepoint ϕ. This follows from the definition of homotopy given in Section 4.3.2, in particular from the fact that Hλ and Fs generate motion on the two-dimensional sheet of states (s, λ)↦ → ψλ(s). 1 s Fs3 H1 s3 s2 Fs2 Hλ3 x(·) s1 Fs1 Hλ2 Hλ1 F0 λ λ1 λ2 λ3 1 Figure 4.7: The TDI associated to the walk x is represented in the square [0,1]2. The upward steps are generated by H, the right-moving steps are generated by F. 1 s 1 Nλ 1 1 N Figure 4.8: Two walks that are adjacent. They delineate a small square with sides of length 1/N . We say that two distinct admissible walks x, y are adjacent if x(t) = y(t) for all, but one value of t ∈ T2N , that we call t∗. It follows that x, y are obtained from each other by flipping the steps between preceding and following the time t∗, i.e. and upwards step becomes right-moving, and vice versa, see Figure 4.8. We then note that for x, y adjacent admissible walks, we have |||Dx − Dy|||(f1) ≤ C0/(2N) By Proposition 4.6.1, and the choice of N made above, we have h(Dx) = h(Dy). Therefore, two admissible walks give rise to loops with the same index if those walks can be deformed into each other by switching a walk into an adjacent one. Consider then the two admissible walks x(t) = {(0, 2t) (2(t − 12 ), 1) y(t) = {(2t, 0) (1, 2(t − 12 )) t≤ 1 2 t > 12 t≤ 1 2 t > 12 These walks can be transformed into each other, as we illustrate in Figure 4.9. The walk xcorrespond to the loop ψ1 □ ν and the walk y corresponds to ν □ ψ0. These two loops have hence the same index and by using the additivity Lemma 4.9.2, we conclude that h(ν) + h(ψ0) = h(ψ1) + h(ν) x(·) y(·) Figure 4.9: Transformation of the walk x(·) into y(·) via a path of adjacent walks. which implies h(ψ0) = h(ψ1). 4.9.4 Homeomorphism property of h We have already established that h maps the concatenation of loops into the sum of charges. We would like to state that h is a homeomorphism, but as it stands, the concatenation of loops admits neither an identity nor an inverse. This can be remedied by using (G)-homotopy to define equivalence classes of loops. The following lemma shows that h acts as a homeomorphism from homotopy classes to H1. Let Idϕ be the constant loop with basepoint ϕ, i.e. ϕ(s) = ϕ, and recall the definition of the inverse ψθ(s) = ψ(1 − s) associated to a loop ψ. Lemma 4.9.3. Let ψ be a G-invariant loop with basepoint ϕ. Then i. h(Idϕ) = 0 ii. ψθ ψ is G-homotopic to Idϕ. □ iii. h(ψ) = −h(ψθ) Proof. Item i) follows because a possible TDI generating constant loops is H = 0, and for that TDI, the pumped state is equal to the basepoint. To show item ii), we consider the following homotopy: ζλ(s) = {ψψ(θ((1λ−+λ(1)2−s)λ)(2s − 1)) ss ≤> 11//22 (4.9.10) We note that ψ((1 − λ)2s) = ψθ(λ + (1 − λ)(2s − 1)), for s = 1/2 by the definition of ψθ, resolving the apparent incongruence between s ≤ 1/2 and s > 1/2 in the definition of ζλ(s). The homotopy property of (s, λ)↦ → ζλ(·) now follows because ψ, ψθ are loops and using Lemma 4.5.9 item i). We then remark that ζ0(·) = ψθ □ ψ, ζ1(·) = Idϕ □ Idϕ = Idϕ which settles item ii). Finally, by additivity and item i): h(ψθ) + h(ψ) = h(ψθ □ ψ) = h(Idϕ) = 0 which implies item iii). 4.9.5 Completeness of classification We now prove that our classification is complete. Lemma 4.9.4. If a pair of G-invariant loops ψ1(·) and ψ2(·) have equal index, then they are G-homotopic. Proof. Indeed, the loop ψ2θ ψ1 has index zero, by Lemma 4.9.3 and Lemma 4.9.2. By Theorem 4.8.5, this loop is G-homotopic to the constant loop Idϕ. Let □ ζλ(s) be this homotopy, satisfying also ζλ(0) = ζλ(1) = ϕ. We now construct two derived homotopies ν and ω by νλ(s) = {ζζλλ−(s()2s−1)λ(1/2) ωλ(s) = {ζζλλ(−1(2−s−s1))λ(1/2) s ≤ 1/2 s > 1/2 s ≤ 1/2 s > 1/2 (4.9.11) (4.9.12) The apparent incongruence at s = 1/2 is resolved by noting that ζλ(s) = ζλ−(2s−1)λ(1/2) for s = 1/2. The fact that s↦ → νλ(s) and λ↦ → νλ(s) are generated by uniformly bounded TDIs, follows from the fact that (s, λ)↦ → ζλ(s) is a homotopy and from Lemma 4.5.7. Then, by construction, ζ0(1/2) = ϕ and ζλ(0) = ϕ so that νλ(·) are loops with basepoint ϕ. This confirms that (s, λ)↦ → νλ(s) is indeed a homotopy. In an analogous way, one checks that (s, λ)↦ → ωλ(s) is a homotopy. In Figure 4.10, we illustrate how ν and ω are derived from ζ. We define also the path κ(z) = ζz(1/2) and note that this path is in fact a loop. Indeed, κ(1) = ϕ because the original homotopy ζ reduces for λ = 1 to Idϕ, and κ(0) = ζ0(1/2) = ϕ as already used above. We are now ready to analyze the homotopies ν and ω. For λ = 0, it reduces to Idϕ □ ψ1. φ s ψ2θ ωλ(·) κ Idφ φ ψ1 φ νλ(·) λ Figure 4.10: We square represents the homotopy (s, λ)↦ → ζλ(s). In this square we show the loops νλ(·) and ωλ(·) building the homotopies ν and ω. For λ = 1, it reduces to ˜κ □ Idϕ . (4.9.13) It is also represented in Figure 4.10. To verify that ω is a homotopy, we proceed analogously as for ν. The homotopy ω reduces for λ = 0 to the loop Idϕ □ ϕ2 and for λ = 1 to the loop (4.9.13). Hence, we conclude that Idϕ □ ϕ1 and Idϕ □ ϕ2 are homotopic to the same loop (4.9.13) and hence to each other. It follows that ϕ1 is homotopic to ϕ2. 4.10 Proof of main theorems In Section 4.9, we proved all results of this paper in the special case of loops with product basepoint. In the present section, we prove our results without this restriction by relying on the results in Section 4.9. Indeed, by the assumption of invertibility, we can reduce all our results to statements about loops with product basepoint. We use the terminology introduced at the beginning of Section 4.3.4. PROOF OF MAIN THEOREMS 4.10.1 Proof of Proposition 4.4.1 Let ψ ◦ αH(·) be loop. We let ψ be an inverse to the basepoint ψ, such that ϕ = ψ ⊗ ψ ◦ β−1 (4.10.1) where ϕ is a product state and β = αE(1) for some TDI E. As in the text preceding Proposition 4.4.1, we let ψ′ = ψ ◦ αH′(1) with H′ the truncated TDI. Let also ϕ′ = ψ′ ⊗ ψ ◦ β−1 (4.10.2) By the uniqueness of the GNS-representation, normality of ψ′ w.r.t. ψ is equivalent to normality of ψ′ ⊗ ψ w.r.t. ψ ⊗ ψ. By (4.10.1) and (4.10.2), it is therefore also equivalent to normality of ϕ′ w.r.t. ϕ. By equation (4.5.5), we have (here we write αH′ for αH′ ⊗ id) ϕ′ = ϕ ◦ β ◦ αH′(1) ◦ β−1 = ϕ ◦ αβ(H′)(1) Since ϕ ◦ αβ(H)(·) is a loop with product basepoint, the state ϕ ◦ αβ(H)′(1) is normal with respect to ϕ by Lemma 4.6.3. Moreover, by Lemma 4.5.6, and the fact that β(H)′ − β(H′) is a TDI anchored in a finite set, we get that ϕ ◦ αβ(H′)(1) is normal with respect to ϕ ◦ αβ(H)′(1). Since normality of pure states is a transitive relation, the claim is proven. 4.10.2 Loops whose basepoint is G-equivalent to a product As a first step in dealing with loops with non-product basepoint, we formulate a lemma for loops whose basepoint is G-equivalent to a product state. Lemma 4.10.1. Let ψ be a G-loop generated by the TDI H, such that, for some G-invariant TDI K and a product state ϕ, ϕ = ψ(0) ◦ α−K1(1). Then the loop ψ is homotopic to the loop ν = ϕ ◦ ((αK □ αH ) □ αθK ) (4.10.3) which has product basepoint ϕ. Moreoever, their indices are equal, i.e. I(ψ(0),H) = h(ν) (4.10.4) λ=1 0<λ<1 λ=0 • ψ(0) •φ •φ • • ψ(0) • ψ(0) •φ Figure 4.11: The homotopy µ moves the basepoint ψ(0) up to the product state ϕ. Proof. We note that the loop ν is such that the evolution αK is traversed between times s = 0 and s = 1/4, αH is traversed between s = 1/4 and s = 1/2, and αθK is traversed between s = 1/2 and s = 1. We define the homotopy, illustated in Figure 4.11, s ≤ 1/4 µλ(s) = ν(s) ⎧⎪⎨ν(λ/4 + (1 − λ)s) 1/4 < s < 1/2 ⎩⎪ν(1/2 + (s − 1/2)(1 − λ)) 1/2 ≤ s We note first that there is no incongruence at s = 1/4 and s = 1/2 since, for any λ, µλ(1/4) = ν(1/4) = ψ(0) = ψ(1) = ν(1/2) = µλ(1/2) From Lemma 4.5.7, we see that the family (s, λ)↦ → µλ(s) is generated by uniformly bounded TDIs in s and λ direction. To conclude that this family is homotopy, we check that it is a loop for all λ, using the definition of time-reversed loops; µλ(0) = ν(λ/4) = ψ(λ) = ψθ(1 − λ) = ν(1 − λ/2) = µλ(1). This homotopy connects the loop ν with the loop (Idψ(0) □ ψ) □ Idψ(0) and the latter is clearly homotopic to ψ, which settles the first claim of the lemma. Since we have not yet proven in general that homotopy preserves the index, we need another argument to get (4.10.4). The pumped state of the loop ν(·) is ϕ◦αK′(1)◦αH′(1)◦α(K′)θ(1) = ϕ◦αK′(1)◦αH′(1)◦α−K1′(1) = ϕ◦ααK′(1)[H′](1) where the first expression follows because (K′)θ = (Kθ)′ with Kθ the TDI generating αθK, i.e. Kθ(s) = −K(1 − s). Then, we observe that αK(1)[H′] − αK′(1)[H′] is a G-invariant TDI anchored in {0, 1}. That follows by Duhamel’s principle from the fact that [K − K′, H′] is anchored in {0, 1} and from Lemma 4.5.2. PROOF OF MAIN THEOREMS This implies then by Lemma 4.5.6 item ii) that the pumped state has zero relative charge w.r.t. the state ϕ ◦ αβ[H′](1) = ϕ ◦ β ◦ αH′(1) ◦ β−1 where we abbreviated β = αK(1). Hence to prove the claim of the lemma, we have to show that the relative charge of ϕ ◦ β ◦ αH′(1) ◦ β−1 w.r.t. equals the relative charge of ϕ ϕ ◦ β ◦ αH′(1) w.r.t. ϕ ◦ β since the latter are the pumped state and basepoint, respectively, of the loop ψ. This equality of relative charges follows then from item v) of Proposition 4.3.1, taking δ = β. 4.10.3 Tensor products Given two G-loops ψ1, ψ2 on spin chain algebra’s A1, A2, generated by TDIs H1, H2, we can consider the product loop ψ1 ⊗ ψ2 on the spin chain algebra A1 ⊗ A2, generated by the TDI H1 ⊗ Id + Id ⊗H2. The truncation of this TDI to the left equals the sum of truncated TDIs H1′ ⊗ Id + Id ⊗H2′ and it then follows that the pumped state is given by a tensor product of pumped states ψ1(0) ◦ αH1′(1) ⊗ ψ2(0) ◦ αH2′(1) From Proposition 4.3.1 item iii), it then follows that the index is additive, i.e. I(ψ1(0) ⊗ ψ2(0), H1 ⊗ Id +H2 ⊗ Id) = I(ψ1(0), H1) + I(ψ2(0), H2) We will establish in the next sections that the index depends only on the loop and not on the generating TDI, but we can already see that, if a loop is generated by the TDI H = 0, then its index is zero. This observation allows us to extend any G-loop ψ generated by H to a G-loop ψ ⊗ Idν, with ν a G-state, generated by H ⊗ Id, such that the index does not change, i.e. I(ψ(0) ⊗ ν, H1 ⊗ Id) = I(ψ(0), H) (4.10.5) Such operations will be used repeatedly in what follows. 4.10.4 The associated loop The main tool that we will use in the remaining proofs is that every G-loop can be related to a loop with product basepoint, such that they have the same index. We consider hence a general G-loop ψ and we let ψ(0) be a G-inverse to ψ(0). By the discussion in Section 4.10.3, the loop ψ ⊗ Idψ(0) has the same index as ψ. However, the former loop has a basepoint that is G-equivalent to a product state and hence we can invoke Lemma 4.10.1 to construct a loop ψA, which we call the associated loop, that has a product basepoint, and it is such that Lemma 4.10.2. Let ψ be a G-loop generated by the TDI H. There is a G-loop ψA with product basepoint such that h(ψA) = I(ψ(0),H). We will use the associated loops frequently in the analysis below. 4.10.5 Proof of Theorem 4.3.8 and 4.4.1 Well-definedness of the index Given a loop ψ generated by a TDI H, we have argued that we can define an associated loop ψA with the same index, in the sense of Lemma 4.10.2. If we have two TDIs H1, H2 that both generate the loop ψ, we see, by the definition of associated loops, that the associated loops can be chosen equal. Hence, by the results in Section 4.9.1, their index is equal and hence also I(ψ(0), H1) = I(ψ(0), H2). Therefore, also for loops with a non-product basepoint, the index I(·, ·) depends only on the loop itself. We can henceforth use the notation h(·). In particular, this means that Theorem 4.4.1 is proven once we establish all the properties of the index h(·) claimed in Theorem 4.3.8, which we do now. Proof of Theorem 4.3.8 We now check the items of Theorem 4.3.8 one by one. Item i) If a loop is constant, we can choose the generating TDI H = 0. In that case the pumped state equals the basepoint and the index is manifestly equal to zero. Item ii) The examples described in Section 4.4.2 realize every h ∈ H1(G). PROOF OF MAIN THEOREMS Item iii) Let the G-loops ψ1, ψ2 be stably G-homotopic. From Section 4.10.3, we know that by adjoining constant loops with product basepoint, we can make these loops G-homotopic without changing their respective indices. Hence without loss of generality we assume henceforth that ψ1, ψ2 are G-homotopic. Consider an associated loop ψ1A with product basepoint ϕ, obtained by adjoining an inverse ψ1(0). Since ψ1(0) and ψ2(0) are G-equivalent, so are ψ1(0) ⊗ ψ1(0) and ψ2(0) ⊗ ψ1(0) and hence also ψ2 has an associated loop ψ2A with basepoint ϕ. Since for j = 1, 2 the loop ψj is stably G-homotopic to the loop ψjA, and the loops ψ1, ψ2 are G-homotopic to each other, also ψ1A, ψ2A are G-homotopic. Since they share a product basepoint, these loops have equal index, by the results in Section 4.9. By Lemma 4.10.2 it then follows that also ψ1, ψ2 have equal index. Item iv) For a pair ψ1, ψ2 of G-loops with common basepoint, we find a pair of associated loops ψA1, ψ2A with common basepoint ϕ. We note first that (ψ2 □ ψ1)A is homotopic to ψ2A □ ψ1A which follows from Lemma 4.9.3 item ii. Since these are loops with product basepoint, the homotopy implies that they have the same index. The claim then follows from Lemma 4.10.2 and the additivity of the index for loops with product basepoint. Item v) This was already proven in Section 4.10.3. Item vi) If the G-loops ψ1, ψ2 have stably G-equivalent basepoints, then by adjoining a product state, the basepoints are G-equivalent. Without loss of generality, we assume hence that the basepoints of ψ1, ψ2 are G-equivalent. Let ψ1(0) be a G-inverse to ψ1(0), then we consider the loops ψj ⊗ Idψ1(0) ⊗ Idψ1(0), j = 1, 2 (4.10.6) and we argue that they are G-homotopic, which will yield the required stable G-homotopy of the original loops, since the adjoined product of constant loops is homotopic to a constant loop with product basepoint. To show that (4.10.6) are G-homotopic, we actually prove that ψj ⊗ Idψ1(0) are G-homotopic. These respective loops are homotopic to the assocated loops ψjA, which can be chosen to have the same product basepoint, by the same reasoning as in item iv). From h(ψ1) = h(ψ2), we deduce that h(ψ1A) = h(ψA2) and hence ψA1, ψA2 are G-homotopic by Lemma 4.9.4. Chapter 5 SPT indices emerging from translation invariance in two-dimensional quantum spin systems 5.1 Introduction In 2010, Chen, Gu and Wen [18] introduced the notion of symmetry-protected topological phases of matter (SPT). They first considered one dimensional matrix product states and later on, Chen, Liu and Wen [19], extended this to two dimensional projective entangled pair models. Afterwards, in [16] this was extended to other dimensions. This last reference used a setup involving so-called lattice nonlinear sigma models and provided an Hd+1(G, U (1)) valued index for any d-dimensional lattice nonlinear sigma model. Another possible setup in which one can define SPT phases is in quantum spin systems (defined in section 5.2.1). In order to define SPT phases in this setting, one needs to fix a finite group G with an on-site group action g↦ → Ug (with g ∈ G), defining a global group action βg (also defined in section 5.2.1). A state ω, is then called G-invariant, if ω ◦ βg = ω. Afterwards, one needs to impose a restriction on the 115 116 SPT INDICES EMERGING FROM TRANSLATION INVARIANCE IN TWO-DIMENSIONAL QUANTUM SPIN SYSTEMSspace of states. We1 ask that our states are short range entangled (SRE), see definition 5.2.2. A state ω is short range entangled if there is a disentangler γ. This is a locally generated automorphism, produced by a one parameter family of interactions Φ ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) (γ = γ0Φ;1 as defined in section 5.2.3) satisfying that ω ◦ γ is a product state. Combining these two definitions, we say that ω is an SPT state if it is short range entangled and G-invariant. One then defines an equivalence relation on these SPT states by saying that ω1 is equivalent to ω2 with respect to the on site group action U if there exists a G-invariant one parameter family of interactions Φ ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) such that ω1 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = ω2 (again, see section 5.2.3 for the definitions). One can then extend this equivalence to the stronger notion of being stably equivalent. This goes as follows: one defines an operation called stacking that takes two SPT states ω1 and ω2 and outputs a third one ω1 ⊗stack ω2 (and similarly for the group action). This ⊗stack is defined in section 5.2.1. In short, it is the tensor product at the level of the on site Hilbert space. One then defines another equivalence (ω2, U2) are stably equivalent if and only if there exist trivial2 SPTs with their relation andsays that two SPT states with on site group actions (ω1, U1) and group actions, (ϕ1, Ũ1) and (ϕ2, Ũ2) and a (G independent) unitary V mapping between the respective on site Hilbert spaces3, such that i. V †U1,g ⊗ Ũ1,gV = U2,g ⊗ Ũ2,g for all g ∈ G. ii. ω1 ⊗stack ϕ1 ◦ iV (where iV is again defined in section 5.2.1) is equivalent to ω2 ⊗stack ϕ2 with respect to the above on site group action. In one spatial dimension so called matrix product states ([19],[50],[54]) can be used to construct non-trivial SPT states. Later on and more generally it was shown in [47] that any G-invariant state satisfying the split property (this includes any SRE state) carries an H2(G, T)-valued4 index and that this index is constant on the (stable) equivalence classes. Later on in [33] it was then shown that this classification problem is complete (the index, seen as a map from the set of stable equivalence classes to H2(G,T) is injective.). In two spatial dimensions, more recently in [48], it was proven there is an H3(G,T)-valued1There are other definitions possible like for instance the concept of invertible G-invariant states used in [33] or the unique gapped ground state of a G invariant interaction presented in the introduction of [48]. 2A trivial state is a G-invariant product state that transforms trivially under the on site group action (see remark 5.5.11). 3The reader can think of this V as being a unitary transformation of the on site group action. 4By Hn(G, T) we mean the n-th (Borel) group cohomology of G with coefficients in the torus T (seen as a (group) module under addition with trivial group action). Group cohomology is defined in section 5.2.5. INTRODUCTION index that is constant on the (stable) equivalence classes5. We’ve used stacking to define the stable equivalence relation. Stacking however plays a more general role. It widely believed that it allows us to define an (abelian) group structure on the set of stable equivalence classes6. Although it is nowhere stated explicitly, the author thinks that the literature (like for example [33]) suggests the following conjecture: Conjecture 5.1.1. Let S be the set of stable SPT classes for some fixed group and a fixed lattice. Let ∗ be the map ∗ : S2 → S : (⟨ω1, U1⟩∼, ⟨ω2, U2⟩∼)↦ → ⟨ω1 ⊗stack ω2, U1 ⊗ U2⟩∼. (5.1.1) Then ∗ is well defined (independent of the choice of representative) and S together with the ∗ operation forms an abelian group. Before proceeding, we make three remarks on this conjecture: i. The claim that ∗ is well defined and abelian is trivial. Namely, by letting iV be the automorphism that exchanges the two algebras that are being stacked, one can exchange the order of the stacking freely. By using ω1 ◦ γ0Φ;11 ⊗stack ω2 ◦ γ0Φ;21 = (ω1 ⊗stack ω2) ◦ γ0Φ;11⊗1+1⊗Φ2 ∼ ω1 ⊗stack ω2, (5.1.2) one can show that this is a well-defined map. ii. A representative of the inverse is sometimes called a G-inverse. iii. From a category point of view, if one assumes that this conjecture is true (for some subclass of groups that is a category), it is not hard to see that it gives rise to a contravariant functor from this category of groups to the category of abelian groups (say S[G]). More specifically, f˜ : S[G2] → S[G1] : ⟨ω, U⟩∼ →↦ ⟨ω, U ◦ f⟩∼ and this f˜ is indeed invariantto each group morphism f : G1 → G2, one can find a group morphismon the choice of representative (if two states can be connected while preserving the symmetry action β, they can certainly be connected while preserving the symmetry β ◦ f). In what follows, we will call S with the above group structure the stable SPT classification.
