In this paper we consider the 2D case with the (stable) equivalence 5In [48], there is no mention of the stacking operation but using remark 5.4.28 and remark 5.4.30, one can clearly extend it to the stable equivalence class. 6The stacking with a trivial state will then be related to the identity of this group SPIN SYSTEMS relation as presented here but with one notable difference. We will only consider states, interactions and on site symmetries that have a translation symmetry in one direction. There is a conjecture about the SPT classification of such states, see section 3.1.5.1 of [65] for a more general and detailed exposition (which was partially based on [16]). Conjecture 5.1.2. The set of translation invariant SPTs under stable equivalence7 also satisfies conjecture 5.1.1. Let g be the inclusion map from the space of 2d translation invariant SPT states to the more general set of 2d SPT states. Let f be the map that takes a 1d SPT state and outputs a translation invariant 2d SPT state by taking the tensor product in the direction of the translation symmetry. The sequence 0 → {1d SPT states} →f {2d translation invariant SPT states} →g {2d SPT states} → 0 (5.1.3) induces a sequence (of group morphisms) on the stable equivalence classes. By this we mean that the class of f (ϕ) only depends on the class of ϕ and similarly for g. Moreover this induced sequence is exact and split. Clearly this implies that {2d translation invariant SPT classification} ≃ {1d SPT classification} ⊕ {2d SPT classification}. (5.1.4) Since a 1d SPT state carries an H2(G, T) valued index and a 2d SPT state carries an H3(G,T) valued index, this means that 2d SPT states with a translation symmetry should carry an H2(G,T)⊕H3(G,T) valued index. This is consistent with the result of section XII of [16]. The first result of this paper is the construction of an H2(G,T) valued index (which we will denote by Index) on the space of translation invariant SPT states that is consistent with conjectures 5.1.1 and 5.1.2. By being consistent with the conjecture it is meant (among other things) that, if Index1 is the one dimensional SPT index from [47], then Index(f(ω)) = Index1(ω) for any 1d SPT ω. This construction highly relies on the objects that are present in the construction of the 2d SPT index in [48]. We also look at the case where there is a second translation symmetry (so the system is translation invariant in both x and y directions). For such systems there is the following conjecture conjecture (see again [65] and [16]): 7In the stable equivalence relation for translation invariant states we ask that the on site symmetry is translation invariant and that any path connecting two states and each trivial state is not only G-invariant but also translation invariant. INTRODUCTION Conjecture 5.1.3. The space of SPTs, translation invariant in two directions under stable equivalence also satisfies conjecture 5.1.1. Let g be the inclusion map from the space of 2d SPT states that are translation invariant in both x and y directions to the more general set of 2d SPT states with translation invariance in the x direction only. Let f be the map that takes a 1d translation invariant SPT state and outputs a 2d SPT state that is translation invariant in both x and y directions by taking the tensor product in the y direction. The sequence 0→ {1d translation invariant} {2d SPT states with two} {2d SPT states translation} SPT states →f translation symmetries →g invariant in x direction → 0 (5.1.5) induces a sequence (of group morphisms) on the stable equivalence classes. By this we mean that the class of f (ϕ) only depends on the class of ϕ and similarly for g. Moreover, this induced sequence is exact and split. Translation invariant SPT states in one spatial dimension are known to carry an H2(G, T) ⊕ H1(G, T) valued index (see appendix B.8). From this and the last two conjectures, we expect there is an H3(G, T) ⊕ H2(G, T) ⊕ H2(G, T) ⊕ H1(G, T) (5.1.6) valued index. The first part of the index is just Index2d. The following two parts can be related to the case of a single translation symmetry as follows. Let µ be the automorphism that rotates the lattice by 90° and let Index(ω) be the index as constructed before (this is the second part of 5.1.6). The third part of the index is now given by Index(ω ◦ µ) (the state rotated by 90°). The last part of the index requires a different construction altogether. It can be thought of as being the charge in the Brillouin zone. A final remark: Remark 5.1.4. As noticed in [16]. The groups in which these indices take values can be concisely written out. Using that H0(Z,T) =∼ T H1(Z,T) =∼ T H2(Z,T) =∼ 0 H3(Z,T) =∼ 0 (5.1.7) and inserting this into the Künneth formula for × G gives Z H2(Z × G, T) =∼ ⊕ Hi(Z, T) ⊗ H2−i(G, T) =∼ H2(G, T) ⊕ H1(G, T) (5.1.8) 2 i=0 H3(Z × G, T) =∼ ⊕ Hi(Z, T) ⊗ H3−i(G, T) =∼ H3(G, T) ⊕ H2(G, T). (5.1.9) 3 i=0 This result can in turn be used to work out the Künneth formula for Z2 × G H 3 (Z2 × G, T) =∼ ⊕ H i (Z, T) ⊗ H 3−i (Z × G, T) =∼ H 3 (G, T) ⊕ H 2 (G, T) ⊕ H 2 (G, T) ⊕ H 1 (G, T). 3 i=0 (5.1.10) The layout of this paper is as follows: First in section 5.2 we explain the setup, define the concept of locally generated automorphisms and give the algebraic definition of group cohomology. In section 5.3.2 we state the two results for SRE states. In section 5.3.1, we state the first result using the weaker assumption 5.3.2 and the second result using the weaker assumption 5.3.5. It is using these weaker assumptions that we then prove the statements. Section 5.4 provides a proof of the first statement whereas section 5.5 provides a proof of the second statement. The results in this paper rely heavily on the methods that where developed in [48]. Acknowledgements T.J. was supported in part by the FWO under grant G098919N. We are grateful to the referees of Communications in Mathematical Physics for their constructive input during the review process. For example, we are very grateful for the proposed changes of lemma B.1.3, the mistake they found in subsection 5.4.4 (the previous assumption was too weak) and the mistakes they found in sections 5.4.5 and 5.5.4. SETUP AND DEFINITIONS 5.2 Setup and definitions In this paper we work in the two dimensional lattice some specific subsets of Z2, so let Z2. We will first need L := {(x,y) ∈ Z2|x < 0}, R := {(x,y) ∈ Z2|x ≥ 0} (5.2.1) U := {(x,y) ∈ Z2|y ≥ 0}, D := {(x,y) ∈ Z2|y < 0} (5.2.2) be the left, right, upper and lower half planes respectively and let Cθ := { (x,y) ∈ Z2∣∣tan(θ) ≤ ∣∣∣xy∣} ∣ (5.2.3) be the horizontal cone (the green area in figure 5.1). We will use τ to denote the bijection that moves every element of Z2 one site upward. Similarly we let ν denote the bijection that translates every element of Z2 by one site to the right. In what follows we will sometimes need to widen our cone or other subsets of Z2 vertically by one site. For this purpose we define W such that for any Γ ⊂ Z2, W (Γ) := Γ ∪ τ (Γ) ∪ τ −1(Γ). (5.2.4) For example, the red area in figure 5.1 is W(Cθ)c. In the later part we will also need to rotate our lattice by 90◦ (clockwise) so call µ the bijection on Z2 that does precisely this.8 Finally we will need to define the horizontal lines and the finite horizontal line Lj := {(i, j)|i ∈ Z} Lnj := {(i, j)|i ∈ Z ∩ [−n, n]}. (5.2.5) 5.2.1 Quasi local C∗-algebra The setup in this paper will be very similar to the setup in [48] and is just the standard setup for defining quantum spin systems. For the rest of this paper, take d ∈ N+ arbitrary. This number will be called the on site dimension9. For each z ∈ Z2, let A{z} be an isomorphic copy of B(Cd) (the bounded oFApoloercraa=ntoy⋃rsΛΛo∈∈nG CG2dAZ)2.Λ, IwannedwsehdtaetfiAnfΛoell=tohwe⊗sq,zul∈eatΛsiGAloZ{cz2}ab.leCWt∗heaedlgseeefitbnroeaf tafihsnetithleoecsanulobrasmlegtescbloorfasuZar2es. of the local aZlgebra (A = Aloc). Similarly, for any (possibly infinite) subset 8We will not discuss rotation invariant states in this paper. The µ is only defined to make certain constructions work. 9In principle in the case were there is only one translation we can let d be x-dependent but for simplicity let us take d constant over the lattice. Γ ⊂ Z2 we set Aloc,Γ = ⋃Λ∈GΓ AΛ and AΓ = Aloc,Γ . Throughout this paper we will sometimes require a stronger form of locality than merely being in the norm completion of the local algebra. Specifically when Γ = Lj is a horizontal line. We will say that an operator A ∈ ALj is summable if and only if there exists a sequence An ∈ ALnj on the finite horizontal lines such that ∑ ∞ ∥A − An∥ < ∞. (5.2.6) i=0 We will need to define some automorphisms on this algebra using the bijections defined previously. To this end, define the isomorphisms τ : AΓ → Aτ (Γ) ν : AΓ → Aν(Γ) µ : AΓ → Aµ(Γ) (5.2.7) as the translation upwards, the translation to the right and the right-handed rotation respectively. By construction, these isomorphisms are automorphisms if Γ is taken to be Z2 (because d is a constant throughout the lattice). Clearly if Γ = (by which we mean again the x-axis (Z,0)) only one of these translation automorphisms descends to an automorphism on AZ. This automorphism is Z then also simply denoted as ν. We will need to define one additional set of automorphisms. For any set of unitaries Vi ∈ U(Cd) (labelled by i ∈ Z2), we define the (unique) automorphism iVΓ ∈ Aut(AΓ) (for all Γ ⊂ Z2) such that iVΓ (A) = Ad(⊗i∈IVi)(A) (5.2.8) for all I ⊂ Γ finite and A ∈ AI . More specifically, let G be a finite group and let Ui ∈ hom(G,U(Ai)) (for i ∈ Z2) be the on site group action. Let βΓ ∈ hom(G,Aut(AΓ)) (for any Γ ⊂ Z2) be such that βgΓ(A) = iΓU(g) = Ad(⊗i∈IUi(g))(A) (5.2.9) for any g ∈ G, I ⊂ Γ finite and A ∈ AI. Clearly, any unitary transformation of our representation U(·) → V †U(·)V induces a transformation of the group action βg → i−V1 ◦ βg ◦ iV . Throughout our paper when we are discussing translation invariance in the vertical direction we will ask that the group action is translation invariant in the vertical direction (τ ◦ βgΓ = βgτ(Γ) ◦ τ). If we also have translation invariance in the horizontal direction, we will also ask that the group action be translation invariant in that direction as well (ν ◦ βgΓ = βgν(Γ) ◦ ν). As it turns out, in showing that the H1-valued index is consistent with all the conjectures of the introduction, we will even require that the on site group action Ui(g) is the same at each site. In what follows we will always assume this. This means that when we denote an on site symmetry action we merely have to give one representation U ∈ hom(G,U(Cd)) and when we denote a unitary transformation of the on site Hilbert space we only have to give a single unitary V ∈ U(Cd), we will use this notation frequently. Clearly by construction there is a tensor product operation on this C∗ algebra in the sense that for any Γ1, Γ2 ⊂ Z2 satisfying that Γ1 ∩ Γ2 = ∅ we can define a bilinear, surjective map ⊗ : AΓ1 × AΓ2 → AΓ1∪Γ2. (5.2.10) There is however a second tensor product operation on this C∗ algebra that we will use. We will call it the stacking operation. It is such that for any Γ ⊂ 2 we define the bilinear, surjective map Z ⊗stack : AΓ × AΓ → A2Γ (5.2.11) where A2 is the quasi local C∗ algebra on Z2 constructed from an on site algebra B(Cd) ⊗ B(Cd) ≃ B(Cd×d)10. We will also need to define the stacking of the group action by which we mean (βg ⊗stack βg)Λ = ⊗ Ad(U (g) ⊗ U (g)z) (5.2.12) z∈Λ for any Λ ∈ GZ2 (in fact stacking can be defined for any automorphism, not just the group action). 5.2.2 States on A We say that a linear functional ω : A → is a state if it positive and normalized. This means that for any A ∈ A, ω(A†A) ≥ 0 and that ω(1) = 1. We denote the C set of states on A by S(A). In this paper we will work exclusively with states that are pure. In this setting, ω ∈ S(A) being pure means that it is extremal in the sense that for any p ∈]0,1[, the only two other states ω1,ω2 ∈ S(A) that satisfy ω = pω1 + (1 − p)ω2 (5.2.13) 10Clearly this can also be used to stack two C∗-algebras with different on site Hilbert spaces, this was used in the introduction. In the rest of the paper we will for simplicity of notation (but without loss of generality) only stack two identical C∗-algebras on top of each other. must satisfy ω1 = ω2 = ω. The set of pure states on A will be called P(A). In this paper we will often refer to the GNS triple. For its definition, construction and properties we refer to [11]. We will sometimes write the tensor product of states ω ⊗ ϕ to be such that (ω ⊗ ϕ)(a ⊗ b) = ω(a)ϕ(b) and similarly for the stacking tensor product. We will call a pure state ϕ on AΓ a product state if for any Λ ⊂ Γ, the restriction ϕ|AΛ is still pure. We will call a state ω, G-invariant if ω ◦ βg = ω (where βg = iU(g) with U an on site group action). Moreover, let U we say that a G-invariant product state ϕ is trivial with respect to U (we will sometimes denote this as (ϕ,U) is trivial) if ϕ(Ui(g)) = 1 for all i ∈ Z2. There is a natural way to construct a pure G-invariant state on the quasi local C∗-algebra over Z2, AZ2 using a pure G-invariant state on the quasi local C∗-algebra over Z, AL011. Definition 5.2.1. Let ϕ ∈ P(AL0) be a state that is G-invariant under a group action βgL0. Define ϕi ∈ P(ALi) as ϕi := ϕ0 ◦ τ−i. We define the infinite tensor product state ωϕ as ωϕ := ⊗ ϕj. (5.2.14) j∈Z This is a G-invariant pure state over Z2 that is invariant under the automorphism τ . The proof that this is a well defined state is done in definition 5.4.17. 5.2.3 Interactions and locally generated automorphisms An interaction Φ is a map Φ : GZ2 → Aloc : I↦ → Φ(I) (5.2.15) where Φ(I) ∈ AI is hermitian (Φ(I) = Φ(I)∗). We will sometimes require a norm on the space of interactions that indicates how local an interaction acts. Take F : → R+ any monotonically decreasing positive function then we define N an F -norm on the space of interactions by: ∥Φ∥F := x,syu∈pZ2 F (|x − y|) Z∈G∑2,Z∋x,y ∥Φ(Z)∥. 1 (5.2.16) Z 11When applied to a trivial state on AL0 this will also give a trivial state on AZ 2 . Following [48] we will fix a specific family of monotonically decreasing positive functions by saying that for any 0 < ϕ < 1 we define Fϕ : R+ → R+ : r↦ → (1 + r)4 exp(−rϕ) . (5.2.17) We will sometimes use the restriction of an interaction. For some Γ ⊂ Z2 we define ΦΓ by ΦΓ : GZ2 → Aloc : I↦ → {Φ(I) oitfhIer⊂wise. Γ 0 (5.2.18) The set of interactions with this norm (for a fixed F ) is a Banach space. One of the properties of F -local interactions is that they can be used to generate automorphisms. Let Φ : GZ2 × [0, 1] → Aloc : (I , t)↦ → Φ(I , t) (5.2.19) be a norm continuous12 one parameter family of interactions such that the F - norm is uniformly bounded (supt∈[0,1] ∥Φ(·, t)∥F < ∞). We will denote the set of one parameter families of interactions that satisfy this property by BF ([0, 1]). For any Φ ∈ BFϕ([0, 1]), we define the locally generated automorphism (LGA) γsΦ;t such that for any A ∈ A, γsΦ;t(A) is given as the solution to the differential equation dtγsΦ;t(A) = −i ∑ γsΦ;t([Φ(I,t),A]) d (5.2.20) I∈G 2 Z with initial condition γsΦ;s(A) = A (the existence of this automorphism is proven in [44]). This satisfies the condition that if supt ∥∥∥∑I∈B 2 Φ(I, t)∥∥ < ∞ then ∥ Z γsΦ;t = Ad(uΦs;t) uΦs;t := T exp⎝−i ∫ s ds′ ∑ Φ(s′, t)⎠. ⎛ ⎞ (5.2.21) t I∈B 2 Z Sometimes we will say that an interaction is G-invariant. By this we simplyis translation invariant we mean that τ(Φ(I)) = Φ(τ(I)) (for all I ∈ GZ2). Itmean that βg(Φ(I)) = Φ(I) (for all I ∈ GZ2). Similarly if we say an interactionshould be clear that if an interaction is G-invariant (translation invariant) that then the LGA it generates commutes with the group action (the translation automorphism) as well. 12By which we mean that Φ(I,·) is norm continuous for each I ∈ G Z 2 . 5.2.4 The stable equivalence class We will now define a subset of these states that we will call short range entangled (SRE): Definition 5.2.2. Let ω ∈ P (A). We say that ω is an SRE state if and only if there exists a ϕ ∈]0, 1[ such that there exists an interaction Φ ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) such that ω ◦ γ0Φ;1 is a product state. We then call γ0Φ;1 a disentangler for ω. On the set of G-invariant SRE states we will now define three stable equivalence classes depending on the additional imposed symmetry: Definition 5.2.3. Take (ω1, U1) and (ω2, U2) elements of S0 = {(ω, U ) ∈ P(A) × hom(G, U (Cd))|ω is SRE, ω ◦ iU(g) = ω ∀g ∈ G} (5.2.22) for two algebras A1 and A213. We say that ⟨ω1, U1⟩∼ = ⟨ω2, U2⟩∼ if and only if there exists a ϕ ∈]0, 1[ such that there exists a G-invariant interaction Φ ∈ BFϕ([0, 1]), trivial elements of S0 (see subsection 5.2.2), (ϕ1, Ũ1) and (ϕ2, Ũ2) for algebras Ã1 and Ã2 respectively and an on site unitary such that ω1 ⊗stack ϕ1 ◦ iV = ω2 ⊗stack ϕ2 ◦ γ0Φ;1 V †U1(g) ⊗ Ũ1(g)V = U2(g) ⊗ Ũ2(g). (5.2.23) We also define similar equivalence classes ⟨·⟩1∼, ⟨·⟩2∼ and ⟨·⟩3∼ on S1 = { (ω, U ) ∈ P(A) × hom(G, U (Cd))∣ω is SRE, ω ◦ iU(g) = ω ∀g ∈ G,} ω ◦ τ = ω (5.2.24) S2 = (ω, U ) ∈ P(A) × hom(G, U (Cd)) is SRE, ωω◦◦iνU(g) = ω ∀g ∈ G, } { ω ∣ = ω (5.2.25) S3 = { (ω, U ) ∈ P(A) × hom(G, U (Cd))∣ω is SωRE◦,τ ω ◦ωiU,(ωg)◦=ν ω ∀g ∈ G, } = = ω (5.2.26) respectively. Here we now also demand that the interactions and the trivial states are invariant under the additional translation symmetries. 13With two different algebras we simply mean two different on site dimensions because we already fixed each on site dimension to be identical. 5.2.5 (Borel) Group cohomology groups In this paper we define the Group cohomology groups using the algebraic approach. A standard reference for Group cohomology is [9]. Let G be an arbitrary finite group. For any n ∈ N, let Cn(G,M) (in principle this can be for any (left) G-module M but in this paper we will always take M = with the addition and the trivial group action14) be the group of all functions from T Gn to M . We will use additive notation on this space and denote the group operator by + and the inverse of an element of the group ϕ by −ϕ. Now define the coboundary homomorphisms dn+1 : Cn(G,M)↦ → Cn+1(G,M) (5.2.27) such that (dn+1ϕ)(g1, · · · , gn+1 ) = g1ϕ(g2, · · · , gn+1) + ∑(−1)iϕ(g1, · · · , gi−1, gigi+1, · · · , gn+1 n ) + (−1)n+1ϕ(g1, · · · , gn). i=1 (5.2.28) Since dn+1 ◦ dn = 0 this defines a cochain complex and we can define its cohomology as Hn(G,M) = Zn(G,M)/Bn(G,M) (5.2.29) where { Zn(G,M) := ker(dn+1) Bn(G,M) := im(dn) if n ≥ 1. (5.2.30) 0 if = 0 n In what follows we will denote the group action on Hn(G,M) also in the same additive notation that we used for Cn(G,M). This notation makes sense because of the property that for any ϕ1, ϕ2 ∈ Zn(G, M) we have that ⟨ϕ1 + ϕ2⟩Hn(G,M) = ⟨ϕ1⟩Hn(G,M) + ⟨ϕ2⟩Hn(G,M) . Remark 5.2.4. In [16], they argue that this definition of group cohomology is only the right approach for discrete groups. When we want to generalize this to any continuous group that has a well defined Haar measure we additionally have to impose that the cochains are measurable. Group cohomology with measurable cochains is sometimes called Borel Group cohomology. We believe that it should be possible to construct a Borel Group cohomology group element from SPT states protected by any locally compact Lie group. However this is beyond the scope of this paper. 14So in particular when we write g1ϕ(g2, · · · , gn) for any ϕ ∈ Cn−1(G, M) we will sometimes identify it simply with ϕ(g2, · · · , gn). Θ αL αR ηgL θ ηgR Figure 5.1: These figures indicate the support area of the different automorphisms in a particular decomposition of the QAut. The angle θ needs to be smaller then or equal to what was indicated here so that the Θ and the ηg (possibly after widening by one site) commute. 5.3 Results This section will contain three different parts. First we discuss the main result starting from some rather abstract assumptions. In the second part we present the claim that these assumptions are implied by some more natural assumptions relating to short range entanglement. In the last part of the section we compare our assumptions to those made in [48]. 5.3.1 Statement of the result in terms of Q-automorphisms Similarly what was done in [48], we will define an index on the space of states that can be disentangled by a Q-automorphism. This class of automorphisms is defined as: Definition 5.3.1. Take α ∈ Aut(A). We say that α ∈ QAut1(A) if and only if ∀θ ∈]0,π/2[ there exists an αL ∈ Aut(AL),αR ∈ Aut(AR),V1 ∈ U(A) and a Θ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c)15 such that α = Ad(V1) ◦ αL ⊗ αR ◦ Θ. (5.3.1) 15Note that our definition of QAut1(A) is slightly different from the definition of QAut(A) from [48] because of this widening W. RESULTS We will often write α0 to mean αL ⊗ αR. In this paper we will consider states that satisfy the following property (see figure 5.1 for the support of the automorphisms): Assumption 5.3.2. Let ω ∈ P(A) be i. such that there exists an automorphism α ∈ QAut1(A) and a product state ω0 ∈ P(A) satisfying ω = ω0 ◦ α. (5.3.2) ii. such that there exists a θ ∈]0, π/2[ for which there exists a map satisfying ω ◦ β˜g = ω β˜ : G → Aut(A) : g↦ → β˜g β˜g = Ad(Vg,2) ◦ ηLg ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU (5.3.3) (5.3.4) for some Vg,2 ∈ U(A), ηgL ∈ Aut(ACθ∩L) and ηRg ∈ Aut(ACθ∩R). iii. translation invariant (ω ◦ τ = ω). We will also require a similar subclass of automorphisms and states on the quasi local C∗-algebra over Z, AL0. We now define the assumption Assumption 5.3.3. Take ϕ ∈ P(AL0) such that i. ϕ ◦ βg = ϕ. ii. there exist automorphisms α˜L ∈ Aut(AL0∩L), α˜R ∈ Aut(AL0∩R) and a summable operator b ∈ U(AL0) such that ϕ0 = ϕ ◦ Ad(b) ◦ α˜L ⊗ α˜R (5.3.5) is a product state. We now state the result that using assumption 5.3.2 we can define an H2(G,T)- valued index. Theorem 5.3.4. For any A satisfying the construction from section 5.2.1 and any choice of on site group action U ∈ hom(G,U(Cd)), there exists a map IndexA,U : {ω ∈ P(A)|ω satisfies assumption 5.3.2} → H2(G,T) (5.3.6) that is well defined (doesn’t depend on any of the choices in assumption 5.3.2). This map will be consistent with conjecture 5.1.2 by which we mean that: Θ ηgL θ ηgR (-1,-•1) Figure 5.2: This figure indicates the support area of the different automorphisms when there are two translation directions. The angle θ still has to be smaller then or equal to what was indicated here so that the Θ and the ηg commute but now we must be able to do both a horizontal and a vertical widening of the support of ηg. Also the coordinate (−1, −1) which will be of particular interest is indicated. i. For any G invariant and translation invariant family of interactions Φ ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) (for some 0 <ϕ < 1) we have that IndexA,U (ω) = IndexA,U (ω ◦ γ0Φ;1). (5.3.7) ii. For ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ), any a one dimensional G-invariant state satisfying assumption 5.3.3, the state ωϕ as defined in definition 5.2.1 satisfies IndexA1dL0,U(ϕ) = IndexA,U(ω). (5.3.8) iii. This index is a group homomorphism under the stacking operator. By this we mean that IndexA2,U⊗U(ω1 ⊗stack ω2) = IndexA,U(ω1) + IndexA,U(ω2). (5.3.9) iv. The index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space by which we mean that for any on site unitary V we get that IndexA,Ad(V †)(U)(ω ◦ iV ) = IndexA,U (ω). (5.3.10) Proof. This statement is proven in subsection 5.4.8. Now we will present the assumption from which we can define the H1(G, T)- valued index (see figure 5.2 for the support of the automorphisms). Assumption 5.3.5. Let ω ∈ P(A) be i. such that there exists an automorphism α ∈ QAut1(A) and a product state ω0 ∈ P(A) satisfying ω = ω0 ◦ α. (5.3.11) ii. such that there exists a θ ∈]0, π/2[ for which there exists a map β˜ : G → Aut(A) : g↦ → β˜g (5.3.12) satisfying ω ◦ β˜g = ω β˜g = Ad(Vg,2) ◦ ηLg ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU (5.3.13) for some Vg,2 ∈ U(A), ηgL ∈ Aut(Aν−1 (Cθ∩L) ) and ηgR ∈ Aut(Aν(Cθ∩R) ) . iii. translation invariant in both directions ω ◦τ = ω ω ◦ ν = ω. (5.3.14) Similar to before, we also require an assumption for states on the quasi local C∗-algebra over Z. Assumption 5.3.6. Take ϕ ∈ P(AL0) such that i. ϕ ◦ βg = ϕ. ii. there exist automorphisms α˜L ∈ Aut(AL0∩L), α˜R ∈ Aut(AL0∩R) and a summable (see subsection 5.2.1 for the definition) operator b ∈ U(AL0 ) such that ϕ0 = ϕ ◦ Ad(b) ◦ α˜L ⊗ α˜R (5.3.15) is a product state. iii. ϕ ◦ ν = ϕ. This is almost completely identical to assumption 5.3.3, the only difference is the added translation symmetry. We are now ready to state the second main result: Theorem 5.3.7. For any A satisfying the construction from section 5.2.1 and any choice of on site group action U ∈ hom(G,U(Cd)), there exists a map IndexA2,tUrans : {ω ∈ P(A)|ω satisfies assumption 5.3.5} → H1(G,T) (5.3.16) that is well defined (doesn’t depend on any of the choices made in assumption 5.3.5). This map will be consistent with conjecture 5.1.3 by which we mean the following: i. For any G invariant family of interactions that is translation invariant in both directions Φ ∈ BFϕ([0,1]) we have that IndexA2,tUrans(ω) = IndexA2,tUrans(ω ◦ γ0Φ;1). (5.3.17) ii. For ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ), any a one dimensional G-invariant and translation invariant state satisfying assumption 5.3.3, the state ωϕ as defined in 5.2.1 satisfies IndexA1dLt0r,aUns(ϕ) = IndexA2,tUrans(ωϕ). (5.3.18) iii. This index is a group homomorphism under the stacking operator by which we mean that IndexA22tr,Uan⊗sU (ω1 ⊗stack ω2) = IndexA2,tUrans(ω1) + IndexA2,tUrans(ω2). (5.3.19) iv. The index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space by which we mean that for any on site unitary V we get that IndexA2,tAradn(sV †)(U)(ω ◦ iV ) = IndexA2,tUrans (ω). (5.3.20) Proof. This statement is proven in subsection 5.5.8. 5.3.2 SRE implies previous assumptions The assumptions in the previous subsection are rather technical. In this section we show that these assumptions are strictly weaker than assumptions that are more natural. The assumptions on the states will now be that they are short range entangled (see definition 5.2.2). We will use the exact same definition (with the same F-function) for states over the quasi local C∗-algebra over Z, AL0. We are now ready to show that SRE implies the previous assumptions. Lemma 5.3.8. Take ω ∈ P (A) a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant then it satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. See subsection 5.4.9. Lemma 5.3.9. Any G-invariant SRE state ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ) satisfies assumption 5.3.3. Proof. See subsection 5.4.9. These two results imply that to any G-invariant translation invariant SRE state I can associate a consistent LGA invariant H 3(G, T) ⊕ H 2(G, T)-valued SPT index. The first index is the index when there are no translations and the last index is the one from theorem 5.3.4. Lemma 5.3.10. Let ω be a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant in two directions then it satisfies assumption 5.3.5. Proof. See subsection 5.5.9. Lemma 5.3.11. Any G-invariant, translation invariant SRE state ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ) satisfies assumption 5.3.6. Proof. Trivially follows from lemma 5.3.9. This shows that if a G-invariant SRE state is translation invariant in two directions I can find a consistent LGA invariant H3(G,T) ⊕ H2(G,T) ⊕ H2(G,T)⊕H1(G,T) valued SPT index. The first index is again the index when there are no translations, the second and third index are given by ω↦ → Index(ω) and ω↦ → Index(ω ◦ µ) (5.3.21) where µ was the rotation automorphism and Index was defined in theorem 5.3.4. Finally the H1(G,T)-valued index is defined in theorem 5.3.7. We now only have to show that there is no additional H1(G,T)-valued index: Lemma 5.3.12. Let µ be the automorphism that rotates every element of the C∗ algebra by 90◦ degrees then IndexA2,tUrans(ω) = IndexA2,tUrans(ω ◦ µ). (5.3.22) Proof. This is proven in subsection 5.5.5. Now all that is left to show is that the indices defined here are constant on the stable equivalence classes introduced in the introduction and later on clarified in subsection 5.2.4. To this end let ⟨·⟩∼, ⟨·⟩1∼, ⟨·⟩2∼ and ⟨·⟩3∼ be the stable equivalence classes without translation symmetry, with only the τ translation symmetry, with only the ν translation symmetry and with both the τ and ν translation symmetry respectively. We now show the following lemma: Lemma 5.3.13. Take (ω1, U1) and (ω2, U2) elements of S0 (see subsection 5.2.4) for algebras A1 and A2. The following three statements now hold true: i. If ⟨ω1, U1⟩∼ = ⟨ω2, U2⟩∼ then IndexAno1,tUra1ns(ω1) = IndexAno2,tUra2ns(ω2) (5.3.23) where Indexno trans is the SPT index introduced in [48] (see subsection 5.3.3 for why this is well defined in this context). ii. If additionally (ω1, U1), (ω2, U2) ∈ S1 and ⟨ω1, U1⟩1∼ = ⟨ω2, U2⟩1∼ then IndexA1,U1(ω1) = IndexA2,U2(ω2) (5.3.24) where Index is the index introduced in theorem 5.3.4. iii. If additionally (ω1, U1), (ω2, U2) ∈ S2 and ⟨ω1, U1⟩2∼ = ⟨ω2, U2⟩2∼ then IndexA1,U1(ω1 ◦ µ) = IndexA2,U2(ω2 ◦ µ) (5.3.25) where µ was the rotation automorphism. iv. If additionally (ω1, U1), (ω2, U2) ∈ S3 and ⟨ω1, U1⟩3∼ = ⟨ω2, U2⟩3∼ then IndexA21tr,Uan1s(ω1) = IndexA22tr,Uan2s(ω2) (5.3.26) where Index2 trans is the index introduced in theorem 5.3.7. Proof. This is shown in appendix B.6. 5.3.3 Comparison with [48] The first thing we would like to remark is that in [48], a different equivalence class on states is used. First of all the set of states considered is a priori different. Namely, for any state ψ ∈ P (A), we define two different conditions i. There exists a Φ ∈ PSL16 such that ψ is the unique gapped groundstate of Φ. ii. ψ is an SRE state. 16This is defined in [48] but it essentially means bounded interaction that is connected to a trivial (without overlapping terms) interaction. However in theorem 5.1 of [48] it is proven that the first item implies the second item. If one then looks at the definition of the index there, one could as well have started from the second condition. This is precisely what we did in this paper. As a side note, one should also be able to prove that the second item implies the first item by using theorem D.5 of [48] with Kt the disentangler and Φ a gapped interaction that has the product state as its groundstate. However, we won’t work this out explicitly in this paper. When we add the group, the story changes considerably. Let us define the two different equivalence classes. To this end, let ψ1 and ψ2 be two (pure) G-invariant states that are unique gapped groundstates of Φ0 and Φ1 ∈ PSL,β respectively. The following two conditions define different equivalence classes: i. There exists a G-invariant, bounded path of gapped interactions λ↦ → Φ˜(λ) (see [48] for precise definitions) such that ψ1 and ψ2 are unique gapped groundstates of Φ˜(0) and Φ˜(1) respectively. ii. There exists a G-invariant LGA, γ0Ψ;1 such that ψ1 ◦ γ0H;1 = ψ2. A priori those two conditions are not equivalent. However in [48] it is proven that, the first equivalence implies the second one. The proof that equivalent states have the same index only uses the second condition. This means that one could also have taken the second equivalence condition as the starting point. This is exactly what we do in this paper. One should also be able to show that the second condition implies the first one using a similar construction as in the above remark without the group and averaging the resulting interaction over the group (where one then has to use that a finite group has a normalised Haar measure). There where two things that are in theorems 5.3.4 and 5.3.7 but where not discussed in [48]. This is the part that the index is a group homomorphism under stacking and the part that the index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space. However, on inspection of the arguments used in subsections 5.4.6 and 5.4.7 one can conclude that these also hold for the H3-valued index. All in all we have provided a proof that the work done in [48] also implies the following theorem: Theorem 5.3.14. For any A satisfying the construction from section 5.2.1 and any choice of on site group action U ∈ hom(G,U(Cd)), there exists a map IndexAno,Utrans : {ω ∈ P(A)|ω is SRE and G-invariant} → H3(G,T) (5.3.27) that is well defined (doesn’t depend on the choice of disentangler). This map will satisfy: i. For any G invariant family of interactions Φ ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) we have that IndexAno,Utrans(ω) = IndexAno,Utrans(ω ◦ γ0Φ;1). (5.3.28) ii. This index is a group homomorphism under the stacking operator by which we mean that IndexAno2,tUra⊗nUs (ω1 ⊗stack ω2) = IndexAno,Utrans(ω1) + IndexAno,Utrans(ω2). (5.3.29) iii. The index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space by which we mean that for any on site unitary V we get that IndexAno,Atdra(nVs†)(U)(ω ◦ iV ) = IndexAno,Utrans(ω). (5.3.30) 5.4 The H2(G, T)-valued index In this section we will define the H 2 (G, T)-valued index starting from assumption 5.3.2. We will restate this assumption here for convenience: Assumption 5.3.2. Let ω ∈ P(A) be i. such that there exists an automorphism α ∈ QAut1(A) and a product state ω0 ∈ P(A) satisfying ω = ω0 ◦ α. ii. such that there exists a θ ∈]0, π/2[ for which there exists a map β˜ : G → Aut(A) : g↦ → β˜g satisfying ω ◦ β˜g = ω β˜g = Ad(Vg,2) ◦ ηLg ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU for some Vg,2 ∈ U(A), ηgL ∈ Aut(ACθ∩L) and ηRg ∈ Aut(ACθ∩R). iii. translation invariant (ω ◦ τ = ω). (5.3.2) (5.3.3) (5.3.4) THE H2(G, T)-VALUED INDEXIn what follows, we will first fix certain objects to define the index and then in section 5.4.3 we will show that it is independent of all these choices. Fix an ω0 and an α. Fix (H0 = HL ⊗ HR, π0 = πL ⊗ πR, Ω0) a GNS triple (see theorem B.1.1) of ω0 where (∀σ ∈ {L, R}) πσ : Aσ → B(Hσ) is a GNS representation of the restriction of ω0 to σ. Fix as well V1, α0 = αL ⊗ αR and Θ a choice of decomposition for α such that Θ and ηg commute (see figure 5.1). Because we will be working with states that are translation invariant it make sense to define the translation action on the GNS space of ω0: Lemma 5.4.1. There exists a unique v ∈ U(H0) such that Ad(v) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ ◦ Θ−1 ◦ α−01 and π0(V1)vπ0(V1†)Ω0 = Ω0. (5.4.1) Proof. Since ω ◦ τ = ω we get by the uniqueness of the GNS triple (see corollary B.1.2) that there exists a unique ṽ ∈ U(H0) satisfying Ad(ṽ) ◦ π0 ◦ α = π0 ◦ α ◦ τ ṽΩ0 = Ω0. (5.4.2) Since α = Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ we get that Ad(π0(V1†)ṽπ0(V1)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ ṽΩ0 = Ω0. (5.4.3) Choosing v = π0(V1†)ṽπ0(V1) concludes the proof. 5.4.1 Cone operators We now define a subgroup of U(H0) that includes the representations of cone automorphisms: α0 := αL ⊗ αR. Take σ ∈ {L, R} and x ∈ U(Hσ) ⊗ 1H 2/σ then we say that x Definition 5.4.2. Take 0 < θ < π/2, αL ∈ Aut(AL), αR ∈ Aut(AR) and a ξ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)∩σ such that is a cone operator on σ (or in short x ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ)) ifZand only if there exists ) Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξ. (5.4.4) Coneσ(α0, θ) is a subgroup of U(Hσ) ⊗ 1Z2/σ. We have that ConeR(α0, θ) ⊆ ConeL(α0, θ)′ ConeL(α0, θ) ⊆ ConeR(α0, θ)′. (5.4.5) If additionally ξ ∈ Aut(ACθ∩σ) we will say that x ∈ ConeWσ (α0, θ). Proof. The proof of equation (5.4.5) just follows from the fact that we defined Coneσ(α0, θ) such that ConeL(α0, θ) ⊆ U(HL) ⊗ 1HR ConeR(α0, θ) ⊆ 1HL ⊗ U(HR). (5.4.6) We will also define a generalisation of this. We will define a subgroup of U(H0) that includes both the group π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(U(AR)) and the representations of cone automorphisms: Definition 5.4.3. Take 0 < θ < π/2, αL ∈ Aut(AL), αR ∈ Aut(AR) and Θ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c). Take σ ∈ {L, R} and take x ∈ U(H0) then we say that x is an inner after cone operator on σ (or in short x ∈ IACσ(α0, θ, Θ)) if there exists an A ∈ U(Aσ) and a y ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ) such that x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y. (5.4.7) IACσ is a subgroup of U(H0). We get that IACR(α0, θ, Θ) ⊆ IACL(α0, θ, Θ)′ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) ⊆ IACR(α0, θ, Θ)′. (5.4.8) If additionally y ∈ ConeWσ (α0, θ) we will say that x ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ). Proof. Take uL ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and uR ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ) arbitrary. Take Aσ ∈ U(Aσ) and vσ ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ) (for σ ∈ {L, R}) such that uσ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Aσ)vσ. We then get [uL, uR] = uLuR − uRuL (5.4.9) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vLπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vR − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL (5.4.10) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)Ad(vL) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vLvR − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL. (5.4.11) If we now take ξσ ∈ Aut(AW (Cθ) ∩ Aσ) such that Ad(vσ) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξσ we get that = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξL(AR)vLvR − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL (5.4.12) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vLvR − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL (5.4.13) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vLvR − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL. (5.4.14) Using property (5.4.5) we now get that = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vRvL − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL (5.4.15) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξR−1(AL)vL − π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR)vRπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL)vL (5.4.16) = 0 (5.4.17) concluding the proof. Remark 5.4.4. The main reason for the introduction of the ConeWσ (α0, θ) andwhen translated. More specifically, let x ∈ ConeWσ (α0, θ) then both vxv† and IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ) subgroups is that they are still (inner after) cone operatorsv†xv are elements of Coneσ(α0, θ). The analogous statement is also true for the IAC operators. The following lemma shows that if a unitary on the GNS space of ω0 has an adjoint action that is the product of cones then it is a product of cone operators: Lemma 5.4.5. Take x ∈ U(H0) such that there exist ξσ ∈ Aut(ACθ ∩ Aσ) (for σ ∈ {L, R}) satisfying Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξL ⊗ ξR (5.4.18) then there exist xσ ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ) such that x = xL ⊗ xR. (5.4.19) These are unique up to a phase. Proof. Using lemma B.1.3 the result follows. Following Yoshiko Ogata [48] we now define objects using the following lemma: Lemma 5.4.6. There unitaries Wg ∈ U(H0) and uσ(g,h) ∈ U(Hσ) for all g,h ∈ G and for all σ ∈ {L,R} satisfying Ad(Wg ) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ Θ−1 ◦ α−01 (5.4.20) Ad(uσ(g, h)) ◦ πσ = πσ ◦ ασ ◦ ηgσ ◦ βgσU ◦ ηhσ ◦ (βgσU )−1 ◦ (ηgσh)−1 ◦ α−σ1 (5.4.21) uL(g, h) ⊗ uR(g, h) = WgWhWg−h1. (5.4.22) Proof. The result follows from the fact that assumption 5.3.2 is sufficient to define the objects used in lemma 2.1 and definition 2.2 of [48]. These objects will be the starting point for our definition. Clearly the uσ(g, h) are elements of ConeWσ (α0, θ). The Wg have the following property: Lemma 5.4.7. Take Ξσ ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ) (for all σ ∈ {L, R}) then Ad(Wg)(Ξσ) ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ) (for all g ∈ G). If more generally we take Ξσ ∈ IACσ(α0,Θ) then Ad(Wg)(Ξσ) ∈ IACσ(α0,Θ). Similarly if Ξσ ∈ ConeWσ(α0,θ) then Ad(Wg)(Ξσ) ∈ ConeWσ(α0,θ). Proof. Take Ξ˜σ such that Ξσ = Ξ˜σ ⊗ 1Hσc. Take ξσ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)∩σ) such that Ad(Ξ˜σ ) ◦ πσ ◦ ασ = πσ ◦ ασ ◦ ξσ . (5.4.23) We have that Ad(Ad(Wg)(ΞR)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ζg,R (5.4.24) where ζg,σ := ηg ◦ βgU ◦ ξσ ◦ (βgU )−1 ◦ ηg−1. (5.4.25) Since ζg,σ ∈ Aut(ACθ ∩ Aσ) we get that Ad(Ad(Wg)(ΞR)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = πL ◦ αL ⊗ πR ◦ αR ◦ ζ g,R. (5.4.26) Using lemma B.1.3 there exists a Zg,R ∈ U(HR) satisfying that Ad(Wg)(ΞR) = 1HL ⊗ Zg,R. To show the second result we only need to observe that for any A ∈ U(AR) we get that Ad(Wg)(π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)ΞR) = Ad(Wg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)Ad(Wg)(ΞR) (5.4.27) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξR(A)Ad(Wg)(ΞR). (5.4.28) By the previous result, this is clearly in IACR(α0, θ, Θ) concluding the proof. We now have to define one more object (remember that v was defined in lemma 5.4.1): Lemma 5.4.8. There exist KgL ∈ ConeL(α0, θ) and KgR ∈ ConeR(α0, θ) such that v†WgvWg† = KgL ⊗ KgR = Kg (5.4.29) and they are unique (up to a phase). They satisfy the identity Ad(KgR) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ α−01. 17 (5.4.30) Proof. By some straightforward calculation we have that Ad(Kg) ◦ π0 = Ad(v†WgvWg†) ◦ π0 (5.4.31) = ⊗ πσ ◦ ασ ◦ τ−1 ◦ ησg ◦ βgσU ◦ τ ◦ (βgσU)−1 ◦ (ηgσ)−1 ◦ α−σ1. σ=L,R (5.4.32) Using lemma 5.4.5 concludes the proof that these unitaries exist and are unique up to a G−dependent phase. 5.4.2 Definition of the index Lemma 5.4.9. There exists a C : G2 → U (1) such that KgRAd(Wg) KhRAd WhWg†h)((KgRh)†))uR(g, h) = C(g, h)v†uR(g, h)v ( ( (5.4.33) for all g, h ∈ G. Proof. The proof is presented after lemma B.2.1. Lemma 5.4.10. The function C as defined in lemma 5.4.9 is a 2-cochain. Proof. Take lemma 2.4 from [48]. There it is stated that there exists a 3-cochain C′ such that uR(g, h)uR(gh, k)uR(g, hk)†Ad(Wg)(uR(h, k)†) = C′(g, h, k)1. (5.4.34) It is clear that this 3-cochain is invariant under the substitution Wg → v†Wgv uR(g, h) → v†uR(g, h)v. (5.4.35) If we now prove that it is also invariant under the substitution Wg → KgWg uR(g, h) → KgRAd(Wg) KhRAd WhWg†h)((KgRh)†))uR(g, h) ( ( (5.4.36) we have proved our result because using equation (5.4.33) we then get that C′(g, h, k) = C(h, k)C(gh, k)−1C(g, hk)C(g, h)−1C′(g, h, k) (5.4.37) proving the result. The invariance of the three cochain is proven in lemma B.7.1. Our translation index is now defined as Definition 5.4.11. Let C : G2 → U(1) be the 2-cochain defined in 5.4.9. Take ϕ : G2 → T such that C(g,h) = exp(iϕ(g,h)) then we define the index as IndexA,U(θ,β˜g,ηg,α0,Θ,ω,ω0) := ⟨ϕ⟩ ∈ H2(G,T) (5.4.38) and (as advertised) it is only a function of the automorphisms (and the product state) not on the choice of the GNS triple of ω0 or on the choice of phases in Wg, uL(g, h), uR(g, h), v, KgL and KgR.18 Proof. Clearly the construction is invariant under the choice of GNS triple since this simply amounts to an adjoint action by some unitary on every operator. Now we will show that it is invariant under the choice of phases of our operators. Clearly the 2-cochain C is invariant under uL(g, h) → α(g)α(g)α(gh)−1β(g, h)−1uL(g, h) uR(g, h) → β(g, h)uR(g, h) (5.4.39) Wg → α(g)Wg v → γv. (5.4.40) Under the transformation KgL → δ(g)−1KgL KgR → δ(g)KgR (5.4.41) we get C(g, h) → δ(g)δ(h)δ(gh)−1C(g, h) which is clearly still in the same equivalence class concluding the proof. 5.4.3 The index is independent of the choices we made In this section we will show that the index is only dependent on ω and not on the choices of our automorphisms nor on ω0. First we show independence of α and its decomposition. Lemma 5.4.12. Take ω01, ω02 ∈ P(A) product states and let α1, α2 ∈ Aut(A) be such that ω01 ◦ α1 = ω02 ◦ α2 = ω. (5.4.42) Let V11,V12 ∈ U(A), αL/R,1,αL/R,2 ∈ Aut(AL/R) and Θ1,Θ2 ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c) be such that α1 = Ad(V11) ◦ α01 ◦ Θ1 α2 = Ad(V12) ◦ α02 ◦ Θ2 (5.4.43) 18Even though we explicitly wrote down the on site group action U, this index is only dependent on Ad(U). with α0,i = αL,i ⊗ αR,i, then IndexA,U(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,1, Θ1, ω, ω01) = IndexA,U(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω02). (5.4.44) Proof. We will first prove the result in the case that ω0 = ω01 = ω02 and then generalise this result. Since ω0 ◦ α2 ◦ α−11 = ω0 there exists a x˜ ∈ U(H0) such that π0 ◦ α2 ◦ α−11 = Ad(x˜) ◦ π0. (5.4.45) Now define x ∈ U(H0) to be x := π0(V1†2)x˜π0(V11) (5.4.46) then π0 ◦ α02 ◦ Θ2 = Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α01 ◦ Θ1. (5.4.47) Now take Wg,1, uR,1(g, h) and KgR,1 to be the operators belonging to the first choice (with arbitrary phases). We have (see [48] lemma 2.11) Ad(xWg,1x†) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α02 ◦ Θ2 ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ Θ−21 ◦ α−021, (5.4.48) Ad(xuR,1(g, h)x†) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α02 ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ηRhβhRU (βgRhU )−1(ηRgh)−1 ◦ α0−21 (5.4.49) and through similar arguments we get Ad(xvx†) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α02 ◦ Θ2 ◦ τ ◦ Θ−21 ◦ α−021 (5.4.50) Ad(xKgR,1x†) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α02 ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ α−021. (5.4.51) This shows that xWg,1x†, xuR,1(g, h)x† and xKgR,1x† are operators belonging to the second choice (with our new translation operator). Since our index is invariant under this substitution this concludes the proof when ω0 = ω01 = ω02. γ ∈ Aut(A) satisfying ω02 = ω01 ◦ γ that is of the form γ = γL ⊗ γR. We nowNow suppose that ω01 ≠ ω02. Since they are both product states there exists a have Index(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω02) = Index(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω01 ◦ γ) = Index(θ, β˜g, ηg, γ ◦ α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω01) (5.4.52) concluding the proof. We now show that the index is invariant under some transformation parametrised by the group IACR: Lemma 5.4.13. Take ω0, θ, α0, Θ and ηg as usual, take v, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h) and Kgσ,1 the operators corresponding to these automorphisms and take δgσ ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ) (for all σ ∈ {L, R} and all g ∈ G). Define Wg,2 := δgWg,1 uσ,2(g, h) := δgσWg,1δhσWg†,1uσ,1(g, h)(δσgh)† Kgσ,2 := v†δgσvKgσ,1(δσg)† (5.4.53) (5.4.54) (5.4.55) then equation (5.4.33), defining the index of v, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h) and Kgσ,1, is still valid when we replace these operators by v, Wg,2, uσ,2(g, h) and Kgσ,2 respectively. The two cochain also remains unchanged. Proof. This is proven in lemma B.7.2. We will now show that the index is independent on the choice of β˜g and its decomposition. Lemma 5.4.14. Take β˜g,1, β˜g,2 ∈ Aut(A), Vg,21, Vg,22 ∈ U(A), ηLg,1, ηgL,2 ∈ Aut(AL ∩ ACθ ) and ηgR,1, ηgR,2 ∈ Aut(AR ∩ ACθ ) such that there exist Vg,21, Vg,22 ∈ U (A) satisfying β˜g,1 = Ad(Vg,21) ◦ ηg,1 ◦ βgU β˜g,2 = Ad(Vg,22) ◦ ηg,2 ◦ βgU (5.4.56) and ω ◦ β˜g,1 = ω ◦ β˜g,2 = ω (5.4.57) then Index(θ, β˜g,1, ηg,1, α0, Θ, ω, ω0) = Index(θ, β˜g,2, ηg,2, α0, Θ, ω, ω0). (5.4.58) Proof. Take α = Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (5.4.59) the usual decomposition. Since ω0 ◦ α ◦ β˜g,1 ◦ (β˜g,2)−1 = ω0 ◦ α (5.4.60) there exist δ˜g ∈ U(H0) such that Ad(δ˜g) ◦ π0 ◦ α = π0 ◦ α ◦ β˜g,2 ◦ (β˜g,1)−1. (5.4.61) Inserting equation (5.4.56) and (5.4.59) in this gives Ad(δ˜g) ◦ π0 ◦ Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(Vg,21) ◦ ηg,1 ◦ ηg−,12 ◦ Ad(Vg†,22 ) . (5.4.62) Putting the V1’s to the other side gives: Ad π0(V1†)δ˜gπ0(V1) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(Vg,21) ◦ ηg,1 ◦ ηg−,21 ◦ Ad(Vg†,22 ( ) ) . (5.4.63) Doing the same for the Vg,21 and Vg,22 now gives Ad π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg†,21)π0(V1†)δ˜gπ0(V1) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(Vg,22) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηg,2 ◦ (ηg,1)−1 ( ) Ad π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg†,21)π0(V1†)δ˜gπ0(V1)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg,22) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ηg,2 ◦ (ηg,1)−1 ◦ α−01 ( ) (5.4.64) Since the last equation is split we have by lemma 5.4.5 that we can take δgL ∈ ConeWL (α0, θ) and δgR ∈ ConeWR (α0, θ) such that δgL ⊗ δgR = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg†,21)π0(V1†)δ˜gπ0(V1)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg,22). (5.4.65) Take Wg,1, uR,1(g, h) and KgR,1 to be the operators belonging to the first choice (with arbitrary phases). Define Wg,2 := δgWg,1 (5.4.66) uR,2(g, h) := δgRWg,1δhRWg†,1uR,1(g, h)(δRgh)† KgR,2 := v†δgRvKgR,1(δRg)† (5.4.67) (5.4.68) then by construction Wg,2, uR,2(g, h) and KgR,2 are operators belonging to the second choice. Now using lemma 5.4.13 concludes the proof. Lemma 5.4.15. The index is independent of the choice of angle θ. take ησg,1 ∈ Aut(AL ∩ ACθ1 ) and ηgσ,2 ∈ Aut(AL ∩ ACθ2 ) to be operatorsProof.
