Since Aut(AL ∩ ACθ1 ) ⊂ ) Due to all these considerations we will write the index as IndexA,U (ω) from here on onward. 5.4.4 Example (consistency with conjecture 5.1.2) In this section we will give a special class of translation invariant states that satisfy assumption 5.3.2. We start our construction by taking a state ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ) that satisfies assumption 5.3.3. We restate this assumption here for convenience: Assumption 5.3.3. Take ϕ ∈ P(AL0) such that i. ϕ ◦ βg = ϕ. ii. there exist automorphisms α˜L ∈ Aut(AL0∩L), α˜R ∈ Aut(AL0∩R) and a summable operator b ∈ U(AL0) such that ϕ0 = ϕ ◦ Ad(b) ◦ α˜L ⊗ α˜R (5.3.5) is a product state. Lemma 5.4.16. This ϕ satisfies the split property. (HL ⊗ HR, πL ◦ α˜L ⊗ πR ◦ α˜R, πL ⊗ πR(b†)ΩL ⊗ ΩR) is a GNS triple of ϕ. This Proof. Take (HL ⊗ HR, πL ⊗ πR, ΩL ⊗ ΩR) a GNS triple of ϕ0. By construction concludes the proof that ϕ satisfies the split property. By the result of [47] this implies that ϕ has a well defined 1d SPT index (see appendix B.8). For any j ∈ and n ∈ take Z N Lj := {(x, y) ∈ Z2|y = j} Lnj := {(x, y) ∈ Z2|y = j, x ∈ [−n, n]} (5.4.69) L<j := {(x, y) ∈ Z2|y < j} L>j := {(x, y) ∈ Z2|y > j}. (5.4.70) We introduce some additional notation, for any automorphism α ∈ Aut(AL0 ) we define α(·,j) := τj ◦ α ◦ τ−j. (5.4.71) We will now define the infinite tensor product state. Definition 5.4.17. Take ϕ ∈ P(AL0) arbitrary. There exists a unique state ω satisfying that for any i ∈ we have that for any A ∈ ALi and B ∈ ALci Z ω(A ⊗ B) = ϕ ◦ τ−j(A)ω(B). (5.4.72) Proof. Clearly this condition gives a construction by induction for ω(A) for each A ∈ Aloc. For general elements we define ω(A) := lim ω(An) (5.4.73) n→∞ where An is a sequence in Aloc converging in A. We have that: Lemma 5.4.18. Let ω be the infinite tensor product of a state ϕ that satisfies assumption 5.3.3 then ω satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. The proof is in lemma B.3.1. This shows that ω has a well defined 2d translation index. We will now show that Index(ω) = Index1d(ϕ). We now fix a GNS triple of ω0 that is of the form ⎛ ⎞ ⎜H0 ⎝ = ⊗ Hρ,σ , π0 = ⊗ πρ,σ,Ω0 = ⊗ Ωρ,σ ⎟ σ∈{L,R} σ∈{L,R} σ∈{L,R} ⎠ ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} (5.4.74) where the πρ,σ : Aρ∩σ → B(Hρ,σ) are all irreducible representations. Remark 5.4.19. We clearly have (by construction) that πL−1,L ◦ αL|L−1 ⊗ πL−1,R ◦ αR|L−1 (5.4.75) is a GNS representation of ϕ. This implies that if we take any kR : G → U(HL−1,R) such that Ad(kR(g)) ◦ πL−1,R ◦ αR|L−1 = πL−1,R ◦ αR|L−1 ◦ βgL−1∩R then there exists a 2 cochain C satisfying that (5.4.76) kR(g)kR(h)kR(gh)−1 = C(g, h)1HL−1,R (5.4.77) and that the equivalence class this cochain is in, is given by Index1d(ϕ). Let k˜ : G → U(HL−1) be the unique operator that satisfies Ad(k˜g) ◦ πL−1 = πL−1 ◦ ◦α|L−1 ◦ βgL−1 ◦ α−1|L−1 k˜gΩL−1 = ΩL−1. (5.4.78) Similarly, let w˜ : G → U(HL>−1,L ⊗ HL>−1,R) be the unique operator such that Ad(w˜g) ◦ πL>−1 = πL>−1 ◦ α|L>−1 ◦ βgτi(U) ◦ α−1|L>−1 w˜gΩL>−1 = ΩL>−1. (5.4.79) Clearly both functions are (linear) representation of the group. Now define Wg = π0(V1)†(w˜g ⊗ 1HL−1 ⊗ 1HL<−1 )π0(V1). (5.4.80) This operator valued function is also a linear representation and satisfies thewe get that WgWhWg−h1 = 1H0. This implies that we can take uσ(g,h) = conditions indicated in lemma 5.4.6. Since Wg is a linear representation1⊗ Hσ,ρ (for any σ ∈ {L,R}). All that is now left is to calculate Kgσ ∈ U (Hσ ). We get that ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} Kg = v†WgvWg† (5.4.81) = v†π0(V1)†(w˜g ⊗ 1HL−1 ⊗ 1HL<−1 )π0(V1)vWg† (5.4.82) = π0(V1)†ṽ†(w˜g ⊗ 1HL−1 ⊗ 1HL<−1 )ṽπ0(V1)Wg†. (5.4.83) Notice however that ṽ†(w˜g ⊗ 1HL−1 ⊗ 1HL<−1 )ṽ and w˜g ⊗ k˜g ⊗ 1HL<−1 both leave the cyclic vector invariant and have the same adjoint action on the GNS representation. By the uniqueness of such operators we get that Kg = π0(V1)†(w˜g ⊗ k˜g ⊗ 1HL<−1)π0(V1)Wg†. (5.4.84) Using the adjoint of equation (5.4.80) this gives Kg = π0(V1)†(1HL>−1 ⊗ k˜g ⊗ 1HL<−1)π0(V1) (5.4.85) = 1HL>−1 ⊗ πL−1(b)†k˜gπL−1(b) ⊗ 1HL<−1 (5.4.86) where ṽ = π0(V1)†vπ0(V1). Now there exists a kL : G → U(H ) and a kR : G → U(HL−1,R) such that L−1 ,L kgL ⊗ kRg = πL−1(b)†k˜gπL−1(b) (5.4.87) kgσ⊗1HL>−1,σ⊗1HL<−1,σ. Noticethatwehave(byconstruction)that∀g,h∈G and these kσg will satisfy what was written in remark 5.4.19. Define Kgσ = [Kgσ ⊗ 1HZ2/σ , Wh] = 0. (5.4.88) We now get (using this equation and the fact that Wg is a representation) KgRWgKhRWhWg†h(KgRh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h) (5.4.89) = WgWhWg†hKgRKhR(KgRh)† (5.4.90) = kRgkhR(kgRh)† ⊗ 1HL>−1,σ ⊗ 1HL<−1,σ and by remark 5.4.19 this gives that C(g, h) = C˜(g, h). (5.4.91) 5.4.5 Index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms The goal of this section is now to show that the index we constructed is invariant under locally generated automorphisms (the final proof of this statement is under theorem 5.4.26). To this end let H ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) be G-invariant, translation invariant (in the vertical direction) one parameter family of interactions. Define furthermore for notational simplicity in this section Hsplit = HL + HR (with HL and HR the restrictions of H as defined in 5.2.3). Clearly we have that γtH;ssplit = γtH;sL ⊗ γtH;sR and we still have that γtH;ssplit ◦ τ = τ ◦ γtH;ssplit (just like we have for H ). For the remainder of the section we will use a decomposition using the following lemma: ΦU0;1 ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c∩U) and ΦD0;1 ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c∩D), both commuting with Lemma 5.4.20. Take 0 < θ < π/2 and Θ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c). There existβg , such that there exists some a ∈ U (A) satisfying that γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split = Ad(a) ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1. (5.4.92) Proof. This follows from the fact that γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ∈ GVAut1(A) (see lemma B.10.4 part 2). In what follows, we will define ã := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a). The main property we will use of this operator is that it satisfies the following lemma: Lemma 5.4.21. Let A ∈ U(AW(Cθ)∩σ) then Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0(A) = Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A). (5.4.93) Proof. Using lemma 5.4.20 we get that Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a)(A) (5.4.94) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ΦU1;0 ⊗ ΦD1;0(A) (5.4.95) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split (A) (5.4.96) here Φ1;0 = Φ−0;11. This concludes the proof. We will then use this property to define a morphism: Lemma 5.4.22. Let ã = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a) and define the map ϕ1,σ : IACσ(α0, θ, Θ) → U(H) (5.4.97) : x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y↦ → ϕ1(x) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A)ãyã† where A ∈ U(Aσ) and y ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ). This map satisfies that i. for (the unique) ξ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)∩σ) such that Ad(y) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξ (5.4.98) we get that Ad(ϕ1,σ(x)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Ad(A) ◦ ξ. (5.4.99) ii. it is well defined (independent of the choice of A and y). iii. it is a group homomorphism. iv. ã†ϕ1(x)ã ∈ IACσ(α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1). v. if x ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ) then ã†ϕ1(x)ã ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1). Proof. The proof is presented after lemma B.4.1. We now have to extend the above definition to the group IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) = {ab = ba|a ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ), b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ)}. (5.4.100) Lemma 5.4.23. Define ϕ1 : IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) → U(H) : ab↦ → ϕ1,L(a)ϕ1,R(b) (5.4.101) where a ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ). This satisfies two points. i. It is well defined, by which we mean that for any a, ã ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and for any b, ˜b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ) such that ab = ã˜b we have that ϕ1,L(a)ϕ1,R(b) = ϕ1,L(ã)ϕ1,R(b˜). (5.4.102) ii. It is still a group homomorphism. Proof. This proof is done under lemma B.4.2. Lemma 5.4.24. Define again ã through equation (5.4.92). Let ϕ2 : {v−pWgvp|g ∈ G, p ∈ {−1, 0, 1}} → U(H) : v−pWgvp↦ → ãv−pWgvpã†. (5.4.103) This satisfies Ad(ϕ2(v−pWgvp)) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ−p ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ τp ◦ γH0;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ Θ−1 ◦ α−01. (5.4.104) Proof. To show that this indeed satisfies equation (5.4.104) observe that using equation (5.4.92) we obtain: Ad(ϕ2(v−pWgvp)) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ τ−p ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ τp ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ Θ−1 ◦ α0−1 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0L ⊗ γ1H;0L ◦ Φ−0;11 ◦ τ−p ◦ ηg ◦ βUg ◦ τp ◦ Φ0;1 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ Θ−1 ◦ α0−1. (5.4.105) Since Φ commutes with both the τ−p ◦ ηg ◦ τp and with the βgτ−p(U) the result follows. Lemma 5.4.25. The ϕ1 and ϕ2 defined previouslysatisfy that for any x ∈ IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) we have that ϕ1(Ad(Wg)(x)) = Ad(ϕ2(Wg))(ϕ1(x)). If additionally x ∈ IACWL×R(α0, θ, Θ) we get that ϕ1(Ad(v)(x)) = Ad(v)(ϕ1(x)) ϕ1(Ad(v†)(x)) = Ad(v†)(ϕ1(x)). (5.4.106) (5.4.107) Proof. This lemma is proven under lemma B.4.3. Theorem 5.4.26. Index(ω) = Index(ω ◦ γ0H;1) Proof. Take α ∈ QAut1(A) such that ω = ω0◦α for some product state ω0. Take 0 < θ1 < θ2 < θ3 < π/2 arbitrary. Take αL ∈ Aut(AL), αR ∈ Aut(AR), V1 ∈ U(A) and Θ ∈ Aut AW(Cθ3)c such that ( ) α = Ad(V1) ◦ αL ⊗ αR ◦ Θ. (5.4.108) Take β˜g,1 such that ω ◦ β˜g,1 = ω and such that there exists some V2,g ∈ U(A) and some ηLg/R ∈ Aut(ACθ1 ∩ AL/R satisfying ) β˜g,1 = Ad(V2,g) ◦ ηgL ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU. (5.4.109) Take Wg, uL/R(g, h), v and KgL/R operators belonging to these automorphisms (see lemmas 5.4.6 and 5.4.8). Clearly α ◦ γ0H;1 satisfies ω ◦ γ0H;1 = ω0 ◦ α ◦ γ0H;1. We also have that α ◦ γ0H;1 ∈ QAut1(A). To show this notice that α ◦ γ0H;1 = Ad(V1) ◦ (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 (5.4.110) = Ad(V1) ◦ (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1. (5.4.111) Because of lemma B.10.5 and lemma B.10.4 part 2 there exists a Θ˜ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ2)c and some Ṽ1,A1 ∈ U(A) such that ) α ◦ γ0H;1 = Ad(Ṽ1) ◦ (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ Θ˜ (5.4.112) (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ Θ˜ = Ad(A1) ◦ αL ⊗ αR ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1. (5.4.113) If we now define the automorphism β˜g,2 = γ1H;0β˜g,1γ0H;1 then this indeed satisfies that ω ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ β˜g,2 = ω ◦ γ0H;1. Define η˜gσ ∈ Aut(ACθ2∩σ through lemma B.10.7. ) It satisfies that there exists a Ṽ2,g ∈ U (A), Aσ2,g ∈ U (Aσ ) such that γ1H;0β˜gγ0H;1 = Ad(Ṽ2,g) ◦ η˜gL ⊗ η˜gR ◦ βgU (5.4.114) η˜gσ = Ad(Aσ2,g) ◦ γ1H;0σ ◦ ησg ◦ βgσU ◦ γ0H;1σ ◦ (βσgU)−1. (5.4.115) Take Φ like in equation (5.4.92) and define ϕ1 : IACR(α0,Θ) → U(H) (5.4.116) the group homomorphism defined from lemma 5.4.22. Take similarly ϕ2 : {Wg|g ∈ G} → U(H) (5.4.117) the map defined in 5.4.24 with arbitrary phase. The following operators now belong to ω ◦ γ0H;1 : ṽ = π0(A1)vπ0(A1)† W˜g = π0(A1)ϕ1(δgL ⊗ δgR)ϕ2(Wg)π0(A†1) ũσ(g, h) = π0(A1)ϕ1(δσgWgδhσWg†uσ(g, h)(δgσh)†)π0(A1)† K˜gσ = π0(A1)ϕ1(v†δgσvKgσ(δgσ)†)π0(A1)† (5.4.118) (5.4.119) (5.4.120) (5.4.121) where δgσ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1σ(Aσ2,g) and A1 was defined in equation (5.4.113). The fact that the index is invariant under Ad(π0(A1)) and under ϕ(·) is just due to the fact that both transformations are homomorphisms. To show that it is invariant under the transformation with de δgσ we invoke lemma 5.4.13. All that is left to show is that operators (5.4.118) through (5.4.121) are indeed operators belonging to ω ◦ γ0H;1. This is shown after lemma B.11.1. 5.4.6 Stacking in the H2(G,T)-valued index Take A a quasi local C∗ algebra on a two dimensional lattice and take U ∈ hom(G,U(Cd)) an on site group action arbitrary. Let ω1,ω2 ∈ {ω ∈ P(A)|ω satisfies assumption 5.3.2} be two states. The goal of this section is to prove that (5.4.122) IndexA2,U⊗U (ω1 ⊗stack ω2) = IndexA,U (ω1) + IndexA,U (ω2). (5.4.123) Let ω0i that and γ0Φ;1i (for all i ∈ {1, 2}) be product states and disentanglers satisfying ωi = ω0i ◦ γ0Φ;i1. (5.4.124) Let (H0i, π0i, Ω0i) be GNS triples for the ω0i. Clearly (H01 ⊗ H02, π01 ⊗ π02, Ω01 ⊗ Ω02) is a GNS triple for ω01 ⊗stack ω02. The following lemma now holds: (5.4.125) (5.4.126) Lemma 5.4.27. Let Wg,i, uσi(g, h), Kgσ,i and vi be operators belonging to ωi then Wg,1 ⊗ Wg,2, uσ1(g, h) ⊗ uσ2(g, h), Kgσ,1 ⊗ Kgσ,2 and v1 ⊗ v2 are operators belonging to ω1 ⊗stack ω2. Proof. To show this we simply have to apply the adjoint action of these operators on π01 ⊗ π02 and see that these are indeed implementations of the right automorphisms. This is so by construction. We are now ready to provide a proof of equation 5.4.123. We have C(g, h) = (KgR,1 ⊗ KgR,2)Ad(Wg,1 ⊗ Wg,2)((KhR,1 ⊗ KhR,2)Ad((Wh,1 ⊗ Wh,2)(Wgh,1 ⊗ Wgh,2)†)((KRgh,1 ⊗ KgRh,2)†)) (uR1(g, h) ⊗ uR2(g, h))v†(uR1(g, h) ⊗ uR2(g, h))†v = C1(g, h)C2(g, h) (5.4.127) concluding the proof. Remark 5.4.28. Clearly the same argument can be used to argue that the H3-valued index is invariant under stacking. 5.4.7 The H2-valued index is invariant of choice of basis of on site Hilbert space Let V ∈ U(Cd) be a unitary operator on the on site Hilbert space and take iV as defined in subsection 5.2.1. In this subsection we will prove that IndexA,Ad(V †) (U)(θ, i−V1 ◦ β˜g ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ ηg ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ α0 ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ Θ ◦ iV , ω ◦ iV , ω0 ◦ iV ) = IndexA,U(θ,β˜g,ηg,α0,Θ,ω,ω0). We do this by proving the following lemma: Lemma 5.4.29. Let Wg,uR(g,h),KgR be operators belonging to IndexA,U(θ,β˜g,ηg,α0,Θ,ω,ω0) (5.4.128) (5.4.129) (5.4.130) for a GNS triple for ω0, (H0, π0, Ω0) then Wg, uR(g, h), KgR are also operators belonging to IndexA,Ad(V †)(U)(θ, i−V1 ◦ β˜g ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ ηg ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ α0 ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ Θ ◦ iV , ω ◦ iV , ω0 ◦ iV ) (5.4.131) for the GNS triple for ω0 ◦ iV given by (H0, π0 ◦ iV , Ω0). Proof. To show this, we merely have to observe that for any x ∈ U(H0) satisfying that Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξ (5.4.132) for some ξ ∈ Aut(A) we get that Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ iV ◦ i−V1 ◦ α0 ◦ iV ◦ i−V1 ◦ Θ ◦ iV = π0 ◦ iV ◦ i−V1 ◦ α0 ◦ iV ◦ i−V1 ◦ Θ ◦ iV ◦ i−V1 ◦ ξ ◦ iV (5.4.133) concluding the proof. Clearly the above lemma implies that the H2-valued index is invariant under the desired transformation. Remark 5.4.30. Clearly the same argument can be used to argue that the H3-valued index is invariant under the same transformation. 5.4.8 Proof of theorem 5.3.4 In this section we summarise the proof of theorem 5.3.4: Proof. The 2-cochain was defined in subsection 5.4.2. The proof that it wasn’t dependent on any of the choices made in assumption 5.3.2 was done in subsection 5.4.3. The first item in the list concerning the invariance under locally generated automorphisms was shown in subsection 5.4.5. The proof of the second item concerning the relation between the 1d SPT index and the 2d translation SPT index is done in subsection 5.4.4. The proof of the third item concerning the stacking is done in subsection 5.4.6. The proof of the last item concerning a change of basis of the on site Hilbert space is done in subsection 5.4.7. This concludes the proof. Θ ηgL θ ηgR (-1,-•1) Figure 5.3: This figure indicates the support area of the different automorphisms when there are two translation directions. The angle θ still has to be smaller then or equal to what was indicated here so that the Θ and the ηg commute but now we must be able to do both a horizontal and a vertical widening of the support of ηg. Also the coordinate (−1, −1) which will be of particular interest is indicated. 5.4.9 Proof of lemma 5.3.8 and lemma 5.3.9 We will provide a proof of lemma 5.3.8 which we state here for convenience: Lemma 5.3.8. Take ω ∈ P (A) a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant then it satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. Let γ0Φ;1′ be the disentangler with Φ′ ∈ BFϕ([0,1]) (for some 0 < ϕ < 1) a one parameter family of interactions. By lemma B.10.4 part 5 (which is just a slight modification of section 5 from [48]) we have that γ0Φ;′1 ∈ SQAut1(A) (by which we mean the definition of SQAut as presented in appendix B.10.1, not the one in [48]) since SQAut1(A) ⊂ QAut1(A) this implies that γ0Φ;1′ ∈ QAut1(A). The existence of the β˜g was done in [48] section 3, where one has to use the fact that γ0Φ;′1 is also an SQAut in the definition by [48]. This concludes the proof that assumption 5.3.2 is satisfied. We will now prove lemma 5.3.9 that we restate here for convenience: Lemma 5.3.9. Any G-invariant SRE state ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ) satisfies assumption 5.3.3. Proof. The proof simply uses lemma B.9.1. 5.5 The H1(G,T)-valued index In this section we discuss translation invariance not just in the vertical direction but in two directions simultaneously. Let ν ∈ Aut(A) be the automorphism that translates the lattice to the right by one site. Let µ ∈ Aut(A) be the automorphism that rotates the lattice by 90◦ clockwise. There is a relation between these automorphisms. Specifically, the automorphism τ that translated the lattice upwards by one site can now be written as τ = µ−1 ◦ ν ◦ µ. We now let our state ω satisfy assumption 5.3.5. We will restate this assumption here forconvenience Assumption 5.3.5. Let ω ∈ P(A) be i. such that there exists an automorphism α ∈ QAut1(A) and a product state ω0 ∈ P(A) satisfying ω = ω0 ◦ α. (5.3.11) ii. such that there exists a θ ∈]0, π/2[ for which there exists a map β˜ : G → Aut(A) : g↦ → β˜g (5.3.12) satisfying ω ◦ β˜g = ω β˜g = Ad(Vg,2) ◦ ηLg ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU (5.3.13) for some Vg,2 ∈ U(A), ηgL ∈ Aut(Aν−1(Cθ∩L)) and ηgR ∈ Aut(Aν(Cθ∩R)). iii. translation invariant in both directions ω ◦ τ = ω ω ◦ ν = ω. (5.3.14) For an overview of the supports see figure 5.3. In this section we will need a stronger version of the cone operators (from definition 5.4.2): Definition 5.5.1. Take 0 < θ < π/2 and αL ∈ Aut(AL) and αR ∈ Aut(AR). Take σ ∈ {L, R} and x ∈ U(Hσ) ⊗ 1HZ2/σ then we say that x is a cone operator on νσ(σ)19 (or in short x ∈ Coneνσ(σ)(α0, θ)) if and only if there exists a ξ ∈ Aut(AW(νσ(Cθ∩σ))) such that Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξ. (5.5.1) Coneνσ(σ)(α0, θ) is a subgroup of U(Hσ) ⊗ 1Z2/σ If additionally ξ ∈ . Aut(Aνσ(Cθ∩σ)) we will say that x ∈ ConeWνσ(σ)(α0, θ). 19Where we define νL := ν−1 and νR := ν. Similarly as before we will also need the generalisation of this definition: Definition 5.5.2. Take 0 < θ < π/2, αL ∈ Aut(AL), αR ∈ Aut(AR) and Θ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c). Take σ ∈ {L, R} and take x ∈ U(H0) then we say that x is an inner after cone operator on νσ(σ) (or in short x ∈ IACνσ(σ)(α0, θ, Θ)) if there exists an A ∈ U(Aνσ(σ)) and a y ∈ Coneνσ(σ)(α0, θ) such that x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y. (5.5.2) 5.5.1 Definition of the index First notice that since this assumption is strictly stronger then the assumption in 5.3.2 we can still define all the objects we did before. So in what follows fix a v ∈ U(H0), Wg ∈ U(H0), uσ(g,h) ∈ ConeWνσ(σ)(α0,θ) and Kgσ ∈ Coneνσ(σ)(α0,θ) (for every g,h ∈ G) and then later on we will show independence on the choice of these objects. We remind the reader of some equalities from section 5.4 Ad(v) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ Ad(Wg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηg ◦ βgU Ad(uσ(g, h)) ◦ πσ ◦ ασ = πσ ◦ ασ ◦ ησg ◦ βgσU ◦ ησh ◦ (βgσU )−1 ◦ (ηgσh)−1 (5.5.3) (5.5.4) (5.5.5) uL(g, h) ⊗ uR(g, h) = WgWhWg−h1 (5.5.6) Ad(KgR) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1. (5.5.7) In what follows, we will need the vertical analogue of the v. We define the horizontal translation operator: Lemma 5.5.3. There exists a unique w ∈ U(H0) such that Ad(w) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν ◦ Θ−1 ◦ α−01 and π0(V1)wπ0(V1†)Ω0 = Ω0. (5.5.8) Proof. Analogous to the proof of 5.4.1. We can use these objects to define bσg: Lemma 5.5.4. There exist a bLg ∈ ConeWν−1(L)(α0, θ) and a bRg ∈ ConeWR (α0, θ) (both unique up to an exchange of a G−dependent phase) satisfying that w†WgwWg† = bg := bLg ⊗ bRg. (5.5.9) It will satisfy Ad bσg ⊗ 1HZ2/σ ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ν−1 ◦ ησg ◦ ν ◦ (ηgσ)−1. ( ) (5.5.10) Proof. It is easy enough to show that Ad(w†WgwWg†) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ (αL ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηgL ◦ ν ◦ (ηgL)−1 ◦ α−L1) ⊗ (αR ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ ν ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ α−R1). (5.5.11) To do this one only has to use that βgU commutes with ν. By lemma B.1.3 the result now follows. Lemma 5.5.5. There exists an α : G → U(1) satisfying v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)† = α(g)w†KgRw where hg := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(U(−1,−1)(g)). Proof. The proof is presented after B.2.2. We have that hg ∈ IACL(θ, α0, Θ). On top of that we also have that Lemma 5.5.6. For all g, h ∈ G we have that [hg,Wh] = 0 [hg,bLh] = 0. (5.5.12) (5.5.13) (5.5.14) Proof. We have that (see figure 5.3) Ad(Wh)(hg) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηh ◦ βhU(U(−1,−1)(g)) (5.5.15) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(U(−1,−1)(g)) = hg (5.5.16) concluding the proof of the first item. The second proof is analogous. Finally before we can show that the α is a U (1) representation we need to prove an analogue of the equation in the 2-cochain lemma 5.4.9: Lemma 5.5.7. The equality Ad bRgWgbRhWhWg†h(bRgh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h) ◦ π0 = Ad(w†uR(g, h)w) ◦ π0 ( ) (5.5.17) holds. Proof. The proof is almost completely analogous to the proof of 5.4.9. We first start by showing that Ad bgWgbhWhWg†h(bgh)†WghWh†Wg†uL(g, h) ⊗ uR(g, h) ◦ π0 = Ad(w†uR(g, h) ⊗ uR(g, h)w) ◦ π0 ( ) (5.5.18) holds. This part is completely the same. The only difference is now that to prove that bgWgbhWhWg†h(bgh)†WghWh†Wg† (5.5.19) is split one needs to use the new (shifted) support of ησg. Using this we can show that: Lemma 5.5.8. The α defined previously is a U(1)-representation. Proof. Take the definition of the 2-cochain (lemma 5.4.9) KgRWgKhRWhWg†h(KgRh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g,h) = C(g,h)v†uR(g,h)v. (5.5.20) Clearly this equation is invariant under the substitution Kg↦R → w†KgRw Wg↦ → w†Wgw uR(g,h)↦ → w†uR(g,h)w. (5.5.21) If we now also show that it is invariant under the substitution Kg↦R → v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)† Wg↦ → w†Wgw uR(g,h)↦ → w†uR(g,h)w (5.5.22) then we get using the definition of α that C(g,h) = C(g,h)α(αg()gαh()h) (5.5.23) which would clearly conclude the proof. This invariance is proven after lemma B.7.3. Definition 5.5.9. Let α be the U (1)-representation defined in lemma 5.5.5. Take ϕ ∈ hom(G, T) such that α(g) = exp(iϕ(g)). We define the 2 translation index as IndexA2t,Urans(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0, Θ, ω, ω0) := ϕ ∈ H1(G, T) (5.5.24) and (as advertised) it is only a function of the automorphisms (and the product state) not on the choice of the GNS triple of ω0 or on the choice of phases in Wg, uL(g, h), uR(g, h), v, w, KgL, KgR, bLg and bRg.20 20It is however explicitly dependent on the on site group action U, and not only Ad(U). Proof. Clearly the construction is invariant under the choice of GNS triple since this simply amounts to an adjoint action by some unitary on every operator. The proof that it is independent of the choice of phases is just as trivial. One can also define this index starting from operators acting on the left. As the following lemma shows this gives us the opposite index (the complex conjugate of the U (1)-representation): Lemma 5.5.10. Define α˜(g) such that v†bLgvh†gKgL(bLg)† = α˜(g)w†KgLw (5.5.25) then α(g)α˜(g) = 1. Proof. By multiplying the left hand side of equation (5.5.25) with the left hand side of equation (5.5.12) we obtain v†bgvKgb†g = v†bgvv†WgvWg†b†g = w†v†WgvWg†w = w†Kgw whereas by multiplying the right hand sides we obtain = α(g)α˜(g)w†Kgw. These two results can only be consistent if the lemma holds. (5.5.26) (5.5.27) (5.5.28) (5.5.29) 5.5.2 The H1(G, T)-valued index is invariant under choices In this section we will show that the index is only dependent on ω and not on the choices of our automorphisms nor on ω0. On this last item we remark: Remark 5.5.11. A product state can have a non-trivial H1(G,T) index and the index is not defined relative to ω0 so in particular IndexA2t,Urans(θ,βgU,Id,Id,Id,ω0,ω0) (5.5.30) can still be non-trivial. In fact in this case we get α(g) = ω0(U(−1,−1)(g)). To show this, notice that we can take bg = 1H and we can choose KgR so that it leaves the cyclic vector of ω0, Ω0 invariant. Applying the definition of the index on this cyclic vector then gives us hgΩ0 = α(g)Ω0. This obviously implies that ⟨Ω0, hgΩ0⟩ = α(g)⟨Ω0, Ω0⟩ giving us indeed the advertised equation. We will now show independence of α and its decomposition. Lemma 5.5.12. Take ω01, ω02 ∈ P(A) product states and α1, α2 ∈ Aut(A) such that ω01 ◦ α1 = ω02 ◦ α2 = ω. (5.5.31) Let V11, V12 ∈ U(A), αL/R,1, αL/R,2 ∈ Aut(AL/R and Θ1, Θ2 ∈ Aut(A ) ) be such that W(Cθ)c α1 = Ad(V11) ◦ α01 ◦ Θ1 α2 = Ad(V12) ◦ α02 ◦ Θ2 (5.5.32) with α0,i = αL,i ⊗ αR,i, then IndexA2t,Urans(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,1, Θ1, ω, ω01) = Index2At,rUans(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω02). (5.5.33) Proof. We will first prove the result in the case that ω0 = ω01 = ω02 and then generalise this result. Since ω0 ◦ α2 ◦ α−11 = ω0 there exists a x˜ ∈ U(H0) such that π0 ◦ α2 ◦ α−11 = Ad(x˜) ◦ π0. Now define x ∈ U(H0) to be x := π0(V1†2)x˜π0(V11) then π0 ◦ α02 ◦ Θ2 = Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α01 ◦ Θ1. (5.5.34) (5.5.35) (5.5.36) Let v, w, Kgσ and bσg be operators belonging to the first choice then by construction xvx†, xwx†, xKgσx† and xbσgx† are operators belonging to the second choice. Since the index is invariant under this substitution this concludes the proof in the case that ω0 = ω01 = ω02. Now suppose that ω01 ≠ ω02. Since they are both product states there exists a γ ∈ Aut(A) satisfying ω02 = ω01 ◦ γ that is of the form γ = γL ⊗ γR. We now have IndexA2t,Urans(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω02) = IndexA2t,Urans(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω01 ◦ γ) (5.5.37) = IndexA2t,Urans(θ, β˜g, ηg, γ ◦ α0,2, Θ2, ω, ω01) (5.5.38) concluding the proof. In what follows we will need that the index is invariant under the following transformation: Lemma 5.5.13. Take ω0, θ, α0, Θ and ηg as usual, take v, w, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h), Kgσ,1 and bσg,1 operators corresponding to these automorphisms and take δσg ∈ IACνσ(σ)(α0, Θ, θ) (for all σ ∈ {L, R} and all g ∈ G). Define Wg,2 := δgWg,1 (5.5.39) uσ,2(g, h) := δgσWg,1δhσWg†,1uσ,1(g, h)(δσgh)† (5.5.40) Kgσ,2 := v†δgσvKgσ,1(δσg)† (5.5.41) bgσ,2 := w†δgσwbσg,1(δgσ)† (5.5.42) then the index of v, w, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h), Kgσ,1, hg and bgσ,1 is equal to the index of v, w, Wg,2, uσ,2(g, h), hg, Kgσ,2 and bσg,2. The one cochain also remains unchanged. Proof. The proof is given after lemma B.7.4. We will now show that the index is independent on the choice of β˜g and its decomposition. Lemma 5.5.14. Take β˜g,1, β˜g,2 ∈ Aut(A), Vg,21, Vg,22 ∈ U(A), ηLg,1, ηgL,2 ∈ Aut(AνL(Cθ∩L) and ηRg,1, ηgR,2 ∈ Aut(AνR(Cθ∩R) such that there exist ) ) Vg,21,Vg,22 ∈ U(A) satisfying β˜g,1 = Ad(Vg,21) ◦ ηg,1 ◦ βgU β˜g,2 = Ad(Vg,22) ◦ ηg,2 ◦ βgU (5.5.43) and ω ◦ β˜g,1 = ω ◦ β˜g,2 = ω (5.5.44) then Index2 trans(θ, β˜g,1, ηg,1, α0, Θ, ω, ω0) = Index2 trans(θ, β˜g,2, ηg,2, α0, Θ, ω, ω0). (5.5.45) Proof. Take α = Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ the usual decomposition. Since ω0 ◦ α ◦ β˜g,1 ◦ (β˜g,2)−1 = ω0 ◦ α (5.5.46) (5.5.47) there exist δ˜g ∈ U(H0) such that Ad(δ˜g) ◦ π0 ◦ α = π0 ◦ α ◦ β˜g,2(β˜g,1)−1. (5.5.48) Inserting equation (5.5.43) and (5.5.46) in this gives Ad(δ˜g) ◦ π0 ◦ Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(Vg,21) ◦ ηg,1 ◦ ηg−,12 ◦ Ad(Vg†,22 ) . (5.5.49) Putting the V ’s to the other side gives: Ad(π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg†,21)π0(V1†)δ˜gπ0(V1)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg,22)) ◦ π0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ηg,2 ◦ (ηg,1)−1 ◦ α0−1 (5.5.50) Since the last equation is split we have again by the same argument used to prove lemma 5.4.5 that we can take δLg ∈ Coneν−1(L)(α0, θ) and δgR ∈ Coneν(R)(α0, θ) such that δgL ⊗ δRg = α0 ◦ Θ(Vg†,21)π0(V1†)δ˜gπ0(V1)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Vg,22). (5.5.51) Take v, w, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h), Kgσ,1 and bgσ,1 operators corresponding to the first choice (with arbitrary phases). Define Wg,2 := δgWg,1 (5.5.52) uσ,2(g, h) := δgσWg,1δhσWg†,1uσ,1(g, h)(δσgh)† Kgσ,2 := v†δgσvKgσ,1(δσg)† bgσ,2 := w†δgσwbσg,1(δgσ)† (5.5.53) (5.5.54) (5.5.55) then Wg,2, uR,2(g, h), KgR,2 and bgR,2 are operators belonging to the second choice. Now using lemma 5.5.13 concludes the proof. Lemma 5.5.15. The index is independent of the choice of angle θ. Proof. After what was done so far this result is trivial. Due to all these considerations we will write this index as IndexA2,tUrans(ω) from here on onward. 5.5.3 Example (consistency with conjecture 5.1.3) This example will be very similar to what was done in section 5.4.4. In this case however we will require that the translation morphism ν acts as an automorphism on the C∗ algebra ALi (for all i) and that our one dimensional state is invariant under this automorphism. We will need assumption 5.3.6 which we restate here for convenience: Assumption 5.3.6. Take ϕ ∈ P (AL0 ) such that i. ϕ ◦ βg = ϕ. ii. there exist automorphisms α˜L ∈ Aut(AL0∩L), α˜R ∈ Aut(AL0∩R) and a summable (see subsection 5.2.1 for the definition) operator b ∈ U(AL0 ) such that ϕ0 = ϕ ◦ Ad(b) ◦ α˜L ⊗ α˜R (5.3.15) is a product state. iii. ϕ ◦ ν = ϕ. Since this state satisfies the split property (see lemma 5.4.16) we can define an H1(G, T) valued index for it (see appendix B.8). Now we will take again the infinite tensor product (see definition 5.4.17) of such states then we get: Lemma 5.5.16. Let ωϕ be the infinite tensor product of a state ϕ that satisfies assumption 5.3.6 then ωϕ satisfies assumption 5.3.5. Proof. The proof of this lemma is given in lemma B.3.2. This shows that ωϕ indeed has a well defined H1(G, T) index. We will now show that Index2 trans(ωϕ) = Index1d trans(ϕ). Just like in section 5.4.4, we fix a GNS triple of ω0 that is of the form ⎛ ⎞ ⎜H0 ⊗ Hρ,σ , π0 = ⊗ πρ,σ,Ω0 = ⊗ ⎝ = Ωρ,σ ⎟ σ∈{L,R} σ∈{L,R} σ∈{L,R} ⎠ ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} ρ∈{L>−1,L−1,L<−1} (5.5.56) where the πρ,σ : Aρ∩σ → B(Hρ,σ) are all irreducible representations. Remark 5.5.17. We clearly have (by construction) that πL−1,L ◦ αL|L−1 ⊗ πL−1,R ◦ αR|L−1 (5.5.57) is a GNS representation of ϕ. This implies that if we take any kR : G → HL−1,R such that Ad(kR(g)) ◦ πL−1,R ◦ αR|L−1 = πL−1,R ◦ αR|L−1 ◦ βgL−1∩R (5.5.58) and wL−1 to be such that Ad(wL−1) ◦ πL−1,L ⊗ πL−1,R = πL−1,L ⊗ πL−1,R ◦ ν (5.5.59) then there exists a U(1) representation α satisfying that (πL−1,L(U(−1,−1)(g)) ⊗ 1HL−1,R)(1HL−1,L ⊗ kR(g)) = α(g)wL†−1(1HL−1,L ⊗ kR(g))wL−1 (5.5.60) and that it is given by Index1d trans(ϕ). Just like in section 5.4.4, let k˜ : G → U (HL−1 ) be the unique operator that satisfies Ad(k˜g) ◦ πL−1 = πL−1 ◦ ◦α|L−1 ◦ βgL−1 ◦ α−1|L−1 k˜gΩL−1 = ΩL−1. (5.5.61) We can take Kg = 1HL>−1 ⊗ πL−1(b)†k˜gπL−1(b) ⊗ 1HL<−1 = 1HL>−1 ⊗ (kLg ⊗ kRg) ⊗ 1HL<−1 . (5.5.62) Similarly we can take wρ ∈ Hρ (where ρ ∈ {L>−1, L−1, L<−1}) satisfying Ad(wρ) ◦ πρ ◦ α0|ρ ◦ Θ|ρ = πρ ◦ α0|ρ ◦ Θ|ρ ◦ ν (5.5.63) and then we get that w = wL>−1 ⊗ wL−1 ⊗ wL<−1. Since ηg = IdA we can simply take bσg = 1Hσ. We now have that π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(U(−1,−1))1HL ⊗ KgR = 1HL>−1 ⊗ (πL−1,L ◦ α˜L(U(−1,−1)) ⊗ kR(g)) ⊗ 1HL >−1 . (5.5.64) By what was written in remark 5.5.17 we get that = 1HL>−1 ⊗ α(g)wL−1(1HL−1,L ⊗ kR(g))wL†−1 ⊗ 1HL<−1 (5.5.65) = α(g)w†(1HL>−1 ⊗ 1HL−1,L ⊗ kR(g) ⊗ 1HL<−1)w (5.5.66) = α(g)w†(1HL ⊗ KgR)w showing that indeed Index2 trans(ωϕ) = Index1d trans(ϕ). (5.5.67) 5.5.4 The H1(G,T)-valued index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms The goal of this section is to show that the index we constructed is invariant under locally generated automorphisms. To this end let H ∈ BFϕ([0,1]) be a G-invariant, translation invariant (in both directions) one parameter family of interactions. In the rest of this section we will define (for notational simplicity) H˜split := Hν−1(L) + Hν(R). Clearly, this H˜split is translation invariant in the vertical direction but not in the horizontal direction. The proof is very similar to what was done in theorem 5.4.26 but with some notable differences. We first need a different version of lemma 5.4.20 (in fact it is almost completely identical only the definition of Hsplit is now slightly different) and use this to define some objects used in the rest of the section: Lemma 5.5.18. Take 0 < θ < π/2 and Θ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c). There exist ΦUs;t ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c∩U) and ΦsD;t ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c∩D), both commuting with βg, such that there exists some a ∈ U(A) satisfying that γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split = Ad(a) ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1. (5.5.68) Proof. This follows from the fact that because of B.10.4 part 2 (or a slight modification thereof because of the new definition of H˜split compared to the definition of Hsplit.) γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ∈ GVAut1(A). This lemma is almost identical to lemma 5.4.20. The only difference is the definition of H˜split compared to Hsplit. In analogy to lemma 5.4.21 we will define ã := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a). The main property we will use of this operator is that it satisfies the following lemma: Lemma 5.5.19. Let A ∈ U(AW(Cθ)∩σ) then Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0(A) = Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split(A). (5.5.69) Proof. Analogous to the proof of lemma 5.4.21. We now need a slightly modified version of lemma 5.4.22: Lemma 5.5.20. Take ã := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a) and define the map ϕ˜1,σ : IACσ (α0, θ, Θ) → U (H) (5.5.70) : x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y↦ → ϕ˜1,σ (x) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split (A)ãyã† where A ∈ Aσ and y ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ). This map satisfies that i. for (the unique) ξ ∈ Aut(ACθ∩σ) such that Ad(y) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξ (5.5.71) we get that Ad(ϕ˜1(x)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ Ad(A) ◦ ξ. (5.5.72) ii. it is well defined (independent of the choice of A and y). iii. it is a group homomorphism. iv. we have that ã†ϕ˜1(x)ã ∈ IACσ(α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1). If on top of this x ∈ IACνσ(σ) then ã†ϕ˜1(x)ã ∈ IACνσ(σ)(α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1). (5.5.73) (5.5.74) v. when additionally x ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1) or when x ∈ IACWνσ(σ)(α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ Φ0D;1) we obtain a similar result. Proof. The proof of this lemma is analogous to the proof of lemma 5.4.22. We now have to extend the above definition to the group IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) = {ab = ba|a ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ), b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ)}. (5.5.75) Lemma 5.5.21. Define ϕ˜1 : IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) → U(H) : ab↦ → ϕ˜1,L(a)ϕ˜1,R(b) (5.5.76) where a ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ). This is well defined, by which we mean that ϕ˜1,L(a)ϕ˜1,R(b) = ϕ˜1,R(b)ϕ˜1,L(a). (5.5.77) This is still a group homomorphism. Proof. Identical to the proof of lemma 5.4.23. Lemma 5.5.22. Define again ã := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a), with a defined through equation (5.5.68). Let ϕ˜2 :{Ad(w−pv−s)(Wg)|g ∈ G,p,s ∈ {−1,0,1}} → U(H) : (5.5.78) Ad(w−pv−s)(Wg)↦ → Ad(ãw−pv−s)(Wg). This satisfies Ad(ϕ˜2(w−pv−sWgvswp)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (5.5.79) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−p ◦ τ−s ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ τs ◦ νp ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0. Proof. The proof of this lemma is analogous to the proof of lemma 5.4.24. Lemma 5.5.23. The ϕ˜1 and ϕ˜2 defined previously satisfy that for any x ∈ IACσ(α0, θ, Θ) we have that ϕ˜1(Ad(w−pWgwp)(x)) = Ad(ϕ˜2(w−pWgwp))(ϕ˜1(x)) (5.5.80) ϕ˜1(Ad(vs)(x)) = Ad(vs)(ϕ˜1(x)) (5.5.81) ϕ˜2(Ad(vs)(w−pWgwp)) = Ad(vs)(ϕ˜2(w−pWgwp)) (5.5.82) for any p,s ∈ {0,1}. For the second equation we need the stronger condition that x ∈ IACWσ(α0,θ,Θ). Proof. This lemma is proven under lemma B.5.1. Lemma 5.5.24. There exist maps AL : [0,1] → U(AL) : λ↦ → AL(λ) AR : [0,1] → U(AR) : λ↦ → AR(λ) (5.5.83) both continuous in norm topology and Φµν : [0,1] → Aut(AW(Cθ)c∩µ∩ν) : λ↦ → Φµν(λ) (5.5.84) where µ ∈ {U, D} and ν ∈ {L, ν(R)}, all four continuous in strong21 topology, satisfying that ν ◦ γ0H˜;λsplit ◦ ν−1 ◦ γλH˜;s0plit = γ0H;λL ⊗ γ0H;λν◦ν(R) ◦ γλH˜;s0plit (5.5.85) = Ad(AL(λ)) ⊗ Ad(AR(λ)) ◦ ⊗ Φµν(λ) µ∈{U,D}, ν∈{L,ν(R)} (5.5.86) and that Φµν ◦ βg = βg ◦ Φµν. Proof. This lemma is proven in B.10.13. In what follows, let AL := AL(1), AR := AR(1) and Φµν = Φµν(1). We will now show some properties for these operators. The first one is that they can be used to exchange w and ϕ˜1/ϕ˜2: Lemma 5.5.25. Define aL := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL) aR := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR) (5.5.87) then for any K ∈ ConeL×ν(R)(α0, θ) we get that w†ϕ˜1(K)w = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR K a†L ⊗ a†R w). (5.5.88) Similarly we have that w†ϕ˜2(Wg)w = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR w)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw)ϕ˜1(w† a†L ⊗ a†R w). (5.5.89) Proof. The proof is presented after lemma B.5.2. The second property is that the following lemma holds: Lemma 5.5.26. Define ϵLg ∈ IACL(α0, θ) and ϵRg ∈ IACR(α0, θ) through ϵgσ := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1(Aσ ηgσ ◦ βgUσ(A†σ)) (5.5.90) (where Aσ was defined in lemma 5.5.24) then w†ϕ˜2(Wg)w = ϕ˜1(ϵLg ⊗ ϵRg)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw) (5.5.91) w†ϕ˜1(Kgσ)w = v†ϕ˜1(ϵσg)vϕ˜1(w†Kgσw)ϕ˜1(ϵσg)†. 21Meaning that Φµν(λ)(A) is continuous for all A ∈ A. (5.5.92) Proof. This lemma is proven after lemma B.5.4. The proof of B.5.4 hinges on lemma B.5.3. We also remark that this last lemma is the only place where the compactness of the group is used in the main body of this paper. Theorem 5.5.27. Index2 trans(ω) = Index2 trans(ω ◦ γ0H;1). Proof. The start of the proof is identical to the proof of theorem 5.4.26. Take α ∈ QAut1(A) such that ω = ω0 ◦ α for some product state ω0. Take 0 < θ1 < θ2 < θ3 < π/2 arbitrary. Take αL ∈ Aut(AL), αR ∈ Aut(AR), V1 ∈ U(A) and Θ ∈ Aut AW(Cθ3)c ( ) such that α = Ad(V1) ◦ αL ⊗ αR ◦ Θ. (5.5.93) Take β˜g,1 such that ω ◦ β˜g,1 = ω and such that there exists some V2,g ∈ U(A) and some ησg ∈ Aut Aνσ(Cθ1∩σ) (for σ ∈ {L, R}) satisfying ( ) β˜g,1 = Ad(V2,g) ◦ ηgL ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU. (5.5.94) Take Wg, v, w, KgL/R and bLg/R operators belonging to these automorphisms. Clearly α ◦ γ0H;1 satisfies ω ◦ γ0H;1 = ω0 ◦ α ◦ γ0H;1. We also have that α ◦ γ0H;1 ∈ QAut1(A). To show this notice that α ◦ γ0H;1 = Ad(V1) ◦ (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 (5.5.95) = Ad(V1) ◦ (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1. (5.5.96) Because of lemma B.10.5 and lemma B.10.4 part 2 there exists a Θ˜ ∈ Aut AW(Cθ2)c and some Ṽ1,A1 ∈ U(A) such that ( ) α ◦ γ0H;1 = Ad(Ṽ1) ◦ (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ Θ˜ (5.5.97) (αL ◦ γ0H;1L ⊗ αR ◦ γ0H;1R) ◦ Θ˜ = Ad(A1) ◦ αL ⊗ αR ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1. (5.5.98) If we now define the automorphism β˜g,2 = γ1H;0 ◦ β˜g,1 ◦ γ0H;1 then this indeed satisfies that ω ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ β˜g,2 = ω ◦ γ0H;1. Define η˜σg through lemma B.10.12. It satisfies that there exists a Ṽ2,g ∈ U(A), A2σ,g ∈ U(Aνσ(σ)) such that γ1H;0β˜gγ0H;1 = Ad(Ṽ2,g) ◦ η˜Lg ⊗ η˜gR ◦ βgU (5.5.99) η˜σg = Ad(Aσ2,g) ◦ γ1H;0νσ(σ) ◦ ησg ◦ βgσU ◦ γ0H;1νσ(σ) ◦ (βgσU)−1. (5.5.100) Take Φ satisfying equation 5.5.68 arbitrary and define δgσ := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H˜;1split (Aσ2,g ). (5.5.101) Let ϕ˜1 : IACL×R(α0,Θ) → U(H) (5.5.102) be the group homomorphism defined from lemma 5.5.21. Take similarly ϕ˜2 : {Ad(w−pv−s)(Wg)|g ∈ G, p, s ∈ {−1, 0, 1}} → U(H) (5.5.103) the map defined in 5.5.22. The following operators now belong to ω ◦ γ0H;1 : ṽ = π0(A1)vπ0(A1)† (5.5.104) w˜ = π0(A1)wπ0(A1)† (5.5.105) W˜g = π0(A1)ϕ˜1(δgL ⊗ δgR)ϕ˜2(Wg)π0(A†1) (5.5.106) K˜gσ = π0(A1)ϕ˜1(v†δgσvKgσ(δgσ)†)π0(A1)† (5.5.107) ˜bσg = π0(A1)w†ϕ˜1(δgR)wϕ˜1(ϵRg)ϕ˜1(bRg)ϕ˜1(δgR)†π0(A1)† (5.5.108) h˜g = π0(A1)ϕ˜1(hg)π0(A1). (5.5.109) First we will show that this transformation indeed leaves the index invariant, then we will show that these operators indeed belong to ω◦γ0H;1. Let α ∈ hom(G, U (1)) be the old index and α˜ ∈ hom(G, U (1)) the new one (of course I can only speak about the new index if these new operators are operators belonging to ω ◦ γ0H;1. Let us assume this for now and prove it later.). We have that α(g) = v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)†w†(KgR)†w (5.5.110) = ϕ˜1(v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)†w†(KgR)†w) (5.5.111) = ϕ˜1(v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)†)ϕ˜1(w†(KgR)†w). (5.5.112) Using equation (5.5.92) on this gives us = ϕ˜1(v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)†)ϕ˜1((ϵRg)†)w†ϕ˜1((KgR)†)wv†ϕ˜1(ϵRg)v (5.5.113) = ϕ˜1(v†ϵRgbRgvhgKgR(bRg)†(ϵRg)†)w†ϕ˜1((KgR)†)w. (5.5.114) This shows that the index is invariant under the ϕ˜1 and ϵRg part (simultaneously). The fact that the index is invariant under the ϕ˜1(δg) part is now completely equivalent to the proof of lemma 5.5.13. The fact that the index remains unchanged by the Ad(π0(A1)) transformation is trivial. This concludes this part of the proof. Now we only need to show that these operators indeed belong to ω ◦ γ0H;1. This is proven in lemma B.11.2. 5.5.5 The H1(G,T)-valued index is invariant under rotations by 90◦ Take ω ∈ ω ∈ P (A) { ω is an SRE state, } ∣ω ◦ βg ω, ω ◦ τ = = ω and ω ◦ ν = ω (5.5.115) arbitrary and let µ be the automorphism that rotates the lattice by 90◦. This section will be dedicated to proving that IndexA2,tUra(ngs)(ω) = IndexA2,tUra(ngs)(ω ◦ µ). (5.5.116) In what follows, let ω0 be the product state and let γ0Φ;1 be the disentangler such that ω = ω0 ◦ γ0Φ;1. Proof. Completely analogous to the proof of (for example) B.10.4.
