Let v, w, KgR and bRg be such that Ad(v) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ τ (5.5.126) Ad(w) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ ν (5.5.127) Ad(KgR) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 (5.5.128) Ad(bRg) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ ν ◦ (ηRg)−1 (5.5.129) then v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)† = α(g)w†KgRw (5.5.130) holds. Moreover α = Index2 trans(ω). If one now defines ˜bRg and K˜gU such that ˜bgUKgRXg = v†Xgv (5.5.131) bgRK˜gUXg = w†Xgw (5.5.132) then w†˜bUgwhgK˜gU(b˜Ug)† = α˜(g)v†K˜gUv (5.5.133) holds. Moreover α˜ = Index2 trans(ω ◦ µ). Proof. The existence of the v, w, KgR and bRg is due to the fact that γ0Φ;1 ∈ QAut1(A). This follows from lemma B.10.4 and from the fact that SQAut1(A) ⊂ QAut1(A). By construction this also implies that indeed α = Index2 trans(ω). We now only have to show the second part of the proof. We have that Ad(K˜gU) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = Ad((bRg)†w†XgwXg†) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 (5.5.134) = Ad((bRg)†w†Xgw) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ (η˜Ug)−1 (5.5.135) = Ad((bRg)†) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜gU ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU◦ (5.5.136) ν ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ (η˜Ug)−1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜gU ◦ βgRU ◦ ν ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (η˜gU)−1. (5.5.137) By similar arguments we get that Ad(b˜Ug) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ η˜gU ◦ τ ◦ (η˜gU)−1. (5.5.138) This also shows that Ad(K˜gU) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ µ = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ µ ◦ µ−1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜gU ◦ βgRU ◦ ν ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (η˜gU)−1 ◦ µ (5.5.139) and similarly for ˜bUg and therefore these operators also belong to ω ◦ µ. This together with the independence of the choice of η˜g proves the second result. Lemma 5.5.31. The following equalities hold [hg,w†˜bUgw] = 0 (5.5.140) [w†˜bUgw,v†bRgv] = 0 (5.5.141) [hg,v†bRgv] = 0 (5.5.142) [KgR,˜bUg] = 0 (5.5.143) [hg,KgR] = 0 (5.5.144) [KgR,v†K˜gUv] = 0 (5.5.145) Proof. All of the above commute as automorphisms on the C∗ algebra, we now have to show that the operators in the GNS space commute as well. First we will start by proving equations (5.5.140), (5.5.142) and (5.5.144). For any operator x ∈ U(H0) satisfying that there exists a ξ ∈ Aut(A) such that Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ ξ (5.5.146) we get that Ad(x)(hg) = π0 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ ξ(U(−1,−1)(g)). (5.5.147) Applying this to these equations gives the desired result. To show the remaining equations decompose π0 and γ0Φ;1 as γ0Φ;1 = Ad(B) ◦ ⊗ γ0Φ;i1 ◦ Θ 4 π0 = ⊗ 4 π0,i (5.5.148) i=1 i=1 where the π0,i are irreducible representations in Ai, the areas i are indicated in figure 5.4 and the Θ have support in the areas shaded red. This shows that up to some inner automorphisms the operators with an R on top act on different parts of the decomposition of π0 then the operators with a U on top do. Combining this with lemma B.1.3 concludes the proof. Lemma 5.5.32. α˜(g) = α(g). Proof. We will work out the expression hgv†bRgvw†˜bUgwKgRK˜gUXg (5.5.149) in two different ways. On the one hand we will use (5.5.141) together with equation (5.5.140) to get (5.5.149) = w†b˜Ugwhgv†bRgvKgRK˜gUXg. Now using equation (5.5.130) we get (5.5.149) = α(g)w†˜bUgww†KgRwbRgK˜gUXg = α(g)w†˜bUgKgRXgw = α(g)w†v†Xgvw (5.5.150) (5.5.151) (5.5.152) (5.5.153) where we’ve used equation (5.5.132) in the first equality and (5.5.131) in the second equality. On the other hand, starting with equation (5.5.142), (5.5.143) and (5.5.144) gives (5.5.149) = v†bRgvhgw†˜bUgwKgRK˜gUXg = v†bRgvKgRhgw†b˜UgwK˜gUXg. (5.5.154) (5.5.155) Now using equation (5.5.133) we get (5.5.149) = α˜(g)v†bRgvKgRv†K˜gUv˜bUgXg = α˜(g)v†bRgvv†K˜gUvb˜UgKgRXg = α˜(g)v†bRgvv†K˜gUvv†Xgv = α˜(g)v†w†Xgwv (5.5.156) (5.5.157) (5.5.158) (5.5.159) where we’ve used equation (5.5.145) and (5.5.143) in the first equality, equation (5.5.131) in the second equality and equation (5.5.132) in the last equality. These two results can only be consistent if α(g) = α˜(g) for all g ∈ G. 5.5.6 Stacking in the H1(G,T)-valued index Take A a quasi local C∗ algebra on a two dimensional lattice and take U(g) an on site group action arbitrary. Let ω1, ω2 ∈ {ω ∈ P(A)|ω satisfies assumption 5.3.5} (5.5.160) be two states. The goal of this section is to prove that IndexA22tr,Uan(sg)⊗U(g)(ω1 ⊗stack ω2) = IndexA2,tUra(ngs)(ω1)IndexA2,tUra(ngs)(ω2). (5.5.161) The proof of this is completely analogous to what was in section 5.4.6. 5.5.7 The H1-valued index is invariant of choice of basis of on site Hilbert space Let V ∈ U(Cd) be a unitary operator on the on site Hilbert space and take iV as defined in subsection 5.2.1. In this subsection we will prove that A,Ad(V †)(U) Index2 trans (θ, i−V1 ◦ β˜g ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ ηg ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ α0 ◦ iV , i−V1 ◦ Θ ◦ iV , ω ◦ iV , ω0 ◦ iV ) (5.5.162) = IndexA2,tUrans(θ, β˜g, ηg, α0, Θ, ω, ω0). (5.5.163) The proof is completely analogous to the proof presented in subsection 5.4.7. 5.5.8 Proof of theorem 5.3.7 In this section we summarise the proof of theorem 5.3.7: Proof. The 2-cochain was defined in subsection 5.5.1. The proof that it wasn’t dependent on any of the choices made in assumption 5.3.5 was done in subsection 5.5.2. The first item in the list concerning the invariance under locally generated automorphisms was shown in subsection 5.5.4. The proof of the second item concerning the relation between the 1d SPT index and the 2d translation SPT index is done in subsection 5.5.3. The proof of the third item concerning the stacking is done in subsection 5.5.6. The proof of the last item concerning a change of basis of the on site Hilbert space is done in subsection 5.5.7. This concludes the proof. 5.5.9 Proof of lemma 5.3.10 In this subsection we prove lemma 5.3.10 which we restate here for convenience: Lemma 5.3.10. Let ω be a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant in two directions then it satisfies assumption 5.3.5. Proof. Completely analogous to the proof of lemma 5.3.8 except that the support area of the ηg automorphism has become smaller. To deal with this, replace the SQAut(A) in theorem 3.1 of [48] by SQAut2(A) (see definition B.10.8) and observe that the resulting ηg has the right support. Chapter 6 Conclusion We have shown how the mathematical tools in section 3 can be used to produce multiple SPT indices and that these indices are robust and in some cases complete. In chapter 4 we had a quasi-local C∗-algebra over Z. We defined to concept of G-loops in definition ?? and defined the concept of stable G-homotopy in definition ??. We then produced an H1(G, T)-valued index for G-loops which we called the charge pumping index. We then showed that two G-loops are stably homotopic if and only if they had the same index. We denoted this result in theorem 4.3.8. In chapter 5 we had a quasi-local C∗-algebra over Z2. We defined the concept of SRE in definition 5.2.2 and defined an on site symmetry and two translation symmetries. We defined the sets S0, S1, S2 and S3 as the subsets of SRE states that satisfied some symmetry. We added an equivalence relation on these sets in definition 5.2.3. We then defined an H2(G,T)-valued index for every translation symmetry and an H1(G,T)-valued index in the case where there are two translation symmetries. Finally, we showed that the index is invariant under the choice of representative in the stable equivalence relation. This we formulated in lemma 5.3.13. There is an endless amount of further research that could be conducted that extend the ideas in this work. I give some ideas here: • We could extend the loop classification to other dimensions. More specifically, in 3d it might be possible that the boundary state of a 181 182 CONCLUSION cyclic process is a state with non-trivial invertible topological order. • It could also be interesting to extend the loop classification to states that have non-trivial anyonic topological order. In this case as well, there are loops that might be non-trivial even without the application of any symmetry. In fact in [1] it has been shown there are locally generated loops of the toric code ground-state that exchange the e and m excitations. Such situations could really benefit from a rigorous treatise. • There is another interesting generalisation of the loop classification coming from Kitaev’s Ω spectrum hypothesis (see e.g. [64]). The generalisation is that in stead of comparing the loops of d + 1 dimensional SPTs with their d-dimensional boundary states, we compare maps from the suspension of some differential manifold ΣM to d + 1-dimensional SPT’s to maps from M to the d-dimensional SPTs. This is related to the higher Berry curvature index you will find in [32] and [3]. In conclusion, multiple directions hold the promise of revealing or analysing fascinating new phenomena that could enrich our understanding of quantum matter. Appendix A App endix to chapter 4 A.1 Appendix: basic tricks in Hilbert space In this appendix we collect a few lemma’s dealing with zero-dimensional systems, i.e. we deal with Hilbert spaces without any local structure. A.1.1 An estimate for bipartite systems Lemma A.1.1. Consider a bipartite system H = Ha ⊗ Hb. Let P = Pa ⊗ Pb where Pa, Pb are rank-one projectors acting on Hilbert spaces Ha, Hb. Let ρ be a density matrix on H and let ρa, ρb be the reduced density matrices on Ha, Hb. Then ||ρ − P ||1 ≤ 6√||ρa − Pa||1 + 6√||ρb − Pb||1 Proof. We abuse notation by writing Pi to denote Pi ⊗ 1. First, ||ρ − PiρPi||1 ≤ ||PiρP¯i||1 + ||P¯iρPi||1 + ||P¯iρP¯i||1 ≤ ||Pi√ρ||2||√ρP¯i||2 + ||P¯i√ρ||2||√ρPi||2 + Tr(P¯iρ) ≤ 3 √Tr(P¯iρ) ≤ 3√||ρi − Pi||1 The second inequality follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the last one is because Tr(P¯iρ) = Tr(P¯i(ρi − Pi)) ≤ ||ρi − Pi||1, 183 APPENDIX TO CHAPTER ?? where we used that Pi is rank one. Then, we bound ||PbρPb − PbPaρPaPb||1 ≤ ||ρ − PaρPa||1 and so ||ρ − PbPaρPaPb||1 ≤ ∑ ||ρ − PiρPi||1 ≤ δ := 3 ∑ √||ρi − Pi||1. i=a,b i=a,b Since P = PaPb is rank one, we conclude that |1 − Tr(P ρ)| = | Tr(ρ − Tr(P ρ)P )| ≤ ||ρ − Tr(P ρ)P ||1 = ||ρ − P ρP ||1 ≤ δ. Hence ||ρ − P ||1 ≤ ||ρ − Tr(P ρ)P ||1 + ||(1 − Tr(P ρ))P ||1 ≤ 2δ. A.1.2 Parallel transport We now turn to the Proof of Lemma 4.6.5. Let the normalized vectors Ω, Ψ ∈ H be representativesFirstly, we note that ||ν − ω|| = 1 − a2. We write then Ψ = aΩ + 1 − a2Ψ⊥ of ω, ν. They can be chosen su√ch that a := ⟨Ψ, Ω⟩ is real, with √0 ≤ a ≤ 1. where Ψ⊥ is orthogonal to Ω and has unit norm. Let nowΨ(s) := y(s)Ω + √1 − y(s)2Ψ⊥, y = a + (1 − a)(1 − (1 − s)2) Then, i. ||Ψ(s)|| = 1, ii. Ψ(0) = Ψ and Ψ(1) = Ω, iii. |∂sy|, |∂s√1 − y(s)2| ≤ 2 1 − a. √ Let P (s) denote the orthogonal rank-one projector onto the span of Ψ(s). We consider the adiabatic generator K (s) = i(P (s)P˙ (s) − P˙ (s)P (s)), (A.1.1) which satisfies P˙(s) = i[K(s),P(s)]. We then have ||K(s)|| ≤ 2||P˙(s)|| ≤ 4||Ψ˙(s)|| ≤ 8√1 − a ≤ 8||ν − ω||. This proves items (i,ii). We turn to item (iii). If hν/ω = 0, then U(g)Ω = zω(g)Ω and so U(g)Ψ(s) = z(g)Ψ(s) for all s. It follows that P(s),P˙(s) are invariantand U(g)Ψ = zν(g)Ψ with zν(g) = zω(g) =: z(g). Therefore U(g)Ψ⊥ = z(g)Ψ⊥ and so is K(s) by definition (A.1.1). APPENDIX: BASIC TRICKS IN HILBERT SPACE 185 A.1.3 Contracting loops In this section, we prove Lemma 4.7.9 on the contractibility of loops in Hilbert space. Throughout this work, we often need to appeal to the fundamental theorem of calculus for Banach-space valued functions defined on the interval [0, 1]. Let X be an arbitrary Banach space. We first recall that a strongly measurable Banach- space valued function J : [0, 1] → X : s↦ → J (s) is Bochner integrable if and only if ∫0s du||J (u)|| < ∞, see [23]. We consider functions F : [0, 1] → X : s↦ → F (s) that satisfy the following property: ∫ s F (s) − F (0) = duJ (u), 0 sup ||J (s)|| < ∞ s∈[0,1] where s↦ → J(s) strongly measurable. In particular the function s↦ → αH(s)[A], for a TDI H and A ∈ Aal satisfies this property, with J = αH(u){[H(u),A]}. For the application we have in mind here, it suffices to restrict our attention to the case of finite-dimensional Banach spaces. In that case (more generally in any Banach space with the Radon-Nikodym property with respect to the Lebesgue measure), a function s↦ → F(s) satisfies the property above if and only if it is Lipschitz continuous, in which case J(s) is its derivative almost everywhere. We say that CF is a Lipschitz bound if sups∈[0,1]||J(s)|| ≤ CF. We now come to the Proof of Lemma 4.7.9. As remarked in (4.5.17), the evolved state ν(s) = ν ◦ αE(s) is of the form ν(s)=ν(0)◦Ad(U∗(s)), U(s)=1+i duE(u)U(u). ∫ s 0 We choose a unit vector representative Ω of ν(0), and we set Ψ˜(s) = U(s)Ω. Then s↦ → Ψ˜(s) is Lipschitz, and its almost sure derivative is iE(s)Ψ˜(s). Of course, changing the phase of Ψ˜(s) does not affect the state ν(s) and we use this to introduce a crucial modification of s↦ → Ψ˜(s). Lemma A.1.2. There exists a Lipschitz function a : [0,1]↦ → U(1), with Lipschitz bound 4|||E|||, and such that Ψ(s) = a(s)Ψ˜(s) satisfies k(s) := Re⟨Ψ(s), Ω⟩ ≥ −1/2. Proof. Let k˜(s) = Re⟨Ψ˜(s), Ω⟩. As s↦ → Ψ˜(s) is Lipschitz continuous with bound |||E|||, so is k˜(s). Then the sets κ0 = {s ∈ [0, 1], k(s) > 0}, κ1 = {s ∈ [0, 1], k(s) < −1/2} are open and dist(κ0,κ1) ≥ 2|||E|||. 1 We can therefore construct a continuous, U(1)-valued function a with Lipschitz bound 4|||E||| such that a(κ0) = 1, a(κ1) = −1, and the vector a(s)Ψ˜(s) satisfies the required properties. We started from a loop ν(·) and we now have a function s↦ → Ψ(s). The latter function is not necessarily a loop of unit vectors in the Hilbert space, but it is a family of representatives of ν(s), in particular Ψ(0) = Ω, Ψ(1) ∝ Ω. (A.1.2) We now set for λ ∈ [0, 1], Ψλ(s) := √N (s, λ) 1 (λΩ + (1 − λ)Ψ(s)), N (s, λ) = λ2+(1−λ)2+2λ(1−λ)k(s). With this definition and from the above construction of Ψ(s) and (A.1.2), it follows that i. N ≥ 1/4, ii. ||Ψλ(s)|| = 1, iii. Ψλ(0) = Ω and Ψλ(1) ∝ Ω, iv. Ψ0(s) = Ψ(s) and Ψ1(s) = Ω. Since k(s) is Lipschitz, and N ≥ 1/4, we infer that √1 is Lipschitz. Therefore, and since s↦ → a(s) and Ψ are Lipschitz, also s↦ → Ψλ(s) is Lipschitz. A short N calculation yields ||∂sΨλ(s)|| ≤ 20|||E|||. We denote by P = P (λ, s) the rank-one projector on the range of Ψλ(s). Writing P = |Ψ⟩⟨Ψ|, the Lipschitz continuity APPENDIX: LOCALITY ESTIMATES of s↦ → Ψλ(s) gives that s↦ → P (λ, s) is Lipschitz with ||∂sP (λ, s)|| ≤ 40|||E|||. We can now set Eλ(s) = −i[∂sP (λ, s), P (λ, s)] to satisfy item iii) of the lemma. Moreover, |||Eλ||| ≤ 80|||E|||. To construct the family Fs(·), we proceed analogously, but the considerations are simpler because the functions λ↦ → Ψλ(s) are clearly Lipschitz in λ. Here we find ||∂λΨλ(s)|| ≤ 52 and so |||Fs||| ≤ 208. A.2 Appendix: Locality estimates We review the standard propagation bounds that are necessary for the proofs of Lemma 4.5.2. These bounds go back to [38] but we use proofs in [44]. A.2.1 Functions N+ → R+ Just as in the main text, we denote N+ = {1, 2, . . .} and we consistently denote by r variables in N+. We define transformations M, S, P on bounded functions N + → R+; • M(f)(r)=maxr′≥rf(r′) • P(f)(r)=rf(r) • S(f)(r)=supℓ∈N+ sup ∏i f(ri) (r1,...,rℓ)∈(N+)ℓ:∑ ri=r iThe definition of S(f ) is taken from [15] and its use lies in the fact that fˆ = S(f ), for f < 1, is logarithmically superadditive, i.e, fˆ(r1)fˆ(r2) ≤ fˆ(r1 + r2) r1, r2 ∈ N+. (A.2.1) We now consider the following transformations: i. f↦ → fˆ = M(pf ) for some polynomial p with positive coefficients; ii. f↦ → fˆ = M ( r−b ) or−thbe∈rwNis+e , for some a ∈ N+, b ∈ N. { f 0 a aiii. f↦ → fˆ = S(f ) for f < 1. These transformations have the following important property, referring to the class F introduced in 4.2.2. Lemma A.2.1. If f ∈ F , then fˆ is affiliated to f and depends on the parameters a, b, p, in the sense of Definition 4.5.1. Proof. Only item iii) needs a proof. Note first that if f ≤ F with F logarithmically superadditive, then S(f ) ≤ S(F ) = F . Assume that f (r) ≤ Cαe−cαrα for some 0 < α ≤ 1. By tuning cα, we can choose Cα = 1, so that f is bounded above by a logarithmically superadditive function r↦ → e−cαrα. The claim now follows. Finally, we will often use without comment that max(f1, f2) ∈ F if f1, f2 ∈ F. Local decompositions We recall the canonical decomposition of observables A ∈ A into finitely suppported terms centered at some j ∈ Z, A = ∑k∈N Aj,k, introduced in Section 4.5.3. We will use the bound ||Ax,k|| ≤ {||A − τBkc(j)[A]|| + ||A − τBck−1 (j)[A]|| k > 0 ||A|| k = 0 (A.2.2) and the terms on the right-hand side will in practice be bounded by the following standard result: Lemma A.2.2. For any A ∈ A, ||A − τZc[A]|| ≤ sup ||[O, A]||. O∈AZc ,||O||=1 Proof. If A is a local observable supported in a finite set X, then the claim follows from the expression τZc[A] = ∫ dµX\Z(U)UAU∗ with µX\Z the Haar measure on the unitary group in AX\Z. The general case follows by approximating A with a sequence of local elements. A.2.2 Lieb-Robinson bounds in finite volume In the present section, we restrict our setup to finite volume, as it is mostly done for the discussion of Lieb-Robinson bounds. More concretely, we assume that all the operators appearing below, in particular the spatial terms of the APPENDIX: LOCALITY ESTIMATES interactions, belong to the algebra A[−L,L] for a large but finite L. In order to ensure a smooth passing to infinite volume in Section A.2.3, we will only consider interactions and TDIs that are restrictions of infinite volume interactions and TDIs. For example, a TDI H(L) on A[−L,L] will be the restriction of a TDI H on the full chain algebra as defined in Section 4.2.2, namely HS(L) = HS whenever S is a subset of [−L, L]. The advantage of this is that the decay function fH associated with H can be chosen fixed and independent of L. Similarly, all estimates are understood to be independent of L. In order not to overburden the notation, we will not keep the superscripts L below. Let H be a TDI as introduced above and let αH be the associated almost local evolution, in the sense that αH (s)[A] = A + i du αH (u){[H (u), A]}. ∫ s 0 In contrast with the main text, we allow here arbitrary times s ∈ R. The existence and uniqueness of this finite-volume dynamics follows from elementary facts on matrix-valued ODE’s. We now state a version of the Lieb-Robinson bound, using the language introduced in section A.2.1. Lemma A.2.3. Let h = S(max( Mv(PfFfF) , Mv(PfHfH) )), v(f ) = sup(Pf (r)) r fˆ(r) = M{(r−1)2Ph(r−1) r−1 + 0 2 2 2 ∈ N otherwise Then for any subset X , ||αH (s)(F )||X,fˆ ≤ 8esv(fH )CH v(fF )||F ||X,fF where CH = sups∈R ||H (s)||fH . Note that fˆ ∈ F if fH , fF ∈ F . (A.2.3) (A.2.4) Proof. We will start from the bound (A.2.5) below. This bound follows from equations (3.41-3.42) of [44] once one proves that the reminder term RN (t) appearing in (3.41) in [44] vanishes as N → ∞. The vanishing of this remainder term is proven analogously to the bounds that we derive below and so we do not comment on this further. For A ∈ AS0 and O ∈ ABr−1(x)c with r ∈ N+, ||[O, αH (s)[A]|| ≤ 2||A|| ∑ ∑ ∫ s ||O|| du||HSn (un)|| . . . ||HS1 (u1)||, n≥0 S1,...,Sn: Sj+1∼Sj ,j=0,...,n (A.2.5) where i. we denote S ∼ S′ whenever S, S′ intersect, ii. ∫ s du is shorthand for ∫0s du1 ∫0u1 du2 . . . ∫0un−1 dun, iii. we introduced the dummy Sn+1 = Br−1(x)c (in particular, the n = 0 term equals 0 if S0 and Br−1(x)c are disjoint and 1 otherwise). We now take A = ∑S0∋x |S10|FS0. Then the bound above, linearity of the commutator and the triangle inequality yield tr := sup ||[O, αH (s)[A]]|| ≤ 2 ∑ ∑ ∫ s O∈ABr−1(x)c ||O|| n≥0 S0,S1,...,Sn: ||F|SS00||| du||HSn (un)|| . . . ||HS1 Sj+1∼Sj,j=−1,...,nwhere we have introduced the dummy S−1 = {x}, i.e. S0 is from now on constrained to satisfy S0 ∼ {x}. Recalling the definition of h in (A.2.3), fF (diavm(f(FS)0) + 1) nj∏=−11 |Sj |fH (dvi(afmH()Sj ) + 1) fF (diavm(f(SFn)) + 1) j∏=0 h(diam(Sj )+1) n ≤ ≤ h(∑ diam(Sj ) + n + 1) ≤ h(r) (A.2.6) n j =0 where the second inequality is because h is logarithmically superadditive and the last inequality is because ∑nj=0 diam(Sj) ≥ r and h is non-increasing. Hence we get, dropping the condition Sn+1 ∼ Sn, ht(rr) ≤ 2 ∑ ∑ n n≥0 S0,...,Sn fF (vd(ifaFm)|(|SF0S)0+|| 1) ∫ s du j∏=1 |Sj−v1(|ffHH)(|d|HiaSmj((uSjj))||+ 1) Sj+1∼Sj:j=−1,...,n−1 (A.2.7) We can now perform iteratively the sum Sj iteratively, starting at j = n and using that 1 ∑ |Sj−1| Sj:Sj∼Sj−1 fH (1||H+Sdji(aum)|(|Sj )) ≤ ||H (u)||fH , and for the last factor j = 0, S0∋x fF (diam(S0) + 1) ≤ ||F ||fF . ∑ ||FS0|| APPENDIX: LOCALITY ESTIMATES Taking sup over u and performing the integrals, we get ht(rr) ≤ 2 ∑ snn! CHn v(fH )n||F ||fF v(fF ) ≤ 2e sv(fH)CHv(fF)||F||fF =: R. n≥0 (A.2.8) From the bound (A.2.2) and Lemma A.2.2 we conclude that, with Kj,r = (αH(s)[A])j,r ||Kj,r|| ≤ tr + tr+1 ≤ 2tr ≤ 2h(r)R. Note that the estimate is independent of the site j. To convert these bounds into a bound on ||αH(s)[F]|| we note that, for a non-increasing fˆ, S∑∋n fˆ(diam(S) + 1) ||(αH (s)[F ])S|| ≤ fˆ(1) ||Kn,0|| + 1 1 ∑ ∑ 1 ||Kj,r|| r∈N+ j:dist(j,n)=r fˆ(2r + 1) (A.2.9) ≤ 2fhˆ((11)) R + 2 r∑∈N+ fˆ(22rr++11) h(r)R. (A.2.10) In the first inequality, we recalled the definition (4.5.3). We choose fˆ as in (A.2.4), so that in particular fˆ(1) ≥ 3h(1) and fˆ(2r + 1) ≥ r2(2r + 1)h(r). Then (A.2.10) is bounded by 23 R + 2π62 R ≤ 4R from which the lemma follows. A.2.3 Passage to infinite volume As was already pointed out in the original [38], the finite volume Lieb-Robinson bound implies the convergence of the ∗-automorphisms αH(L) as L → ∞. Lemma A.2.4. Let αH(L) be the finite volume almost local evolution above. Then, for any A ∈ A and s ∈ R, the limit αH(s)[A] = Ll→im∞αH(L)(s)[A] exists and defines astrongly continuous family of ∗-automorphisms solving the Heisenberg equation (4.2.1). The extension of αH (s) to interactions, as defined in Section 4.5.3, satisfies the same bound as given in Lemma A.2.3. The proof of this claim relies on Lemma A.2.3, its proof and most importantly of the fact that the bounds therein hold uniformly in L. Since the argument is well-known, we omit it here. Finally, we can now prove the bound of Lemma 4.5.2 item (iv). It follows because we can now restrict to s ∈ [0, 1], and hence the prefactor 8esv(fH)CH v(fF ) can be omitted by choosing fˆ judiciously. A.2.4 Useful local transformations We say that a function fˆ∈ F is weakly affiliated to f ∈ F if f(r) ≤ Cβe−cβrβ for some β ≤ 1 implies that for any 0 < β′ < β, there are cβ′,Cβ′ such that fˆ(r) ≤ Cβ′e−cβ′rβ′, cf. Definition 4.5.1. For any function w ∈ L1(R) that satisfies the decay property |w(t)| ≤ Ce−c(log|t||t|)2 , (A.2.11) we define the map KwH : Aal → Aal KwH [A] = ∫ ∞ w(t)αH (t)[A]dt −∞ and this map is extended to a map on interactions, just as we did for automorphisms. Lemma A.2.5. For an interaction H and f ∈ F such that ||H||f < CH, ||KwH[A]||X,fˆ ≤ ||A||X,f, A ∈ Aal, for some fˆ that is weakly affiliated to f and that depends on CH. Given a pair of interactions H1,H2 such that ||Hj||f < CH, we have ||KwH2[A] − KHw1[A]||X,fˆ ≤ C||A||X,f||H2 − H1||f As we shall see shortly, the function fˆ depends on w, in particular on the decay rate appearing in (A.2.11). The map Kw[·] will be used in Lemma A.3.2 with two different functions having the same rate c. While this rate is directly related to a spectral gap, we will show that this gap is larger than 1 in our construction, see Proposition A.3.1; in particular, this constant depends on no parameter 2 of our setting. We therefore chose not to emphasize the w-dependence in the lemma. APPLICATIONS OF SPECTRAL FLOW Proof. Let X be such that ||A||X,f < ∞ and let x ∈ X. Let h be the function appearing in Lemma A.2.3, and let tr(O) = ||O − trBr−1(x)c O||. We estimate tr(KHw[A]) ≤ |w(t)|tr(αH(t)[A])dt ∫ (A.2.12) ∫ ≤ |w(t)| min h(r)2e|t|v(f )CH v(f )||A||X,f , 2||A|| dt ( ) (A.2.13) ( ∫ ∞ ( ) ≤ 2||A||X,f h(r)||w||L1 + χ |t| ≥ − −∞ logv((fv()fC)Hh(r)) )|w(t)|f (1)dt (A.2.14) since ||A|| ≤ ||A||X,f f (1). The second inequality follows from Lemma A.2.3 and the preservation of norms under unitary evolution. To estimate the integral in the last line, we observe that ∫ |w(t)|χ(|t| > a)dt ≤ Cae−clog(a)2 . a Therefore, we get the bound tr(KwH[A]) ≤ 2||A||X,f||w||L1 h(r) + Ca(r)e−clog(aa((rr)))2 ( ) , a(r) = v(f)CH − log(v(f)h(r)) . The second term in the bracket, considered as a function of r, is in F. Therefore, we have tr(KwH[A]) ≤ ||A||j,fĥ(r) for some ĥ ∈ F that depends on h,f. In fact, it is weakly affiliated to h and therefore to f. The remainder of the proof follows the end of the proof of Lemma A.2.3. The second part of the lemma follows similarly using Duhamel’s formula. A.3 Applications of spectral flow The aim of this section is to review the proofs of the stability result Proposition 4.8.3 and the uniqueness result Proposition 4.8.2. As already mentioned, Proposition 4.8.3 is a standard result, but the present setting allows for some simplifications. In contrast, Proposition 4.8.2 seems not be contained in the literature. A.3.1 Spectral flow for gapped systems We start out in the same finite-volume setting as in Section A.2.2. The finite volume C∗-algebra is isomorphic to a simple matrix algebra that we write as M acting on a finite-dimensional Hilbert space. The trace on M is written as Tr(·). Throughout this section, we fix a constant CH and a function f and consider interactions such that ||H||f < CH. Let us write σ(·) for the spectrum of an operator. Definition A.3.1. We say that H has a spectral gap ∆ if E0 = minσ(H) is a simple eigenvalue of H and 0 < ∆ ≤ dist(E0, σ(H) \ E0) In accordance with our finite volume conventions, the independence of ∆ on the finite size of the system is part of the definition. In what follows, we always use P to denote the one-dimensional spectral projector corresponding to E0 and we write P¯ = 1 − P . We write ωP to denote the state on M given by ωP (A) = Tr(P A), A ∈ M. Lemma A.3.2. Let H have a spectral gap ∆. There are integrable functions v, q satisfying the bound (A.2.11) such that i. ∫ ∞ v(t)dt = 1 and v ≥ 0; −∞ ii. KHv (H ) = H ; iii. [KHv (A), P ] = 0 for any A ∈ M; iv. [H, KHq (A)] = A for any A ∈ M such that A = P AP¯ + P¯ AP . Proof. We denote by ŵ the Fourier transform of an integrable function w. We choose a non-negative v such that vˆ is compactly supported in (−∆, ∆) and vˆ(0) = 1. We choose q and such that qˆ(x) = √21πx for |x| ≥ ∆. The possibility of doing this while satisfying the bound (A.2.11) was explained in [8]. Item (ii) is immediate and properties (iii,iv) follow by spectral calculus. The following lemma shows an important application of the above construction. This idea of the lemma goes back to [28], see also [8]. Lemma A.3.3. Let H be a TDI such that |||H(s)|||f < CH and H(s) has a spectral gap ∆ for all s ∈ [0,1]. Let P(s) denote the ground state projector for H(s). If ∫ s H (s) = H (0) + duY (u), |||Y |||f < ∞, (A.3.1) 0 then there exists a TDI Ŷ such that ωP (s) = ωP (0) ◦ αŶ (s) and such that |||Ŷ |||fˆ ≤ C|||Y |||f for some fˆ weakly affiliated to f and that depends on CH. Proof. We define the TDI Ŷ by Ŷ (s) = −iKqH(s)[Y (s)]. The required bound on Ŷ holds by Lemma A.2.5. By (A.3.1), s↦ → H(s) is Lipschitz with bounded derivative Y (s) almost everywhere. By the gap assumption, s↦ → P (s), and therefore s↦ → ωP (s)[A] (for any A ∈ M), have the same property and one checks using Lemma A.3.2 that the derivative of the latter equals ωP (s)([Ŷ (s), A]) almost everywhere. We conclude that ωP (s) = ωP (0) ◦ αŶ (s), as required. A.3.2 Stability of the gap For the next result, we recall the definition of the interaction F given at the beginning of Section 4.8, but now restricted to a finite volume. Recall in particular (i) that F has only on-site terms with ||Fj|| = 1 and (ii) that F has a spectral gap equal to 1. It follows that ||F||f = f(1) for all f ∈ F. The next proposition is a special case of the celebrated stability result of [14]. Proposition A.3.1. For any f ∈ F , there is ϵ(f ) > 0 such that, for any interaction W with ||W ||f ≤ ϵ(f ), the interaction H = F + W has a spectral gap ∆ = 1 . 2 Proof of Proposition A.3.1 We adopt the notation of Lemma’s A.3.2 and A.3.3. Let H(s) = F + sW with s ∈ [0, 1]. We let s0 be the maximal value in [0, 1] such that the spectral gap of H is at least 1/2 for s ∈ [0, s0]. Note that the spectral gap of F is equal to 1 and that s0 > 0 by spectral perturbation theory for finite dimensional matrices (here, no uniformity of s0 in the finite volume is claimed nor required!) If s0 < 1, then necessarily the spectral gap of H(s0) is equal to 1/2. We prove now that this gap is actually not smaller than 1 − ϵ(f ), thus forcing a contradiction if ϵ(f ) < 1/2. Let Ŷ be the TDI of Lemma A.3.3 generating the spectral flow automorphism which exists by of the gap assumption, and let H˜ := αŶ (s0)[H(s0)]. Note that H˜, being isospectral to H, has a simple eigenvalue at the bottom of its spectrum. By the spectral flow, P := P(0) is its ground state projector. Since H(s0) is an interaction and the spectral flow is an almost local evolution, we can write H˜ = ∑j H˜j such that H˜j is anchored at j and such that ||H˜j||j,fˆ ≤ C for some fˆ weakly affiliated to f. Next, we use the diagonalization operator F = KvH˜, see Lemma A.3.2, so that H˜ F (H˜ ) = ∑ F (H˜j ) = j is written as a sum of almost-local terms F(H˜j) anchored at sites j that satisfy [P,F(H˜j)] = 0. Let now Aj := (F (H˜j ) − Fj ) − ωP (F (H˜j ) − Fj ). The operators Aj and the sum A = ∑ Aj j have the following properties: i. F + Ahas the same spectral gap as H˜ , hence as H . ii. The terms Aj satisfy Aj P = P Aj = 0. iii. There is f ′ ∈ F weakly affiliated to f such that sup ||Aj ||j,f ′ ≤ C ||W ||f j where we denoted || · ||j,f ′ = || · ||{j },f ′ . (A.3.2) (A.3.3) (A.3.4) The first two properties are by construction and by the fact that P is one- dimensional. In order to derive the third one, we note that KFv [Fj ] = Fj because F is a sum of on-site terms and write F (H˜j ) − Fj = KHv˜ [H˜j ] − KFv [Fj ] = KHv˜ [H˜j − Fj ] + (KHv˜ [Fj ] − KFv [Fj ]) The bound (A.3.4) follows from ||H˜j − Fj ||j,f ′ ≤ C ||W ||f and Lemma A.2.5. By the locality property (A.3.4), we know that Aj can be written as a sum terms anchored in j, with increasing support and rapidly decreasing norm. We need to modify this decomposition so that each of the terms, and not just the sum, satisfies the above item ii). Lemma A.3.4. For each j, we can write Aj = ∑r Dj,r such that the following holds (we suppress the index j and we write Br for the ball with radius r centred at j): i. DrPBr = PBrDr = 0; ii. ||Dr|| ≤ fˆ(r)||Aj||j,f′, where f′ is the function appearing in (A.3.4) and fˆis affiliated to f′. Note that fˆis therefore weakly affiliated to f. Proof. We define the conditional expectation Er(O) = TrBrc(OPBrc) ⊗ 1Brc Since the volume is finite, Brc = ∅ and hence TrBcr(O) = O for large enough r. We set Dr = EE1r((AAjj)),− Er−1(Aj), r => 1 { r 1 Because of finite volume, we have Dr = 0 for large enough r, and Aj = ∑r Dr as required. Further, the product property P = PBr PBcr implies that P Er (Aj ) = Er (Aj )P = TrBrc (Aj P ) ⊗ PBrc = 0 because of Aj P = 0, and then also PBr′ Er (A) = Er (A)PBr′ = 0 for r′ ≥ r. This implies (i). In order to get estimate (ii), we use the standard decomposition Aj = ∑k≥0 Aj,k described in Section 4.5.3 and recall that ||Aj,k || ≤ f˜(k + 1)||Aj||j,f′ where f˜ is affiliated to f′, see Lemma 4.5.5, item i. The bound ||Dr|| ≤ 2 ∑k≥r ||Aj,k|| then yields the claim with fˆ(r) = 2 ∑k≥r f˜(k + 1). From DrPBr = PBrDr = 0 and FBr ≥ 1 − PBr, we conclude that Dr ≤ ||Dr||FBr (A.3.5) where the inequality is here in the sense of operators. We now lift this inequality to A. Lemma A.3.5. The following operator bound holds: A ≤ C(f)||W||fF, where C(f) depends only on f ∈ F, in particular not onL. Proof. To get the statement of the lemma, we first write F = ∑ Fj = ∑ r2 ∑ Fj = ∑ ∑ ar2 Nr (j ) FBr (j ) 1 1 1 j a r j r j where a = ∑ 12 = π2 and Nr (j ) is the number of balls of radius r that contain j ; in pra≥r1tircular Nr (j ) ≤ 2r + 1. Then, reinstating the site index j in 6 Aj and using (A.3.5), we get A = ∑∑Dj,r ≤ ∑∑||Dj,r||FBr(j) ≤ δ ∑∑ 1 j r r j r j ar2Nr(j)FBr(j) = δF with δ = supr,j ||Dj,r||ar2Nr(j). To estimate δ, we use Lemma A.3.4 item ii and recall (A.3.4) to conclude that δ ≤ Ca||W ||f sup(r2(2r + 1)fˆ(r)) r which is finite since fˆ ∈ F . It only depends on f since fˆ does. This yields the claim of the lemma. From standard spectral perturbation theory, it then follows that that the spectral gap of F + A, and therefore of H, is not smaller than 1 − C(f)||W||f, which is in contradiction to the assumption that s0 < 1. A.3.3 Passage to infinite volume: Proof of Proposition 4.8.3 The previous sections of this appendix were staged in finite volume, but now we revert back to infinite volume. Interactions in particular again refer to infinite-volume objects, and we derive finite-volume interactions from them by setting HS(L) = χ(S ⊂ [−L,L])HS Note that bounds are inherited from infinite volume, i.e. ||H(L)||f ≤ ||H||f. For convenience, we restate Proposition 4.8.3. Proposition 4.8.3. For any h ∈ F, there is 0< ϵ3(h) < 1 such that, for any pair of TDIs W and Y satisfying |||W |||h ≤ ϵ3(h), |||Y |||h < ∞, W (z) − W (0) = dz′Y (z′), (4.8.3) ∫ z 0 the following holds: There exists a TDI Ŷ satisfying |||Ŷ |||h′ ≤ |||Y |||h for h′ ∈ F depending only on h, such that, if the pure state ν is a ground state of F + W (0), then ν(z) = ν(0) ◦ αŶ (z), z ∈ [0, 1] (4.8.4) is a ground state of the interaction F + W (z). If Y is G-invariant, then also Ŷ can be chosen G-invariant. Proof. We note that H(L) = F (L) + W (L) satisfies all conditions of Proposition A.3.1 if we take ϵ1(h) small enough. Therefore, they also satisfy all conditions of Lemma A.3.3, with the TDI Y in that lemma given by Y (L) (derived from the infinite volume TDI Y ). We denote by PL(s) the spectral projections of Lemma A.3.3 by and Ŷ (L) the TDIs constructed in Lemma A.3.3. The notation reflects the fact that the latter are not restrictions of an infinite volume interaction. However, the L-dependent TDIs Ŷ (L) satisfy the following compatibility requirement: As a consequence of the Lieb-Robinson bound, the limits ŶS (s) := lim Ŷ (L, s)S (A.3.6) L exist, uniformly in s. It follows that the TDI Ŷ inherits the bounds of Lemma A.3.3 on Ŷ (L) and we conclude that |||Ŷ |||h′ ≤ |||Y |||h with h′ ∈ F depending only on h. To complete the proof of Proposition 4.8.3, we still need to show that ψ(s) = ψ(0) ◦ αŶ (s) is a ground state associated to H(s). Here ψ(0) is the product state that is a ground state associated to the interaction F . By (A.3.6) and the Lieb-Robinson bound, we see that ψ(s)[A] = lim ωPL(s)[A] L for A ∈ A with local support. Since ωPL(s) are ground states associated to the truncated interactions H(L), we deduce by density that ψ(s) is a ground state associated to the interaction H(s). A.3.4 Proof of Proposition 4.8.2 Our aim in this final section is to prove the uniqueness of the ground state (in the sense of Defintion 4.8.2) of the interaction F + W (s) for W small enough. The following lemma is a special case of what was already proven at the end of Section A.3.3. Recall that ωPL is the state on AL corresponding to the projector PL, i.e. ωPL(A) = TrL(PLA). Then Lemma A.3.6. For A ∈ A with finite support, the limit ν(A) = limωPL(A) L exists. By density, ν extends to a state on A. For any ground state ψ associated to H, the invariance property (4.8.2) implies that ψ(A) = ψ(KHv(A)) = limψ(KvH(L)(A)) L with the function v as in Lemma A.3.2 item iii). The second equality is by the Lieb-Robinson bound. Now KvH(L)(PLAP¯L) = KHv(L)(P¯LAPL) = 0, where P¯L = 1 − PL. Hence, ψ(A) = lim(ψ(KHv(L)(PLAPL)) + ψ(KHv(L)(P¯LAP¯L)) (A.3.7) L = lim(ψ(PLAPL) + ψ(KHv(L)(P¯LAP¯L)) (A.3.8) Lwhere the second equality follows because PL is a one-dimensional spectral projection of H(L). If we choose A with finite support, then for large enough L, ψ(PLAPL) = ψ(PL) TrL(PLA). Since ψ(PL) ∈ [0, 1], there is a subsequence Ln such that the limit limn ψ(PLn ) exists. We call this limit a ∈ [0, 1]. We then see from Lemma A.3.6 that limψ(PLnAPLn) = aν(A) n and this equality extends by density to any A ∈ A. From (A.3.8), it then follows that ψ(A) = aν(A) + (1 − a)µ(A) (A.3.9) where, in case a < 1, µ(A) = lim ψ(P¯Ln)ψ(P¯LnKvH(Ln)(A)P¯Ln) 1 n and we used Lemma A.3.2 item iii) to commute the projectors. The existence of the limit follows because the first term in (A.3.8) has a limit. We now claim that µ is a state. Indeed, positivity follows from the nonnegativity of the function v. Normalization follows from KHv(Ln)(I) = I since ∫ v = 1. Now, since ψ is assumed to be pure, (A.3.9) means that either a = 0 or a = 1, since we can easily check that ν and µ are not equal. We will exclude the case a = 0, which will end the proof. We define the boundary operator BL = ∑ WS S:S∩[−L,L]≠0,S∩[−L,L]c≠∅ satisfying ||BL|| ≤ 2f(1)||W||f. By the variational principle Lemma 4.8.3 ψ(H(L) + BL) ≤ (ωPL ⊗ ψ|[−L,L]c)(H(L) + BL) which implies ψ(H(L)) ≤ ωPL(H(L)) + 2||BL|| By the gap assumption, we have also ψ(H(L)) ≥ ψ(PL)E0,L + (1 − ψ(PL))(E0,L + ∆) and hence ψ(PL)E0,L + (1 − ψ(PL))(E0,L + ∆) ≤ E0,L + 2||BL|| from which we conclude that (1−ψ(PL))≤ 2||BL|| 4f(1)||W||f. ∆ ≤ ∆ If ||W||f is small enough, we get that a = liminfLψ(PL) > 0 and so the alternative a = 0 is indeed excluded. □ Appendix B Appendix to chapter 5 B.1 Representations and states In this section we summarize all the results we need from [11]. Theorem B.1.1. Let ω be a state on a C ∗ -algebra A. It follows that there exists a cyclic representation (Hω , πω , Ωω ) of A such that ω(A) = ⟨Ωω , πω (A)Ωω ⟩ for all A ∈ A. Moreover, the representation is unique up to unitary equivalence. Proof. Theorem 2.3.16 in [11]. We will call this cyclic representation a GNS triple for ω. Corollary B.1.2. Let ω be a state over the C ∗ -algebra A and τ a *- automorphism of A which leaves ω invariant, i.e., ω ◦ τ = ω. Let (Hω , πω , Ωω ) be a GNS triple for ω. It follows that there exists a uniquely determined unitary operator Uω , such that Uω πω (A)Uω† = πω ◦ τ (A) for all A ∈ A, and Uω Ωω = Ωω . 203 If furthermore, ω is pure then (up to a phase) there even exists a unique Uω without requiring the second condition. Proof. The proof of this corollary is a combination of Corollary 2.3.17 and Theorem 2.3.19 from [11]. The following lemma does not come from Bratteli-Robinson but in stead follows from Wigner’s theorem: Lemma B.1.3. Let A and B be arbitrary unital C∗-algebras. Let (HA, πA) and (HB, πB) be arbitrary irreducible ∗-representations on A and B respectively. Let U ∈ U(HA ⊗ HB) be such that there exists an αA ∈ Aut(A) and an αB ∈ Aut(B) satisfying Ad(U) ◦ (πA ⊗ πB) = πA ◦ αA ⊗ πB ◦ αB then there exists aUA ∈ U(HA) and a UB ∈ U(HB) such that U = UA ⊗ UB. Proof. From the assumptions we see that ∀A ∈ A Ad(U) ◦ πA ⊗ πB(A ⊗ 1) = πA ◦ αA(A) ⊗ 1 ⊂ B(HA) ⊗ 1. (B.1.1) (B.1.2) (B.1.3) Since Ad(U) is continuous in weak operator topology (on B(HA ⊗ HB)), it follows that we can extend the map Ad(U)|Im(πA) : Im(πA) ⊗ 1 → B(HA) ⊗ 1 (B.1.4) to the closure in weak operator topology. By irreducibility (and Von Neumanns bicomutant theorem), we get that πA(A)′′ = B(HA) and therefore we get a map Ad(U)|B(HA)⊗1 : B(HA) ⊗ 1 → B(HA) ⊗ 1. (B.1.5) By restriction this gives rise to an automorphism τA : U(HA) → U(HA). By Wigners theorem any automorphism of B(HA) is inner and therefore there exists a UA such that τA = Ad(UA). Doing the same on B gives us similarly a τB and a UB. We now get Ad(U ) ◦ (πA ⊗ πB ) = τA ◦ πA ⊗ τB ◦ πB = Ad(UA ⊗ UB ) ◦ (πA ⊗ πB ). (B.1.6) By the irreducibility of πA ⊗ πB we get that (up to some irrelevant phase) we need that U = UA ⊗ UB concluding the proof. EXISTENCE OF THE PHASES C AND α B.2 Existence of the phases C and α Lemma B.2.1. There exists a C : G2 → U (1) such that KgRAd(Wg) KhRAd WhWg†h)((KgRh)†))uR(g, h) = C(g, h)v†uR(g, h)v ( ( (B.2.1) for all g, h ∈ G. Proof. Since the GNS representation is irreducible this is equivalent to showing that the left and righthandside of equation (5.4.33) have the same adjoint action on the GNS representation. We first prove the result for the full tensor product. By using the definition of u(g, h) we get v†uL(g, h)vv†uR(g, h)v = v†(uL(g, h) ⊗ uR(g, h))v (B.2.2) = v†WgWhWg−h1v. (B.2.3) Now using the definition of Kg gives: (B.2.2) = KgWgv†WhWg−h1v (B.2.4) = KgWgKhWhv†Wg−h1v (B.2.5) = KgWgKhWhWg†hKg†h (B.2.6) = KgWgKhWhWg†hKg†hWghWh†Wg†WgWhWg†h (B.2.7) = KgAd(Wg)(KhAd(WhW g†h)(Kg†h))uL(g, h) ⊗ uR(g, h). (B.2.8) Using lemma 5.4.7 we get that (KgL ⊗ KgR)Ad(Wg) (KhL ⊗ KhR)Ad WhWg†h)((KgLh ⊗ KgRh)−1)) ( ( (B.2.9) = KgLAd(Wg)(KhLAd(WhWg†h)((KgLh)†)) ⊗ KgRAd(Wg)(KhRAd(WhWg†h)((KgRh)†)) (B.2.10) concluding the proof. Lemma B.2.2. There exists an α : G → U(1) satisfying v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)† = α(g)w†KgRw where hg := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(U(−1,−1)(g)). (B.2.11) (B.2.12) Proof. We have that Ad(w†KgRw) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (B.2.13) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν. (B.2.14) Now we will use the fact that because of translation invariance of the group action, we have that τ−1 ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 = βgRL−1 with Lj = {(x, y) ∈ Z2|y j}. This leads to = = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ τ ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν (B.2.15) = Ad(v†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ τ ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ ν. (B.2.16) Inserting bRgvv†(bRg)† now gives = Ad v†bRgvv†(bRg)† ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ τ ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ ν. ( ) (B.2.17) Using the inverse of equation (5.5.10) we now get = Ad(v†bRgv) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ ν−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ τ ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν = Ad(v†bRgv) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ τ ◦ ν−1 ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν. (B.2.18) Now we will use the fact that ν−1 ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ ν = Ad(U(−1,−1)(g)) ◦ βgR,L−1 to obtain = Ad(v†bRgv) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ τ ◦ Ad(U(−1,−1)(g)) ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν. (B.2.19) Since (as you can check in figure 5.3) τ−1(ηRg(τ(U(−1,−1)(g)))) = U(−1,−1)(g) this gives = Ad(v†bRgv) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(U(−1,−1)(g)) ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ τ ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ ν (B.2.20) = Ad(v†bRgvhg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ τ ◦ βgR,L−1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ ν. (B.2.21) Now using again that τ ◦ βgR,L−1 = βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 we get: = Ad(v†bRgvhg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ−1 ◦ ηRg ◦ βgRU ◦ τ ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ ν (B.2.22) = Ad(v†bRgvhgKgR) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηgR ◦ ν−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ ν. (B.2.23) PROPERTIES OF INFINITE TENSOR PRODUCT STATES After again using (5.5.10) we obtain: = Ad(v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ. (B.2.24) By the irreducibility of π0 this implies that there indeed exists such an α. B.3 Properties of infinite tensor product states Lemma B.3.1. Let ω be the infinite tensor product of a state ϕ that satisfies assumption 5.3.3 then ω satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. To show that β˜g exists note that we can take β˜g to be simply βgU . The translation invariance was true by construction. We now only have to find an α ∈ QAut1(A) that satisfies ω = ω0 ◦ α. We define α as the infinite product automorphism of α˜−L1 ⊗ α˜−R1 ◦ Ad(b†). This Automorphism indeed satisfies that ω0 := ω ◦ α−1 (B.3.1) is a product state. This is because for any A ∈ ALi, B ∈ ALj with i ≠ j we have that ω0(A ⊗ B) = ϕ0(A)ϕ0(B). (B.3.2) We will now show that α ∈ QAut1(A). To do this, take 0 < θ < π/2 and let bj be a summable sequence converging to b such that bj ∈ U(ALn0(j)) where n(j) ∈ N is the largest number such that Lnj(j) ⊂ W(Cθ)c. Define Θ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)c) through Θ = ⊗ Ad(b† ) |j| (·,j) . j∈Z Let ασ ∈ Aut(Aσ) be ασ := ⊗(α˜−σ1)(·,j). j∈Z Now define Ṽ1,m := ⊗ τj(b†b|j|). j∈Z∩[−m,m] We will now show that the limit Ṽ1 := lim Ṽ1,m m→∞ (B.3.3) (B.3.4) (B.3.5) (B.3.6) exists (is an element of A). By construction we have that for any ϵ there exists an n0 > 0 such that ϵn := ∑ ∞ ∥b − bi∥ < ϵ (B.3.7) i=n for all n > n0. We will now show that our sequence is a Cauchy sequence. Let ϵ > 0 and take n0 accordingly. For any n, m ≥ n0 we have that ∥∥Ṽ1,n − Ṽ1,m∥ ≤ ∥∥Ṽ1,n − Ṽ1,n0∥ + ∥∥Ṽ1,m − Ṽ1,n0∥ (B.3.8) = ∥∥Ṽ1,nṼ1†,n0 − 1∥ + ∥∥Ṽ1,mṼ1†,n0 − 1∥∥. (B.3.9) We will find a bound on the first therm as the bound of the second therm is analogous. First notice that we have for any tensor product that A ⊗ B − C ⊗ D = (A − C + C) ⊗ B − C ⊗ D = (A − C) ⊗ B + C ⊗ (B − D). (B.3.10) By using this property and the triangle inequality recursively we get ⊗−n0 (b†b|i|)i ⊗ (b†bi)i − 1HL−n,...,−n0 ⊗ 1HLn0,...,n n (B.3.11) ∥i=−n i=n0 ∥ ≤ 2 ∑ ∥∥b†bi − 1HLi ∥∥ < 2ϵ. n (B.3.12) i=n0 This proves that the sequence is a Cauchy sequence and hence the convergence follows. To conclude the proof, we merely have to define V1 := α0(Ṽ1). We then get Ad(V1) ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = α0 ◦ Ad(Ṽ1) ◦ Θ (B.3.13) = ⊗ α˜−01 ◦ Ad(b†b|j|) ◦ Ad(b†|j| ) (B.3.14) j∈Z (·,j ) = ⊗ α˜−01 ◦ Ad(b†)(·,j) (B.3.15) j∈Z = α (B.3.16) concluding the proof. Lemma B.3.2. Let ω be the infinite tensor product of a state ϕ that satisfies assumption 5.3.6 then ω satisfies assumption 5.3.5. SOME PROPERTIES OF ϕ1 AND ϕ2 Proof. The proof of this lemma is analogous to the proof of lemma B.3.1. Since we can take ηg = 1 here the change in support of ηg from lemma 5.3.2 is not an issue. If the one dimensional state is ν invariant, it follows that the infinite product state is as well. This concludes the proof ofthis lemma. B.4 Some properties of ϕ1 and ϕ2 Lemma B.4.1. Let ã = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a) and define the map ϕ1,σ : IACσ(α0, θ, Θ) → U(H) (B.4.1) : x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y↦ → ϕ1(x) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A)ãyã† where A ∈ U(Aσ) and y ∈ Coneσ(α0, θ). This map satisfies that i. for (the unique) ξ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)∩σ) such that Ad(y) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ ξ (B.4.2) we get that Ad(ϕ1,σ(x)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Ad(A) ◦ ξ. (B.4.3) ii. it is well defined (independent of the choice of A and y). iii. it is a group homomorphism. iv. ã†ϕ1(x)ã ∈ IACσ(α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ Φ0D;1). v. if x ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ) then ã†ϕ1(x)ã ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ ◦ ΦU0;1 ⊗ ΦD0;1). Proof. In this proof we take σ = R, the proof when σ = L is equivalent. Take x ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ) arbitrary. Take A ∈ U(AR) and y ∈ ConeR(α0, θ, Θ) such that x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y (B.4.4) and take ξ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ) ∩ AR) the automorphism such that Ad(y) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξ. (B.4.5) Take a and Φ = ΦU ⊗ ΦD as given in equation (5.4.92). We now define ϕ1,R(x) := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A)ãyã†. (B.4.6) We now have to prove three things: i. It satisfies equation (B.4.3). ii. This map is well defined (independent of our choices). iii. This is a group homomorphism. To show the first item just observe that Ad(ϕ1,R(x)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γH1;0split = Ad π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A)π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a)yπ0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a)† ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ( ) = Ad π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ξ ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ( ) . (B.4.7) Now we insert γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = Id and obtain: = Ad π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ (γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0) ( ) (B.4.8) ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ξ ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Ad(A) ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ξ ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split. (B.4.9) Using equation (5.4.92) this gives = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Ad(A) ◦ Φ−1 ◦ ξ ◦ Φ (B.4.10) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Ad(A) ◦ ξ (B.4.11) concluding the proof of the first item. To show the second item, suppose we have two different representatives of x, say x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A1)y1 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A2)y2. (B.4.12) By construction, this implies that π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A†2A1) = y2y†1. (B.4.13) This implies that Ad(A†2A2 ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ)∩R and hence we require that ) ) A†2A1 ∈ U(A′(W(Cθ)∩R)c) = U(AW(Cθ)∩R) (this last equality follows from section 3 of [43]). By using this equation combined with lemma 5.4.21 we get that Ad(ã)(y2y1†) = Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A†2A1) (B.4.14) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†2A1). (B.4.15) Reworking this equation gives the desired ϕ1,R(π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A1)y1) = ϕ1,R(π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A2)y2). (B.4.16) To then show the third item take x1, x2 ∈ IACR(α0, Θ) arbitrary. Take A1, A2 ∈ U(AR), y1, y2 ∈ ConeR(α0, Θ) and ξ1, ξ2 ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ) ∩ AR) such that xi = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Ai)yi Ad(yi) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξi. (B.4.17) We have x1x2 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A1)y1π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A2)y2 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A1)y1π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A2)y†1y1y2 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A1ξ1(A2))y1y2 giving ϕ1,R(x1x2) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A1ξ1(A2))ãy1y2ã†. where ã = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a). Filling this in gives ϕ1,R(x1x2)ϕ1,R(x2)†ϕ1,R(x1)† (B.4.18) (B.4.19) (B.4.20) (B.4.21) (B.4.22) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A1ξ1(A2))ãy1y2ã†ãy†2ã† (B.4.23) π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†2)ãy1†ã†π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†1). Writing out a part of this gives: Ad(ãy1ã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†2) (B.4.24) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ξ1 ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†2). (B.4.25) Using equation (5.4.92) now yields: = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ξ1 ◦ Φ(A†2) (B.4.26) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ Φ ◦ ξ1(A†2) (B.4.27) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ξ1(A†2). (B.4.28) This shows that Ad(ãy1ã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†2) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ξ1(A†2). (B.4.29) Inserting this in equation (B.4.23) shows that ϕ1,R(x1x2)ϕ1,R(x1)†ϕ1,R(x2)† = 1 (B.4.30) concluding the proof of the third item. To show the last two items one only has to work out Ad(ã†ϕ1,R(x)ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (B.4.31) in both situations. Doing this concludes the proof. Lemma B.4.2. Define ϕ1 : IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) → U(H) : ab↦ → ϕ1,L(a)ϕ1,R(b) (B.4.32) where a ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ). This satisfies two points. i. It is well defined, by which we mean that for any a, ã ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and for any b, ˜b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ) such that ab = ã˜b we have that ϕ1,L(a)ϕ1,R(b) = ϕ1,L(ã)ϕ1,R(b˜). (B.4.33) ii. It is still a group homomorphism. Proof. The fist item is trivial, this is because the fact that ab = ãb˜ already implies that (a, b) and (ã, b˜) can only differ up to an exchange in phase. To show the second item, we only have to show that ϕ1,L(a)ϕ1,R(b) = ϕ1,R(b)ϕ1,L(a) (B.4.34) for any a ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ) and for any b ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ). To show this, we first write out b = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(B)yb where B ∈ U(AR) and where yb ∈ ConeR(α0, θ). We can now split the proof in two parts. First we want to prove that Ad(ϕ1,L(a)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(B) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(B). (B.4.35) This can be done using equation (B.4.3). Secondly we want to prove that Ad(ϕ1,L(a))(ϕ1,R(yb)) = (ϕ1,R(yb)). (B.4.36) We can rewrite this equation to Ad(ϕ1,R(yb))(ϕ1,L(a)) = (ϕ1,L(a)). (B.4.37) We now write out a = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)ya with A ∈ U(AL) and ya ∈ ConeL(α0, θ). We again split the proof of this equality in two parts. The equality with the invariance of the A part again uses equation (5.4.99). The equality with the invariance of the ya part can be done by inserting the definition and observing that the ã cancel. Lemma B.4.3. The ϕ1 and ϕ2 defined in lemma 5.4.23 and 5.4.24 satisfy that for any x ∈ IACL×R(α0, θ, Θ) we have that ϕ1(Ad(Wg)(x)) = Ad(ϕ2(Wg))(ϕ1(x)). (B.4.38) If additionally x ∈ IACWL×R(α0,θ,Θ) we get that ϕ1(Ad(v)(x)) = Ad(v)(ϕ1(x)) ϕ1(Ad(v†)(x)) = Ad(v†)(ϕ1(x)). (B.4.39) Proof. Take x ∈ IACR(α0,θ,Θ) arbitrary (the proof for x ∈ IACL(α0,θ,Θ) is analogous). Take A ∈ U(AR) and y ∈ ConeR(α0,θ) such that x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y (B.4.40) and ξ ∈ Aut(ACθ ∩ AR) the automorphism such that Ad(y) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξ. (B.4.41) Take a and Φ as given in equation (5.4.92) and take ã = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(a). We now get WgxWg† = Ad(Wg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)WgyWg† (B.4.42) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηg ◦ βgU(A)WgyWg†. (B.4.43) We still have that WgyWg† ∈ ConeR(α0, θ). This is because there exists a ξ˜ ∈ Aut(ACθ ∩ AR) such that Ad(WgyWg†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξ˜ (B.4.44) (one can just take ξ˜ = ηg ◦ βgU ◦ ξ ◦ βgU−1 ◦ ηg−1). This implies that ϕ1(WgxWg†) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ηg ◦ βgU (A)ãWgyWg†ã†. (B.4.45) Filling this in gives ϕ1(WgxWg†)ϕ2(Wg)ϕ1(x)†ϕ2(Wg)† (B.4.46) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ηg ◦ βgU(A)ãWgyWg†ã† (B.4.47) ãWgã†ãy†ã†π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A)†ãWg†ã†. To prove that this is the identity operator observe that Ad(ãWgã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A) = Ad(ãWg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A) = Ad(ãWg) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Φ(A) (B.4.48) (B.4.49) (B.4.50) = Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ Φ(A) (B.4.51) = Ad(ã) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Φ ◦ ηg ◦ βgU(A) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ Φ ◦ ηg ◦ βgU(A) (B.4.52) (B.4.53) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ηg ◦ βgU(A). (B.4.54) Filling this in equation (B.4.47) concludes the proof of the first item. The proofTake A ∈ U(AR) and y ∈ ConeWR (α0, θ) such that of the second item looks very similar. Now take x ∈ IACWR (α0, θ, Θ) arbitrary. x = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A)y (B.4.55) We now get that (the part with v replaced with v† and τ by τ −1 is equivalent) vxv† = π ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ(A)vyv†. (B.4.56) When we now take ξ˜ = τ ◦ ξ ◦ τ −1 we still obtain an equation of the form Ad(vyv†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξ˜. (B.4.57) This again (in analogy to equation (B.4.45)) implies that we can take ϕ1(vxv†) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ(A)ãvyv†ã†. (B.4.58) Filling this in now gives ϕ1(vxv†)vϕ1(x)†v† (B.4.59) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ(A)ãvyv†ã†vãy†ã†π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A)†v†. (B.4.60) Before we proceed we will first show the equation Ad(ãvyv†ã†vãy†ã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ τ. (B.4.61) To prove this, observe that Ad(ãvyv†ã†vãy†ã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (B.4.62) = Ad(ãvyv†ã†v) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ ξ−1 ◦ Ad(a). (B.4.63) Now inserting equation (5.4.92) in this gives = Ad(ãvyv†ã†v) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ (Φ)−1 ◦ ξ−1 ◦ Φ ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = Ad(ãvyv†ã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ ◦ ξ−1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ τ ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ Ad(a) ◦ τ ◦ ξ ◦ τ−1 ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ ◦ ξ−1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ τ. (B.4.64) Using again equation (5.4.92) now yields: = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Φ−1 ◦ τ ◦ ξ ◦ τ−1 ◦ Φ ◦ τ ◦ ξ−1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ τ (B.4.65) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ ◦ ξ ◦ τ−1 ◦ τ ◦ ξ−1 ◦ τ−1 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ τ (B.4.66) concluding the proof of equation (B.4.61). We will now show that the expression in equation (B.4.60) is the identity. First we will show that the A’s in equation (B.4.60) cancel. By equation (B.4.61) we get that Ad(ãvyv†ã†vãy†ã†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split(A†) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ τ(A†). (B.4.67) Filling this in shows that the A’s cancel. Now, what is left to show is that ãvyv†ã†vãy†ã†v† = 1 (B.4.68) which is equivalent to showing that Ad(y)(v†ã†vã) = v†ã†vã. (B.4.69) To show this, first we use the definitions of these objects to see that this is equivalent to showing that ξ(τ−1(a†)a) = τ−1(a†)a. (B.4.70) However, since Ad(τ−1(a†)a) = τ−1 ◦ Φ ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ τ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Φ−1 = τ−1 ◦ Φ ◦ τ ◦ Φ−1, (B.4.71) we get that τ−1(a†)a ∈ U(AW(Cθ))′ = U(AW(Cθ)c), where the last equality is again because of section 3 in [43]. This concludes the proof of B.4.70 concluding the proof of this lemma. B.5 Some properties of ϕ˜1 and ϕ˜2 We now prove lemma 5.5.23. Lemma B.5.1. The ϕ˜1 and ϕ˜2 defined previously satisfy that for any x ∈ IACσ(α0, θ, Θ) we have that ϕ˜1(Ad(w−pWgwp)(x)) = Ad(ϕ˜2(w−pWgwp))(ϕ˜1(x)) (B.5.1) ϕ˜1(Ad(vs)(x)) = Ad(vs)(ϕ˜1(x)) (B.5.2) ϕ˜2(Ad(vs)(w−pWgwp)) = Ad(vs)(ϕ˜2(w−pWgwp)) (B.5.3) for any p, s ∈ {0, 1}. For the second equation we need the stronger condition that x ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ). Proof. The proof of this lemma is analogous to the proof of lemma B.4.3. The only difference is that now the Wg is generalized to w−pWgwp. This is possible because the support of ηg is smaller in assumption 5.3.5 then it is in assumption 5.3.2 and therefore everything still splits and therefore, everything is still well defined. We now prove lemma 5.5.25. Lemma B.5.2. Define aL := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AL) aR := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(AR) (B.5.4) with Aσ as defined in lemma 5.5.24. For any K ∈ ConeL×ν(R)(α0, θ) we get that w†ϕ˜1(K)w = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR K a†L ⊗ a†R w). (B.5.5) Similarly we have that w†ϕ˜2(Wg)w = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR w)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw)ϕ˜1(w† a†L ⊗ a†R w). (B.5.6) Proof. We will only show the first equality as the second one is completely analogous. We need to show that ϕ˜1(K) = Ad(wϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRw))(ϕ˜1(w†Kw)) (B.5.7) = Ad(wϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRw))(ãw†Kwã†) (B.5.8) = Ad(wϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRw))(ãw†ã†ϕ˜1(K)ã†wã†) (B.5.9) = Ad(wϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRw)w†(wãw†ã†))(ϕ˜1(K)). (B.5.10) To do this, we first find an A ∈ U (A) such that π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split(A) = wϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRw)w†(wãw†ã†) (B.5.11) and then we will prove that A ∈ U(AW(Cθ)c). It should be clear that the result follows from this1. Finding this A can be done by working out wϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRw)w†(wãw†ã†) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(ν ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1(AL ⊗ AR)ν(a)a†). (B.5.13) First we insert γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = Id to obtain = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0(ν ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1(AL ⊗ AR)ν(a)a†). (B.5.14) Using the fact that H is translation invariant allows us to cancel it giving = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split(γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ ν ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1(AL ⊗ AR)γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0(ν(a)a†)) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split(γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1(AL ⊗ AR)γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0(ν(a)a†)). (B.5.15) This shows that we can take A := γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1(AL ⊗ AR)γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0(ν(a)a†). (B.5.16) Now we only have to show that indeed A ∈ U(AW(Cθ)c). To do this, take X ∈ AW(Cθ) arbitrary. If we can show that Ad(A)(X) = X for any such X 1This is most easily seen from Ad(ϕ˜1(K))◦π0◦α0◦Θ◦γ0H;1◦γ1H˜;0split(A)=ϕ˜1(Ad(K)◦π0◦α0◦Θ(A))=ϕ˜1(π0◦α0◦Θ(A))=π0◦α0◦Θ◦γH0;1◦γ1H˜;0split(A). (B.5.12) then we get that A ∈ U(A′W(Cθ) ). Since by corollary 3.1 of [43] we get that U(A′W(Cθ)) = U(AW(Cθ)c) this is sufficient to conclude the proof. To show this, observe that Ad(A)(X) = γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1 ◦ Ad(AL ⊗ AR) ◦ ν ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν−1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ γ0H˜;1split (B.5.17) ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ ν ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ν−1 ◦ Ad(a†) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split(X) where the cancellation is done using the fact that H is translation invariant. Using equation (5.5.86) we obtain Ad(A)(X ) = (⊗ Φµν )−1 ◦ ν ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ H1;0 ◦ Ad(a) ◦ ν −1 ◦ Ad(a† ) ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split (X ). µν (B.5.18) Now using equation (5.5.68) we get Ad(A)(X ) = (⊗ Φµν )−1 ◦ ν ◦ (ΦU ⊗ ΦD )−1 ◦ ν −1 ◦ ΦU ⊗ ΦD (X ) = X µν (B.5.19) concluding the proof. We will now prove a small lemma that we will need to prove lemma 5.5.26. Lemma B.5.3. For all σ ∈ {L, R}, the following equality holds: Ad(Wg)(a†σvaσv†) = a†σvaσv†. (B.5.20) Proof. We will prove this equality in two steps. First we will find some Bσ ∈ U (A) such that π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Bσ) = a†σvaσv† (B.5.21) ηg) and that βgU(Bσ) = Bσ (concluding the proof of being invariant underthen we will show that Bσ ∈ A(W(Cθ)∩σ)c (his already proves invarianceunder ηg ◦ βgU). To find Bσ, we write out aσ†vaσv† = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(A†στ(Aσ)) (B.5.22) and observe that we can take Bσ := A†στ(Aσ). Now we will prove that Bσ ∈ U(ACθc∩σ) = U(A′(Cθc∩σ)c). Take X ∈ A(Cθc∩σ)c arbitrary. Using equation (5.5.86) we have that Ad(BL ⊗ BR)(X) = Ad(A†L ⊗ A†R) ◦ τ ◦ Ad(AL ⊗ AR) ◦ τ−1(X) (B.5.23) = ⊗ Φµν ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1 (B.5.24) µν ◦ τ ◦ ν ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν −1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (⊗ Φµν )−1 ◦ τ −1 (X ) µν = X (B.5.25) concluding the proof. The fact that Ad(βgU(Bσ)) = Ad(Bσ) follows from this same equation as well. This already shows that that there exists a G-dependent phase α(g) such that βgU(Bσ)Bσ† = α(g)1A. To show that α(g) = 1 we have to use two things. First, we use the fact that α has to be a U(1)-representation. Secondly, because we can make this construction for every λ (I mean the λ from lemma 5.5.24) we need that α must be connected to the trivial U(1)- representation through a continuous path. However, because our group is finite we can use lemma B.8.4 to conclude that α is trivial an hence the result follows. We now provide a proof of lemma 5.5.26. Lemma B.5.4. Define ϵLg ∈ IACL(α0, θ) and ϵRg ∈ IACR(α0, θ) through ϵgσ := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1(Aσ ηgσ ◦ βgUσ(A†σ)) (B.5.26) (where Aσ was defined in lemma 5.5.24) then w†ϕ˜2(Wg)w = ϕ˜1(ϵLg ⊗ ϵRg)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw) (B.5.27) w†ϕ˜1(Kgσ)w = v†ϕ˜1(ϵσg)vϕ˜1(w†Kgσw)ϕ˜1(ϵσg)†. (B.5.28) Proof. By equation (5.5.89) we get that w†ϕ˜2(Wg)w = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR w)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw)ϕ˜1(w† a†L ⊗ a†R w) (B.5.29) = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR w)Ad(ϕ˜2(w†Wgw))(ϕ˜1(w† a†L ⊗ a†R w))ϕ˜2(w†Wgw). (B.5.30) Using result 2 and 3 of lemma 5.5.23 on this now gives = ϕ˜1(w† aL ⊗ aR Ad(Wg)(a†L ⊗ a†R)w)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw) (B.5.31) = ϕ˜1(w†aLAd(Wg)(a†L) ⊗ aRAd(Wg)(a†R)w)ϕ˜2(w†Wgw). (B.5.32) Since aσAd(Wg)(a†σ) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ(Aσηgσ ◦ βgσU(A†σ)) w†aσAd(Wg)(a†σ)w = ϵσg (B.5.33) (B.5.34) the first result follows. For the second result we start by using equation (5.5.88) which gives us w†ϕ˜1(Kgσ)w = ϕ˜1(w†aL ⊗ aRKgσa†L ⊗ a†Rw) = ϕ˜1(w†aσKgσa†σw). Inserting v†Wgva†σaσv†Wg†v = 1 in this gives us (B.5.35) (B.5.36) = ϕ˜1 (w†aσ Ad(v†Wg v)(a†σ aσ )Kgσ a†σ w) (B.5.37) = ϕ˜1 (w†aσ Ad(v†Wg v)(a†σ )Kgσ Ad((Kgσ )†v†Wg v)(aσ )a†σ w). (B.5.38) We now use the fact that KgWg = v†Wgv to get = ϕ˜1(w†aσAd(v†Wgv)(a†σ)KgσAd(Wg)(aσ)a†σw) = ϕ˜1(w†aσAd(v†Wgv)(a†σ)Kgσ(ϵσg)†w). (B.5.39) (B.5.40) Inserting ww† in this and using the second result of lemma 5.5.23 gives = ϕ˜1(w†aσAd(v†Wgv)(a†σ)ww†Kgσww†(ϵσg)†w) (B.5.41) = ϕ˜1(w†aσAd(v†Wgv)(a†σ)w)ϕ˜1(w†Kgσw)ϕ˜1(w†(ϵσg)†w) (B.5.42) = v†ϕ˜1(vw†aσAd(v†Wgv)(a†σ)wv†)vϕ˜1(w†Kgσw)ϕ˜1(w†(ϵσg)†w). (B.5.43) The only thing we now have to prove is that aσAd(v†Wgv)(a†σ) = v†aσAd(Wg)(a†σ)v = v†wϵσgw†v (B.5.44) since inserting this, concludes the proof. To do this notice that we can rewrite equation (B.5.44) as Ad(v†Wgv)(v†a†σvaσ) = v†a†σvaσ. (B.5.45) This equality is proven in lemmaB.5.3. PROOF OF LEMMA ?? B.6 Proof of lemma 5.3.13 In this section we prove lemma 5.3.13: Proof. We will only prove the first item as all the other proofs are analogous. First notice that the equivalence implies that there exist product states ϕ1 ∈ P(Ã1) and ϕ2 ∈ P(Ã2) and group actions Ũ1 and Ũ2 such that the combinations (ϕ1, Ũ1) and (ϕ2, Ũ2) are trivial (see 5.2.2 for what this means). Moreover these will satisfy that there exists a unitary transformation of the on site Hilbert space, V such that ω1 ⊗stack ϕ1 ◦ iV = ω2 ⊗stack ϕ2 ◦ γ0Φ;1 V †U1(g) ⊗ Ũ1(g)V = U2(g) ⊗ Ũ2(g) (B.6.1) for some G-invariant locally generated automorphism. Using item 1 and item 3 of 5.3.14 this implies that IndexAno1⊗trsatnacskÃ1,U1⊗Ũ1(ω1 ⊗ stackϕ1) = IndexAno2⊗trsatnacskÃ2,U2⊗Ũ2(ω2⊗stackϕ2). (B.6.2) Using item 2 of 5.3.14 this is satisfied if IndexÃno1,tŨra1ns(ϕ1) = IndexÃno2,tŨra2ns(ϕ2) = 1. (B.6.3) This is trivially true. Only in the last part with the H1-valued index does one need that the (ϕ,Ũ) pairs are trivial (see remark 5.5.11). For the other three statements it is enough that we have G-invariant product states. B.7 Some calculations with cochains Lemma B.7.1. The three-cochain C′(g, h, k) defined through uR(g, h)uR(gh, k)uR(g, hk)†Ad(Wg)(uR(h, k)†) = C′(g, h, k)1. (B.7.1) is invariant under the substitution Wg → KgWg uR(g, h) → KgRAd(Wg) KhRAd WhWg†h)((KgRh)†))uR(g, h) ( ( (B.7.2) Proof. Lemma B.7.2. Take ω0, θ, α0, Θ and ηg as usual, take v, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h) and Kgσ,1 the operators corresponding to these automorphisms and take SOME CALCULATIONS WITH COCHAINS δgσ ∈ IACWσ (α0, θ, Θ) (for all σ ∈ {L, R} and all g ∈ G). Proof. First we will prove that we still have that uL,2(g, h)uR,2(g, h) = Wgh,2Wh†,2Wg†,2.
