(B.7.32) Using the fact that by definition Kg,1Wg,1 = v†Wg,1v we obtain C2(g, h) = C1(g, h)v†δgRWg,1δRhWg†,1Wg,1(δRh)†Wg†,1(δRg)†v = C1(g, h) concluding the proof. (B.7.33) (B.7.34) SOME CALCULATIONS WITH COCHAINS Lemma B.7.3. The two-cochain as defined through KgRWgKhRWhWg†h(KgRh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h) = C(g, h)v†uR(g, h)v. (B.7.35) is invariant under the substitution Kg↦R → v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)† Wg↦ → w†Wgw uR(g, h)↦ → w†uR(g, h)w. (B.7.36) Proof. To show this, notice that we have by construction and by lemma 5.5.7 that Ad(bgWg) ◦ π0 = Ad(w†Wgw) ◦ π0 (B.7.37) Ad bRgWgbRhWhWg†h(bRgh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h) ◦ π0 = Ad(w†uR(g, h)w) ◦ π0. ( ) (B.7.38) This shows that there exists a β : G → U (1) and a γ : G × G → U (1) such that w†Wgw = β(g)bLgbRgWg w†uR(g, h)w = γ(g, h)bRgWgbRhWhWg†h(bRgh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h). (B.7.39) Since the equation is clearly invariant under the substitution with these two phases all that is left to do is to show that equation (B.7.35) is invariant under the substitution: Kg↦R → v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)† = v†bRgvKgR(bRg)†hg Wg↦ → bLgbRgWg (B.7.40) uR(g, h)↦ → bRgWgbRhWhWg†h(bRgh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h). (B.7.41) To show this first notice that by using the fact that hg ∈ IACR(θ, α0, Θ)′ and lemma 5.5.6 we get that KgRWgKhRWhWg†h(KgRh)† (B.7.42) →↦ v†bRgvhgKgR(bRg)†bLgbRgWgv†bRhvhhKhR(bRh)†bLhbRhWhWg†h(bLghbRgh)†(v†bRghvhghKgRh(bRgh)†)† (B.7.43) = hghhh†ghv†bRgvKgR(bRg)†bLgbRgWgv†bRhvKhR(bRh)†bLhbRhWhWg†h(bLghbRgh)†(v†bRghvKgRh(bgRh)†)† (B.7.44) (all the h−operators can be put in front). Since hg is an honest representation we get that the h−operators cancel out. This leaves us with checking that equation (B.7.35) is invariant under Kg↦R → v†bRgvKgR(bRg)† Wg↦ → bLgbRgWg uR(g, h)↦ → bRgWgbRhWhWg†h(bRgh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h). Using the fact that (bRgh)†WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h) = (bRgh)†uL(g, h)† = uL(g, h)†(bRgh)† = WghWh†Wg†uR(g, h)(bRgh)† (B.7.45) (B.7.46) (B.7.47) (B.7.48) we see that we can prove that our equation is invariant under the substitution using lemma B.7.2. This concludes the proof. Lemma B.7.4. Take ω0, θ, α0, Θ and ηg as usual, take v, w, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h), Kgσ,1 and bσg,1 operators corresponding to these automorphisms and take δσg ∈ IACνσ(σ)(α0, Θ, θ) (for all σ ∈ {L, R} and all g ∈ G). Define Wg,2 := δgWg,1 uσ,2(g, h) := δgσWg,1δhσWg†,1uσ,1(g, h)(δσgh)† Kgσ,2 := v†δgσvKgσ,1(δσg)† (B.7.49) (B.7.50) (B.7.51) bgσ,2 := w†δgσwbσg,1(δgσ)† (B.7.52) then the index of v, w, Wg,1, uσ,1(g, h), Kgσ,1, hg and bσg,1 is equal to the index of v, w, Wg,2, uσ,2(g, h), hg, Kgσ,2 and bσg,2. The one cochain also remains unchanged. Proof. We define the index in function of the new variables: α2(g) := v†bRg,2vhgKgR,2(bR2,g)†w†(K2R,g)†w = v†(w†δRgwbRg,1(δgR)†)vhg(v†δgRvKgR,1(δgR)†)(w†δRgwbgR,1(δgR)†)† w†(v†δgRvKgR,1(δgR)†)†w (B.7.53) (B.7.54) = v†w†δgRwbRg,1(δRg)†vhgv†δRgvKgR,1(δRg)†δRg(bR1,g)†w†(δgR)†ww†δgR(KgR,1)†v†(δgR)†vw. (B.7.55) TRANSLATION INVARIANCE IN ONE DIMENSION If we now insert vv†, we obtain α2(g) = v†w†δgRwbRg,1vv†(δgR)†vhgv†δgRvKgR,1(bR1,g)†w†(KgR,1)†v†(δgR)†vw (B.7.56) where the cancelation is due to the fact that v†δgRv ∈ IACR(α0, θ, Θ) whereas hg ∈ IACL(α0, θ, Θ). Again after inserting vv† and ww† we now get α2(g) = v†w†δgRwvv†bRg,1vhgKgR,1(bR1,g)†w†(KgR,1)†ww†v†(δgR)†vw = v†w†δgRwvα1(g)w†v†(δRg)†vw = α1(g) concluding the proof. (B.7.57) (B.7.58) (B.7.59) B.8 Translation invariance in one dimension Let B be the quasi local C∗ algebra defined with on the one dimensional lattice. Let Ui ∈ hom(G,U(Ai)) (for i ∈ Z) be the on site group action. Let βg bewill look at states satisfying the split property. We say that ω ∈ P(B) satisfiesagain so that for each finite I ⊂ Z, βgI = Ad(⊗i∈I Ui(g)). In this section, wethe split property iff. it is quasi equivalent to ω|L ⊗ ω|R. This implies that there exists a GNS triple of ω that is of the form (H = HL ⊗ HR, π = πL ⊗ πR, Ω). (B.8.1) We will denote the space of pure states satisfying the split property by SP(A). Now let us additionally ask that ω is invariant under the group action (ω◦βg = ω). The following now holds: Lemma B.8.1. There exist maps uσ : G → U(Hσ) (for all σ ∈ {L,R}) satisfying Ad(uσ(g)) ◦ πσ = πσ ◦ βgσ uL(g) ⊗ uR(g)Ω = Ω. (B.8.2) They are unique up to a G-dependent phase. Proof. See [47]. This can now be used to define the one dimensional SPT index: Lemma B.8.2. There exists a 2-cochain C : G2 → U (1) that satisfies uR(g)uR(h)uR(gh)† = C(g,h)1HR uL(g)uL(h)uL(gh)† = C(g,h)−11HL. (B.8.3) Its second group cohomology class is independent of the choice of GNS triple or the choice of (a G-dependent) phase in uR(g). This index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms generated by G-invariant interactions. Proof. Again see [47]. Now let us assume additionally (on top of the split property and the G-invariance) that ω be translation invariant. To this end, let ν be the automorphism that translates B by one site to the right. We assume that ω ◦ ν = ω. The following now holds: Lemma B.8.3. There exists a unique w ∈ U (H) such that Ad(w) ◦ π = π ◦ ν wΩ = Ω. (B.8.4) Proof. Since ω ◦ ν = ω, we get that (H, π ◦ ν, Ω) ∼ (H, π, Ω). (B.8.5) u.e. The uniqueness of the GNS triple now implies the existence of this w. Its uniqueness follows from the irreducibility of π. We can use this to define an additional 1d index for translation invariant states. To do this, we will need to use the finiteness of the group explicitly. We will use one particular property of this, namely that finite groups have discrete U(1) representations. By this we mean the following: Lemma B.8.4. Let G be a finite group. There exists an ϵ > 0 such that for all α ∈ hom(G, U (1)), min |α(g) − 1| < ϵ (B.8.6) g∈G\1 holds if and only if α = 1. Proof. We can simply take ϵ := |exp(2πi/|G|) − 1| (B.8.7) TRANSLATION INVARIANCE IN ONE DIMENSION where |G| is the amount of group elements. This is because if we assume that this minimum is smaller then ϵ for some α ∈ hom(G, U (1)), we can reach a contradiction. Namely, let g ∈ G be the group element that gives the minimum. For all n ∈ ∩ [1, |G| + 1], we get that all of the α(g)n need to be different. This implies that multiplying g, n times needs to be different for each n but N this is impossible since there are only |G| group elements. Lemma B.8.5. There exists a (unique) α ∈ hom(G, U (1)) satisfying that π(U−1(g))(1HL ⊗ uR(g)) = α(g)w†(1HL ⊗ uR(g))w. (B.8.8) This index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms generated by one parameter families of interactions in BFϕ([0,1]) (with Fϕ as presented in (5.2.17)) that are both G and translation invariant. Proof. The fact that α exists follows from the fact that π is irreducible and combined with the fact that Ad(π(U−1(g))(1HL ⊗ uR(g))) ◦ π = Ad(w†(1HL ⊗ uR(g))w) ◦ π = π ◦ βg[−1,∞[. (B.8.9) The fact that α is a U(1)−representation follows from the fact that uR is the lift of a projective representation. Suppose that uR(g)uR(h) = C(g,h)uR(gh) then π(U−1(g))(1HL ⊗ uR(g))π(U−1(h))(1HL ⊗ uR(h)) = C(g, h)π(U−1(gh))(1HL ⊗ uR(gh)) (B.8.10) on the one hand whereas w†(1HL ⊗ uR(g))ww†(1HL ⊗ uR(h))w = C(g, h)w†(1HL ⊗ uR(gh))w. (B.8.11) These two equations can only be consistent if α(g)α(h) = α(gh). The proof that this is independent of the choice of GNS triple is straightforward. Now we need to show that this index is invariant under LGA’s generated by G-invariant interactions. To this end let Fϕ be our F-function from equation (5.2.17). Let Φ ∈ BFϕ([0, 1]) be a G-invariant, translation invariant interaction. For simplicity of notation let Φsplit = Φν−1(L) + Φν(R). Let λ ∈ [0, 1]↦ → Aλ ∈ U(A) be a norm continuous one parameter family such that γ0Φ;λ = Ad(Aλ) ◦ γ0Φ;sλplit A0 = 1A. (B.8.12) and define A := A1. This exists because of lemma B.9.1. By construction (H, π ◦ γ0Φ;s1plit, π(A†)Ω) is a GNS triple of ω ◦ γ0Φ;1. Let w˜ := π(A†)wπ(A) then α˜(g) := π(U−1(g))uR(g)w˜†uR(g)†w˜ (B.8.13) is the index of ω ◦ γ0Φ;1. Working this out gives α˜(g) = π(U−1(g))uR(g)π(A†)w†π(A)uR(g)†π(A†)wπ(A) (B.8.14) = π(U−1(g))uR(g)w†π(ν(A†)A)uR(g)†π(A†ν(A))w (B.8.15) = π(U−1(g))uR(g)w†uR(g)†π ◦ βgR(ν(A†)A)π(A†ν(A))w (B.8.16) = α(g)w†π ◦ βgR(ν(A†)A)π(A†ν(A))w. (B.8.17) This shows that we conclude the proof if we can show that βgR(ν(A†)A) = ν(A†)A. (B.8.18) We will do this proof in two steps. The first step is that we prove that Ad(βgR(ν(A†)A)) = Ad(ν(A†)A). (B.8.19) We use the first equation of (B.8.12) and obtain Ad(βgR(ν(A†)A)) = βgR ◦ Ad(ν(A†)A) ◦ (βgR)−1 (B.8.20) = βgR ◦ ν ◦ γ0Φ;s1plit ◦ γ1Φ;0 ◦ ν−1 ◦ γ0Φ;1 ◦ γ1Φ;s0plit ◦ (βgR)−1 (B.8.21) = βgR ◦ γ0ν;(1Φsplit) ◦ γ1Φ;s0plit ◦ (βgR)−1 (B.8.22) = Ad(ν(A†)A). (B.8.23) This shows that there exists some α′ ∈ hom(G, U (1)) such that α′(g) = βgR(ν(A†)A)(A†ν(A)). (B.8.24) However since this has to hold for each λ ∈ [0, 1] we can define for each λ some αλ ∈ hom(G, U (1)) through αλ(g) = βgR(ν(A†λ)Aλ)(A†λν(Aλ)). (B.8.25) This implies that α′(g) = α1(g) has to be connected to α0(g) = 1. Now we will use that the U(1) representations of a finite group are discrete. More specifically we will use lemma B.8.4. This implies that α′(g) = 1 for all g ∈ G in our case (as we can just use lemma B.8.4 as many times as needed and obtain that λ↦ → αλ(g) is constant for all g ∈ G). All together we constructed a proof of the following theorem: PROPERTIES OF LOCALLY GENERATED AUTOMORPHISMS: 1D Theorem B.8.6. There exist maps Index1d : {ω ∈ S P (A)|ω ◦ βg = ω} → H 2(G, T) (B.8.26) Index1d trans : {ω ∈ SP(A)|ω ◦ βg = ω and ω ◦ ν = ω} → H1(G, T) ∼= hom(G, T). (B.8.27) For any G−invariant family of interactions Φ ∈ BF ([0, 1]), we have that Index1d(ω) = Index1d(ω ◦ γ0Φ;1). For any G−invariant family of interactions Φ′ ∈ BF ([0, 1]) that is also translation invariant, we have that Index1d trans(ω) = Index1d trans(ω ◦ γ0Φ;′1). B.9 Properties of locally generated automorphisms: 1d In this section, let A be a quasi local C∗ algebra over Z . Lemma B.9.1. Take Φ ∈ BFϕ ([0, 1]) (with Fϕ as presented in (5.2.17)) then there exists an A ∈ U (A) satisfying Ad(A) = γ0Φ;L1+ΦR ◦ γ1Φ;0. (B.9.1) Moreover, this A is summable (this was defined in subsection 5.2.1). More generally there exists a continuous (in norm topology) one parameter family λ ∈ [0, 1]↦ → Aλ ∈ U (A) such that Aλ is summable for each λ and such that Ad(Aλ) = γ0Φ;Lλ+ΦR ◦ γλΦ;0. (B.9.2) Proof. We have for any B ∈ A that γΦ0;Lt+ΦR ◦ γΦt;0(B) = B + dsds γ0Φ;Ls+ΦR ◦ γsΦ;0(B) ∫ t d ( ) 0 =B−i∫ tds ∑ γΦ0;Ls+ΦR([ΦL(s,I)+ΦR(s,I)−Φ(s,I),γsΦ;0(B)]) 0 I ∈GZ ]) =B−i dsγ0Φ;Ls+ΦR◦γsΦ;0 ∑ γ0Φ;s(ΦL(s,I)+ΦR(s,I)−Φ(s,I)),B ∫ t ([ . 0 I ∈GZ (B.9.3) To simplify notation we will define an interaction Φ˜(s, I) = ΦL(s, I) + ΦR(s, I) − Φ(s, I). (B.9.4) We will in essence have to find a 1D analogue of the proof of Theorem 5.2 of [48] with a few exceptions. Most notably we need the summability condition. First let us still define the extensions and X(m) := {x ∈ Z|∃y ∈ X : dist(x,y) ≤ m} (B.9.5) ∆ X(m) := ΠX(m) − ΠX(m−1) (B.9.6) the differences between the conditional expectation values. Define an interaction Ξ(Z, t) := ∑ ∑ ∆ X(m)(γ0Φ;t(Φ˜(X, t))) (B.9.7) m≥0 X⊂Z: X(m)=Z then we get by construction that γ0Φ;Lt+ΦR ◦ γtΦ;0 = γ0Ξ;t. We will now define Aλ := T exp −i ds ∑ Ξ(Z, s) . ( ∫ λ ) 0 Z∈BZ (B.9.8) (B.9.9) By construction if this exists it is continuous in λ. To show that it exists and is summable, define some sets Bn := [−n, n] ∩ Z Bn,L :=] − ∞, −n] ∩ Z Bn,R := [n, ∞[∩Z (B.9.10) and let An := T exp −i ds ∑ ΞBn (Z, s) . ( ∫ 1 ) (B.9.11) 0 Z ∈BZ In what follows we will find a bound on cn := sup ∑ (Ξ(Z, t) − ΞBn(Z, t)) (B.9.12) t∈[0,1] ∥Z∈BZ ∥ that is summable. Finding this would conclude the proof because ∑ ∥A − An∥ = ∑ ∥∫01 ds ds d An(s)†A(s) ≤∑ sup ∑ (Ξ(Z,t)−ΞBn(Z,t)) =∑cn. n n ∥ n t∈[0,1]∥Z∈BZ ∥ n (B.9.13) In analogy with equation (5.22) of [48] we get cn ≤ ∑ sup ∥Ξ(Z, t)∥ (B.9.14) Z∈BZ: t∈[0,1] Z∩Bn,L≠∅ or Z∩Bn,R≠∅ ≤ 8 (e2IF (Φ) − 1) ∑ ∑ cF sup (∥∥Φ˜(X,t)∥)|X|GF(m). (B.9.15) m≥0 X∈BZ: t∈[0,1] X(m)∩Bn,L≠∅ or X(m)∩Bn,R≠∅ Now using a trick analogous to what was done in equation (5.27) of [48] we get ⎛ ⎞ cn ≤ ∥Φ1∥F ⎝ ∑ GF (m)⎠( ∑ ∑ F (d(x, y)) + ∑ ∑ F (d(x, y))). m≥0 x∈Bn,L y=B0,R x∈B0,L y=Bn,R (B.9.16) To show that the last bound is summable we only have to observe that ∑∑ ∑ ∞ F (d(x, y)) ≤ ∑ ∑ F (d(x, y)). (B.9.17) n=0 x∈Bn,L y=B0,R x∈C1 y=C2 where C1 is the cone one obtains by putting the Bn,L on top of each other whereas C2 is the right half plane of Z2. The proof that the sum over the cones is bounded is done explicitly in [48]. B.10 Properties of locally generated automor- phisms: 2d In this section, let A be a quasi local C∗ algebra over Z2. Take H ∈ BFϕ([0, 1]) (for some 0 < ϕ < 1) and γsH;t its locally generated automorphism (see section 5.2.3). We will now show some properties of this locally generated automorphism γsH;t. In this section we will heavily rely on the framework and theorems of Yosiko Ogata [48] who in her turn relies heavily on the framework developed in [44]. We will use the notation C[0,θ] := Cθ C]θ1,θ2] := Cθ2/Cθ1 C]θ,π/2] := Z2/Cθ (B.10.1) where 0 < θ < π/2 and 0 < θ1 < θ2 < π2. Figure B.1: This figure shows the support of the different automorphisms present in the decomposition of an SQ1-automorphism acting on the upper half plane. B.10.1 The one translation symmetry This section will define the classes of automorphisms required in the assumptions and proofs about the H2-valued translation index. In analogy with section 2.1 from [48] we will define some classes of automorphisms (see figure B.1): Definition B.10.1. Take α ∈ Aut(A). We say that α ∈ SQAut1(A) if and only if for any 0 <θ0.8 < θ1 < θ1.2 < θ1.8 < θ2 < θ2.2 < θ2.8 θ3 < θ3.2 < π/2 there exist a ∈ A, α[0,θ1],σ ∈ Aut AC[0,θ1]∩σ , α]θ1,θ2],σ,ρ ∈ ( ) < Aut AC]θ1,θ2]∩ρ∩σ , α]θ2,θ3],σ,ρ ∈ Aut A(W(C[0,θ3])/C[0,θ2])∩ρ∩σ) ,α]θ3,π/2],ρ ( ) ( ) ∈ Aut Aτρ(C[θ3,π/2]∩ρ) , α]θ0.8,θ1.2],σ,ρ ∈ Aut AC]θ0.8,θ1.2]∩ρ∩σ , α]θ1.8,θ2.2],σ,ρ ( ) ( ) ∈ Aut(AC]θ1.8 ) ,θ2.2]∩ρ∩σ and α]θ2.8,θ3.2],σ,ρ ∈ Aut(τρ(AC]θ2.8,θ3.2]∩ρ∩σ ) ) for any ρ ∈ {U,D} and σ ∈ {L,R} (here τU = τ and τD = τ−1) such that α = Ad(a) ◦ ⊗ α[0,θ1],σ ◦ ⊗ α]θ1,θ2],σ,ρ ◦ ⊗ α[θ3,π/2] ◦ ⊗(α]θ0.8,θ1.2],ρ,σ ⊗ α]θ1.8,θ2.2],ρ,σ ⊗ α]θ2.8,θ3.2],ρ,σ). σ σ,ρ ρ ρ,σ (B.10.2) If additionally everything (except a) commutes with βgU we say that α ∈ GSQAut1(A). As a remark, notice that this definition is not exactly identical to de definition given in [48] due to the translation operators. Definition B.10.2. Take α ∈ Aut(A). We say that α ∈ HAut1(A) if and only if for any 0 < θ < π/2 there exists an a ∈ A and some ασ ∈ Aut(ACθ ∩ Aσ) for each σ ∈ {L, R} such that α = Ad(a) ◦ αL ⊗ αR. (B.10.3) We will need one additional class of automorphisms: Definition B.10.3. Take α ∈ Aut(A). We say that α ∈ VAut1(A) if and only if there exists some a ∈ A, αU ∈ Aut τ(ACθc ∩ AU) and an αD ( ) ∈ Aut τ−1(ACθc ∩ AD) such that ( ) α = Ad(a) ◦ αU ⊗ αD. (B.10.4) If furthermore αU ◦ βgU = βgU ◦ αU we say that α ∈ GVAut1(A). Now we will state some properties of locally generated automorphisms: Lemma B.10.4. Take H an interaction such that there exists a 0 < ϕ < 1 satisfying that ∥H∥fϕ ≤ 1. The following statements now hold (for any s, t ∈ R): i. γsH;t ◦ γtH;sD ⊗ γtH;sU ∈ HAut1(A). ii. γsH;t◦γtH;sL ⊗γtH;sR ∈ VAut1(A). If additionally H is a G-invariant interaction we even have γsH;t ◦ γtH;sL ⊗ γtH;sR ∈ GVQAut1(A). iii. γsH;tU ⊗ γsH;tD ∈ SQAut1(A). If additionally H is a G-invariant interaction we even have γsH;tU ⊗ γsH;tD ∈ GSQAut1(A). iv. If H is G-invariant then γtH;s ◦ βgU ◦ γsH;t ◦ (βgU )−1 ∈ HAut1(A). v. γtH;s ∈ SQAut1(A). Proof. Part 1 is done in Proposition 5.5 in [48] and part 4 follows trivially from Part 1. Except for the translation operators in my definition of the SQAut(A), part 3 follows from Theorem 5.2 in [48]. To show part 3 we therefore have to show that Theorem 5.2 in [48] still holds if we replace C0 and C1 in the proof by C0 := {C[0,θ1],σ, C]θ1,θ2],σ,ρ, C]θ2,θ3],σ,ρ ∪ τρ(C]θ2,θ3],σ,ρ), τρ(C]θ3,π/2],ρ)|σ = {L, R}, ρ = {U, D}} C1 := {C[θ0.8,θ1.2]∩σ∩τ, C[θ1.8,θ2.2]∩σ∩τ, τρ(C[θ2.8,θ3.2]∩σ∩ρ)|σ = {L, R}, ρ = {U, D}}. (B.10.5) Take the Ψ from this proof to be our H, take Ψ(0) to be ∑C∈C0 H C (with our new definition of C0) and take Ψ(1) := Ψ − Ψ(0). Now define Ξ(s)(Z, t) through Ξ(s)(Z, t) := ∑ ∑ X(m)(γsΨ;t(Ψ(1)(X; t))) ∞ ∆ (B.10.6) m=0 X⊂Z, X(m)=Zwith these new definitions of Ψ(0) and Ψ(1). We now want so show that for every t, ∑ Ξ(s)(Z, t) − ∑ 1Z⊂CΞ(s)(Z, t) ( ) (B.10.7) Z⊂Z2 C∈C1 is bounded. Following the arguments in equation (5.22) to (5.24) in [48] we still get that ∑ sup ∥Ξ(1) Z⊂Z2, t∈[0,1] ∥ (Z, t)∥ ≤ CF (e2IF (Ψ) − 1) ∑ 8 M (C1, C2) (B.10.8) C1,C2∈C0, ∄C∈C1:Z⊂C C1 ≠C2 where M(C1,C2):= ∑ ∑ ( ) m≥0 X: t∈su[0p,1](∥∥Ψ(1)(X; t)∥∥)|X|GF (m) ∀C∈C1,X∩((Cc)(m))≠∅, X∩C1≠∅,X∩C2≠∅ (B.10.9) is now defined using the new C1. To bound these M(C1,C2) we will (just like in [48]) differentiate between two cases. That is, the case where C1 and C2 are adjacent2 and the case where they are not. We begin with the latter. In this case we still have in complete analogy with the proof in [48] that M(C1,C2)≤b0(C1,C2):= ∑ ∑ ( ) sup (∥∥Ψ(1) (X ; t)∥∥)|X |GF (m) m≥0 X:X∩C1≠∅, t∈[0,1] X∩C2≠∅ (B.10.10) ≤ ∥Ψ1∥F ∑ F (d(x, y)) ∑ GF (m) < ∞. (B.10.11) ∞ x∈C1 m=0 y∈C2 C˜ ∈ C1 such that C1 ∩ C˜ ≠ and C2 ∩ C˜ ≠ ∅. Take L1 ∂C˜/C24 and 3 What is now left to show is the case where C1 and C2 are adjacent. Take ∅ = L2 = ∂C˜/C1. By following the same reasoning that led to equation (5.36) in [48] we get that M(C1, C2) ≤ b0(C1, C2/C˜) + b0(C1/C˜, C2) + b0(C˜ ∩ C2, (C1 ∪ C2)c) + b1(C1 ∩ C˜, C2 ∩ C˜, L1, L2) (B.10.12) 2We say that C1 and C2 are adjacent if and only if #(C1(1) ∩ C2(1)) = ∞. 3Here Ψ1 is defined through Ψ1(X) = |X|1Ψ(X). 4Here ∂C˜ means the boundary of C˜. where b1(C1 ∩ C˜, C2 ∩ C˜, L1, L2) := ∑ ∞ ∑ sup ∥Ψ(X; t)∥|X|GF (m) m=0 X⊂C˜: t∈[0,1] X∩C1∩C˜≠∅ X∩C2∩C˜≠∅ X∩(C˜c(m))≠∅ (B.10.13) ⎛ ⎞ ≤ ∥Ψ1∥F ∑ ∞ GF (m)⎜ ∑ + ∑ m=0 ⎝x∈C2∩C˜, x∈C1∩C˜,⎠ ⎟F (d(x, y)) < ∞. y∈L1(m) y∈L2(m) (B.10.14) Since the remainder of the proof can remain unchanged from [48], this concludes the proof of item 3. The proof of item 5 just follows from the fact that for any α1 ∈ SQAut(A) and for any α2 ∈ HAut(A) we have that α2 ◦ α1 ∈ SQAut(A). We now only need to comment on item 2. We must show that (γsH;t ◦ γtH;sL ⊗ γtH;sR )−1 = γsH;tL ⊗ γsH;tR ◦ γtH;s ∈ GVAut(A). (B.10.15) The proof of this starts analogously to the proof of item 1 and 3. We take Ψ = H, Ψ(0) = Hτ(Cθc∩U) + Hτ−1(Cθc∩D) and Ψ(1) = Ψ − Ψ(0). Define Ξ(s)(Z; t) again through equation (B.10.6). In analogy to what was done in equation (5.54) in [48] we obtain ∑ sup ∥Ξ(1) Z:Z⊈τ(Cθc∩U) t∈[0,1] ∥ (Z, t)∥ ≤ CF (e2IF (Ψ) − 1) ∑ 8 ∞ ∑ ∥ m=0 X:X(m)⊈τ(Cθc∩U) t∈su[0p,1] ∥Ψ(1) (X ; t)∥∥|X |GF (m). and Z⊈τ−1(Cθc∩D) and X(m)⊈τ−1(Cθc∩D) (B.10.16) If X in the last line has a non-zero contribution, then at least one of the following occurs: i. X ∩ (W (Cθ ) ∩ L) ≠ ∅ and X ∩ R ≠ ∅. ii. X ∩ (W (Cθ ) ∩ R) ≠ ∅ and X ∩ L ≠ ∅. iii. X ⊂ W (Cθ )c and (a) X ⊂ U, X ⊂ D, or (b) X ⊂ U, X ⊂ L, X ⊂ R and X(m) ∩ (τ −1(Cθc ∩ D))c ≠ ∅, or (c) X ⊂ D, X ⊂ L, X ⊂ R and X(m) ∩ (τ (Cθc ∩ U ))c ≠ ∅. This shows that we have a bound ∑ sup ∥Ξ(1) ∥ (Z, t)∥ (B.10.17) Z:Z⊈τ(Cθc∩U) t∈[0,1] and Z⊈τ−1(Cθc∩D) ≤ 8 CF (e2IF (Ψ) − 1)(b0 (W (Cθ ) ∩ L, R) + b0 (L, W (Cθ ) ∩ R) + b0 (W (Cθ )c ∩ U, W (Cθ )c ∩ D) + b1 (W (Cθ )c ∩ U ∩ L, W (Cθ )c ∩ U ∩ L, L ∩ ∂ (W (Cθ )c ∩ U ), R ∩ ∂ (W (Cθ )c ∩ U )) b1 (W (Cθ )c ∩ D ∩ L, W (Cθ )c ∩ D ∩ R, L ∩ ∂ (W (Cθ )c ∩ D), R ∩ ∂ (W (Cθ )c ∩ D))) < ∞. (B.10.18) This concludes the proof. This implies certain things for our locally generated automorphisms. From these four statements we can prove the following results: Lemma B.10.5. Take H an interaction such that there exists a 0 < ϕ < 1 satisfying that ∥H∥fϕ ≤ 1. Take θ1 and θ2 such that 0 < θ1 < θ2 < π/2 then for all Θ ∈ Aut AW(Cθ2)c and s,t ∈ there exists an a1 ∈ U(A) and a ( ) R Θ˜ ∈ Aut(AW(Cθ1)c such that ) γtH;s ◦ Θ ◦ γsH;t = Ad(a1) ◦ Θ˜. (B.10.19) Proof. We have that γtH;s ◦ Θ ◦ γsH;t = γtH;sD ⊗ γtH;sU ◦ γsH;tD ⊗ γsH;tU ◦ γHt;s ◦ Θ ◦ γsH;t ◦ γtH;sD ⊗ γtH;sU ◦ γsH;tD ⊗ γsH;tU . (B.10.20) Using that γsH;t ◦ γtH;sD ⊗ γtH;sU ∈ HAut1(A) we get that there exists some a ∈ A and η ∈ Aut(ACθ ) such that γtH;s ◦ Θ ◦ γsH;t = Ad(a) ◦ γtH;sD ⊗ γtH;sU ◦ ηs−;t1 ◦ Θ ◦ ηs;t ◦ γsH;tD ⊗ γsH;tU (B.10.21) = Ad(a) ◦ γtH;sD ⊗ γtH;sU ◦ Θ ◦ γsH;tD ⊗ γsH;tU . (B.10.22) Since by B.10.4 part 3 γsH;tD ⊗ γsH;tU ∈ GSQAut1(A) the result follows. Lemma B.10.6. Take H an interaction such that there exists a 0 < ϕ < 1 satisfying that ∥H∥fϕ ≤ 1. Take θ1 and θ2 such that 0 < θ1 < θ2 < π/2. Then for all ησg ∈ Aut(ACθ1 ∩ Aσ) (where σ ∈ {L, R} and g ∈ G) and s, t ∈ R there exist a2 , ∈ U (A), a3,σ ∈ U (Aσ ) and some η˜σg ∈ Aut(ACθ2 ∩ Aσ ) such that γtH;s ◦ ηgL ⊗ ηRg ◦ γsH;t = Ad(a2) ◦ (η˜gL ⊗ η˜gR) (B.10.23) γtH;sσ ◦ ησg ◦ γsH;tσ = Ad(a3,σ) ◦ η˜gσ. (B.10.24) Proof. In this proof, take Hsplit = HL + HR. First we show that equation (B.10.24) implies equation (B.10.23). This is because using equation (B.10.23) we get that γtH;s ◦ ηg ◦ γsH;t = γtH;s ◦ γsH;tsplit ◦ γtH;ssplit ◦ ηg ◦ γsH;tsplit ◦ γtH;ssplit ◦ γsH;t (B.10.25) = γtH;s ◦ γsH;tsplit ◦ Ad(a3,L ⊗ a3,R) ◦ η˜g ◦ γtH;ssplit ◦ γsH;t. (B.10.26) If one now uses the fact that γtH;s ◦ γsH;tsplit ∈ GVAut1(A) (see lemma B.10.4 item 2) the implication follows. To finish the proof we now only have to use the fact that the γ0H;1σ are in SQAut1(Aσ). Additionally when we add the group action, we get: Lemma B.10.7. Take H a G-invariant interaction such that there exists a 0 < ϕ < 1 satisfying that ∥H∥fϕ ≤ 1. Take θ1 and θ2 such that 0 < θ1 < θ2 < π/2. Then for all ηgσ ∈ Aut(ACθ1 ∩ Aσ ) (where σ ∈ {L, R} and g ∈ G) and s, t ∈ there exist a2 , ∈ U (A), a3,σ ∈ U (Aσ ) and some η˜σg ∈ Aut(ACθ2 ∩ Aσ such that ) R γtH;s ◦ ηgL ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU ◦ γsH;t = Ad(a2 ) ◦ (η˜gL ⊗ η˜gR ) ◦ βgU (B.10.27) γtH;sσ ◦ ησg ◦ βgσU ◦ γsH;tσ = Ad(a3,σ) ◦ η˜gσ ◦ βgσU. (B.10.28) Proof. In this proof, take again Hsplit = HL + HR. First we show that equation (B.10.28) implies equation (B.10.27). This is because using (the inverse of) equation (B.10.27) we get that γtH;s ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ γsH;t ◦ βgU−1 ◦ (η˜g )−1 (B.10.29) = (Inner) ◦ γtH;s ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ γsH;t ◦ γtH;ssplit ◦ βgU−1 ◦ (ηg)−1 ◦ γsH;tsplit ◦ γtH;s ◦ γsH;t. (B.10.30) Now using the fact that by lemma B.10.4 item 2, γsH;t ◦ γtH;ssplit ∈ GVAut1(A) this gives us = (Inner) ◦ γtH;s ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ βgU−1 ◦ (ηg)−1 ◦ γsH;t. (B.10.31) Figure B.2: This figure shows the support of the different automorphisms present in the decomposition of an SQ2-automorphism acting on the upper half plane. By taking a2 such that Ad(a2) is this inner automorphism, we can conclude the proof that equation (B.10.28) implies equation (B.10.27). Now we only have to prove equation (B.10.28). To finish the proof we now only have to use the fact that the γ0H;1σ are in GSQAut1(Aσ). B.10.2 The two translation symmetries This section will define the classes of automorphisms required in the assumptions and proofs about the H1-valued translation index. In analogy with section 2.1 from [48] we will define some classes of automorphisms (see figure B.2): Definition B.10.8. Take α ∈ Aut(A). We say that α ∈ SQAut2(A) if and oθ3n.l2y <if πfo/r2 atnhyer0e eAut Aνσ(C]θ1,θ2]∩ρ∩σ) , α]θ2,θ3],σ,ρ ∈ Aut A ( ) ( ) , α]θ3,π/2],ρ ∈ Aut Aτρ(C[θ3,π/2]∩ρ) , α]θ0.8,θ1.2],σ,ρ ∈ Aut Aνσ(C]θ0.8,θ1.2]∩ρ∩σ) , ( ) (W(C[0,θ3])/νσ(C[0,θ2]∩σ))∩ρ∩σ) ( ) α]θ1.8,θ2.2],σ,ρ ∈ Aut Aνσ(C]θ1.8,θ2.2]∩ρ∩σ) and α]θ2.8,θ3.2],σ,ρ ∈ Aut Aτρ(C]θ2.8 ( ) ( ) ,θ3.2]∩ρ∩σ) for any ρ ∈ {U,D} and σ ∈ {L,R} (here τU = τ, τD = τ−1, νR = ν and νL = ν−1) such that α = Ad(a) ◦ ⊗ α[0,θ1],σ ◦ ⊗ α]θ1,θ2],σ,ρ ◦ ⊗ α[θ3,π/2] ◦ ⊗(α]θ0.8,θ1.2],ρ,σ ⊗ α]θ1.8,θ2.2],ρ,σ ⊗ α]θ2.8,θ3.2],ρ,σ). σ σ,ρ ρ ρ,σ (B.10.32) If additionally everything (except a) commutes with βgU we say that α ∈ GSQAut2(A). We now have to define a different horizontal automorphism: Definition B.10.9. Take α ∈ Aut(A). We say that α ∈ HAut2(A) if and only if for any 0 < θ < π/2 there exists an a ∈ A and some ασ ∈ Aut(Aνσ(Cθ∩σ) ) for each σ ∈ {L, R} such that α = Ad(a) ◦ αL ⊗ αR. (B.10.33) The main reason why we introduce this new class of automorphisms is that if α ∈ HAut2(A) we automatically have that the translations of α in the horizontal directions, ν−1 ◦ α ◦ ν and ν ◦ α ◦ ν−1 are elements of HAut1(A). We will let the definition of vertical automorphism stay the same, namely VAut2(A) = VAut1(A) and GVAut2(A) = GVAut1(A). Lemma B.10.10. Lemma B.10.4 will still be true when we exchange all the 1’s for 2’s. Proof. Completely equivalent to the proof of B.10.4. Lemma B.10.11. Take θ1 and θ2 such that 0 < θ1 < θ2 < π/2. Then for all ησg ∈ Aut(Aνσ(Cθ1∩σ) (where σ ∈ {L,R} and g ∈ G), there exist ) a2,∈ U(A),a3,σ ∈ U(Aνσ(σ)) and some η˜σg ∈ Aut Aνσ(Cθ2∩σ) such that ( ) γ1H;0 ◦ ηgL ⊗ ηRg ◦ γ0H;1 = Ad(a2) ◦ (η˜gL ⊗ η˜Rg) γ1H;0νσ(σ)ησgγ0H;1νσ(σ) = Ad(a3,σ) ◦ η˜gσ. Proof. Analogous to the proof of B.10.6. Additionally when we add the group action, we get: (B.10.34) (B.10.35) Lemma B.10.12. Take H a G-invariant interaction such that there exists a 0 < ϕ < 1 satisfying that ∥H ∥fϕ ≤ 1. Take θ1 and θ2 such that 0 < θ1 < θ2 < π/2. Then for all ησg ∈ Aut(ACθ1 ∩ Aσ) (where σ ∈ {L, R} and g ∈ G), there exist a2, ∈ U(A), a3,σ ∈ U(Aσ) and some η˜σg ∈ Aut(Aνσ(Cθ2∩σ) such that ) γ1H;0 ◦ ηgL ⊗ ηgR ◦ βgU ◦ γ0H;1 = Ad(a2) ◦ (η˜gL ⊗ η˜gR) ◦ βgU γ1H;0σ ◦ ησg ◦ βgσU ◦ γ0H;1σ = Ad(a3,σ) ◦ η˜gσ ◦ βgσU. Proof. Analogous to the proof of B.10.7. (B.10.36) (B.10.37) In what follows, let H˜split := Hν−1(L) + Hν(R). We will need the following lemma: Lemma B.10.13. There exist maps AL : [0,1] → U(AL) : λ↦ → AL(λ) AR : [0,1] → U(AR) : λ↦ → AR(λ) (B.10.38) both continuous in norm topology and Φµν : [0,1] → Aut(AW(Cθ)c∩µ∩ν) : λ↦ → Φµν(λ) (B.10.39) where µ ∈ {U, D} and ν ∈ {L, ν(R)}, all four continuous in strong5 topology, satisfying that ν ◦ γ0H˜;λsplit ◦ ν−1 ◦ γλH˜;s0plit = γ0H;λL ⊗ γ0H;λν◦ν(R) ◦ γλH˜;s0plit (B.10.40) = Ad(AL(λ)) ⊗ Ad(AR(λ)) ◦ ⊗ Φµν(λ) µ∈{U,D}, ν∈{L,ν(R)} (B.10.41) and that Φµν ◦ βg = βg ◦ Φµν . Proof. The proof of this is very similar to all the other proofs in this section. We will go over the highlights. We want to define an AL(λ) and a ΦU,L ⊗ ΦD,L satisfying Ad(AL(λ)) ◦ ΦU,L ⊗ ΦD,L(λ) = γ0H;λL ◦ γλH;ν0−1(L) (B.10.42) and similarly for the right side. We will only work out this side as the other calculation is analogous. We do this in two steps. First we find an interaction Ξ satisfying γ0Ξ;λ = γ0H;λL ◦ γλH;ν0−1(L). We can do this by taking the usual Ξ(Z, t) := ∑ ∑ X(m)(γ0H;tν−1(L)(H˜(X, t))) ∞ ∆ m=0 X⊂Z X(m)=Z 5Meaning that Φµν(λ)(A) is continuous for all A ∈ A. (B.10.43) (B.10.44) OPERATORS BELONGING TO ω ◦ γ0H;1 where H˜ := HL − Hν−1(L). We can now define ΦµL(λ) := γ0Ξ;Wλ(Cθ)c∩µ∩L. (B.10.45) This means that we can satisfy B.10.41 if Ad(AL) = γ0Ξ;λ ◦ γλΞ;′0 Ξ′ := ΞW(Cθ)c∩U∩L + ΞW(Cθ)c∩D∩L. (B.10.46) Using the same argument as before, this can be realised when we have Ad(AL(λ)) = γ0Ξ˜;λ (B.10.47) where Ξ˜(Z, t) := ∑ ∑ ∆X(m)(γ0Ξ;′t(Ξ(X, t) − Ξ′(X, t))). ∞ (B.10.48) m=0 X⊂Z X(m)=ZThe last part of the proof is to show that ∑ ∥ Z ∈BZ2 Ξ˜(Z, t)∥ < ∞ which can be done using similar techniques as before. This means that we can simply define ⎛ AL(λ) := T exp⎝−i ∫λ ⎞ ds ∑ Ξ˜(Z, s)⎠ (B.10.49) 0 Z∈B 2 Z and this is by construction bounded and continuous in λ. B.11 Operators belonging to ω ◦ γ0H;1 We will complete the proof of theorem 5.4.26. Lemma B.11.1. The following operators now belong to ω ◦ γ0H;1 : ṽ = π0(A1)vπ0(A1)† (B.11.1) W˜g = π0(A1)ϕ1(δgL ⊗ δgR)ϕ2(Wg)π0(A†1) (B.11.2) ũσ(g, h) = π0(A1)ϕ1(δgσWgδhσWg†uσ(g, h)(δgσh)†)π0(A1)† (B.11.3) K˜gσ = π0(A1)ϕ1(v†δσgvKgσ(δσg)†)π0(A1 )† (B.11.4) where δgσ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1σ (Aσ2,g ) with A2σ,g defined in 5.4.115 and A1 was defined in equation (5.4.113). Proof. To do this we first state that a small calculation shows that ∀x ∈ U(H0) satisfying that ∃ξ ∈ Aut(A) such that Ad(x) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ξ (B.11.5) we get that Ad π0(A1)xπ0(A†1)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ Θ˜ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ Θ˜ ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ ξ ◦ γ0H;1. ( (B.11.6) This already proves that Ad π0(A1)vπ0(A†1)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ Θ˜ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ Θ˜ ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ τ ◦ γ0H;1 ( (B.11.7) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ Θ˜ ◦ τ. (B.11.8) To show the second one we get that Ad(ϕ1(δg)ϕ2(Wg)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (B.11.9) = Ad(ϕ1(δg)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 (B.11.10) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ Ad(γ0H;1L(AL2,g) ⊗ γ0H;1R(AR2,g)) ◦ ηg ◦ βgU ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0 (B.11.11) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ Ad(AL2,g ⊗ AR2,g) ◦ γ1H;0split ◦ ηg ◦ βUg ◦ γ0H;1split ◦ γ1H;0. (B.11.12) Using equation (5.4.115) on this we obtain = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ η˜g ◦ βgU ◦ γ1H;0. (B.11.13) Inserting this in equation (B.11.6) with x = ϕ1(δg)ϕ2(Wg) and ξ = γ0H;1 ◦ η˜g ◦ βgU ◦ γ1H;0 now proves the fact that W˜g is an operator belonging to ω ◦ γ0H;1. Proving that ũσ(g, h) and K˜gσ are operators belonging to ω ◦ γ0H;1 is completely analogous. This concludes the proof. We will now finish the proof of theorem 5.5.27. OPERATORS BELONGING TO ω ◦ γ0H;1 Lemma B.11.2. The following operators now belong to ω ◦ γ0H;1 : ṽ = π0(A1)vπ0(A1)† (B.11.14) w˜ = π0(A1)wπ0(A1)† (B.11.15) W˜g = π0(A1)ϕ˜1(δgL ⊗ δgR)ϕ˜2(Wg)π0(A†1) (B.11.16) K˜gσ = π0(A1)ϕ˜1(v†δσgvKgσ(δgσ)†)π0(A1 )† (B.11.17) ˜bgσ = π0(A1)w†ϕ˜1(δgR)wϕ˜1(ϵgR)ϕ˜1(bgR)ϕ˜1(δgR)†π0(A1)† (B.11.18) h˜g = π0(A1)ϕ˜1(hg)π0(A1). (B.11.19) Here the δσg := π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H˜;1split(Aσ2,g) with Aσ2,g as defined in 5.5.100 and A1 is as defined in equation (5.5.98). Proof. The proof that the first four operators belong to ω ◦ γ0H;1 is completely analogous to what was done in the proof of B.11.1 and we will therefore focus on the ˜bσg part. To show this, observe that we have Ad(ϕ˜1(ϵRgbRg)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (B.11.20) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1 ◦ Ad(AR ηRg ◦ βgRU(A†R)) ◦ ν ◦ ν−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ ν (B.11.21) ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1 ◦ Ad(AR ηRg ◦ βgRU(A†R)) ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ ν (B.11.22) ◦ (βgν−1(RU))−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1 ◦ Ad(AR) ◦ ηRg ◦ βgRU ◦ Ad(A†R) ◦ ν (B.11.23) ◦ (βgν−1(RU))−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ν−1 ◦ Ad(AR) ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ Ad(A†R) ◦ ν ◦ γ0H;1split (B.11.24) ◦ ν−1 ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (βgν−1(RU))−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0. After using the restriction to R of equation (5.5.86), this leads to = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (⊗µΦµν(R))−1 ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ (⊗µΦµν(R)) ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν (B.11.25) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (βgν−1(RU))−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0. On the other hand we have that Ad(w†ϕ˜1(δgσ)w) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ Ad(Aσ2,g) ◦ γ1H;0 ◦ ν. (B.11.26) This leads us to Ad(w†ϕ˜1(δgR)wϕ˜1(ϵRgbRg)) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ (B.11.27) = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ ν−1 ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ Ad(AR2,g) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ ηgR ◦ βgRU ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ ν (B.11.28) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (βgν−1(RU))−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜gR ◦ βgRU ◦ ν (B.11.29) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (βgν−1(RU))−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0. Now define S = {(0, y)|y ∈ Z} then = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜Rg ◦ βgν(RU) ◦ βgS ◦ ν (B.11.30) ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (βgν−1(S))−1 ◦ (βgRU)−1 ◦ (ηRg)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ γ1H;0. OPERATORS BELONGING TO ω ◦ γ0H;1 249 Doing the same thing on the right will give us Ad(w†ϕ˜1(δgR)wϕ˜1(ϵRgbRg)ϕ˜1(δgR)†) ◦ π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜gR ◦ βgν(RU) ◦ ν ◦ γ1H˜;0split ◦ (βRgU)−1 ◦ (ηgR)−1 ◦ γ0H˜;1split ◦ Ad((AR2,g)†) ◦ γ1H;0 = π0 ◦ α0 ◦ Θ ◦ γ0H;1 ◦ ν−1 ◦ η˜gR ◦ βgν(RU) ◦ ν ◦ (βRgU)−1 ◦ (η˜gR)−1 ◦ ◦γ1H;0. (B.11.31) The role that the A1 will play is analogous to the proof of B.11.1 (see equation (B.11.6)), concluding the proof. Bibliography [1] Aasen, D., Wang, Z., and Hastings, M. B.
